description:
Rounding up to 4 stars, I've had better ramen but not bad by any means. The restaurant is "fast casual" as you wait in line to order, take a number, and they bring your food to wherever you're seated. 

The menu is fairly small and is nothing extravagant but covers all the bases for your ramen cravings. I had the taitan, pork and chicken broth based, served with pork, bamboo, and soft boiled egg. The broth had good flavor, but probably could've also been richer. I was really wanting that richness you find in tonkotsu ramen. My biggest complaint that the broth was also only warm, could've been hotter. 

Overall, decent place for lunch, but would be on the search if you're wanting something more authentic.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Overpriced, mediocre Japanese food but in a good location with a nice ambiance. I came here in the past out of convenience and got forgettable ramen. The next time I came I got the karaage happy hour appetizer for $7, which only came with 4 TINY pieces of chicken. It'd be one thing if they were 4 normal sized karaage pieces but they were the size of popcorn chicken! It even tasted like the popcorn chicken you'd get from a Quickly's. In fact, I probably would have preferred Quickly's over this. 

It was pretty laughable and I honestly thought I might have offended the waitress somehow to warrant such a small amount. 

Whatever the case, this place is a rip-off and exploiting their convenient location and the Michael Mina brand.
author: Danielle C.

description:
Very disappointing.  I would expect for the quality of this ramen the price to be cut more than in half.  I spent roughly $20 for a bowl of ramen and Thai milk tea.  
The tea was way to milky, I'm not sure there was even tea in it. 
I ordered the Tokyo style ramen, the broth was super oily, flavorful but I'm pretty sure most of it was grease... enough to leave the film in my mouth. The pork in the soup had a terrible flavor but even worse was the texture.  This meat was tougher than a piece of jerky. This is by far the worst ramen I have ever had.  Pretty bummed I spent that much on something this terrible.
author: Meredith J.

description:
Ordered take-out and got the Tokyo-Shoyu ramen. I've definitely had my fair share of ramen and overall, this spot was okay for taste but pretty expensive as well. We decided on Ramen Bar since it was close to the office and my friend was really craving some soup. 

The base price for the ramen was $14 and you could add additional toppings for an additional charge. The pork chashu was tender for the 2-3 small pieces that you get. The egg was actually cooked surprisingly well and had the soft inside that you look for. The bamboo was actually a bit odd for me since it was far softer than usual and actually a bit sweet. Usually i like the menma (bamboo shoots) to have more of a bite instead of dissolving in your mouth. The noodles were pretty standard and the broth was average as well. Essentially an average bowl of ramen with no frills or fireworks. 

Probably won't go again since the price point was a bit high for an okay bowl of ramen.
author: Eric L.

description:
Good service, clean place, but maybe I should of ordered Ramen. Instead I ordered the special of the day the TRB Burger which is a double patty chicken burger

Nothing special about the flavor. Maybe it wasn't what I expected, but the flavor fell way too short for me and the chips that came with weren't all that either. 

Definitely will come try something more traditional next time.
author: Ahmed H.

description: Utterly shit service and a joke of an appetizer. There were literally 5 tiny pieces of chicken and some bits. I actually laughed out loud when the waitress brought it out.
author: Teresa L.

description:
Came here because it was close to a friend's workplace. Food is pretty average- nothing good but nothing terrible. 

I ordered the tuna poke, which was basically a lot of white rice and not enough tuna. It tasted alright, although I had half a bowl of rice left when I finished eating. Would not order this dish again unless they improve the quantity.
author: Karanveer M.

description: Not sure why this place's rating is under 4 stars. It's good, and, surprisingly, one of the few ramen places in SF's Financial District where people can get their ramen on during lunchtime.
author: Katherine G.

description: They have great happy hour specials: chicken kaarage, wings and baos are all $5. Tried the spicy miso and shoyu ramen and the noodles were cooked perfectly. The egg is so good I wanted to order another one. Save room for dessert and try the wasabi pea rice crispie treat
author: Weich Y.

description: Ah, I've come here a handful of times just because I was craving ramen in FiDi and it's better than Ramen Underground. However, if you really want solid ramen, leave the FiDi area.
author: Sophia L.

description:
The idea of a casual ramen shop like The Ramen Bar sounds great in theory, but the quality just isn't there.

For one, they certainly skimp on the meat and veggies. The Tokyo Shoyu only had two small, fatty pieces of pork. In addition, the noodles barely had any flavor to them - they should've taken on some of the flavor of the broth, but that too didn't have any noticeable flavors to it.

It should be worth noting too that this place is in the heart of the Financial District. We went before the lunch rush, and still had to wait a good 15 minutes to even take our order. The line was twice as long once we were through it, so this probably isn't the best spot if you're pressed for time.
author: Casey S.

description:
Good Ramen - Great Broth 
Nicely cooked Egg
Was central but crowded as is everything on a busy weekday in SF
a little pricey and small portions - but that's typical for downtown SF
I will return
author: Doug L.

description:
So this place is alright. The location works for me and it's fairly affordable. The actual ramen is average tasting. No matter how much spicy stuff I put it in, the soup got mild hot at best. So that was disappointing but hey what do you expect for Ramen downtown? Overall, I mainly liked how chill the place was and the ambiance was nice. Kind of loud at lunch but whatevs. They have "healthy" options too. 

Good place for a quick lunch meal with friends or colleagues. Not a date place unless you're "casual" with them. It's not an impressive spot but it gets the job done. Lunch time gets packed with a line out the door so arrive in 11 o'clock hour or after 1pm to avoid the line. Then again people are into lines so suit yourselves.
author: Rose E.

description: Love the cozy atmosphere here. Yes, it's a bit pricey, but the ramen was fantastic and the cocktails were as well. It's a great place to eat and hang out. I'll definitely be going back!
author: Jane N.

description:
Sad.

Worst ramen over $10 I've ever had.
On par with the packaged ones you boil up yourself. 

I came here for lunch with high hopes.. but for $14 per bowl, I expected more than fresh out of plastic noodles and overly salty broth. 

Their karaage that costs $11 will give you 8-10 pieces of fried chicken bits (seriously, bits) that actually make you miss kfc.
author: Atsuko Y.

description:
Came here on a work lunch break because I work so close. I didn't have high expectations after reviewing on Yelp. After eating there it was pretty much what I expected it to be, expensive and nothing amazing.

I went there around 11:30AM to beat the lunch rush. You wait in line to order your food and get a table after. I tried the Hokkaido ramen with chicken. It was a bit different than other ramen that I've tried at different restaurants. Not a huge fan of the garnish, it overpowers the flavor of the broth and other topping in the bowl. The broth had a slight kick to it but was nothing special. Seemed to be on the oily and thicker side. Was not a fan of whatever spice they put on the egg...if I didn't add the chili paste, the chicken would have been extremely bland and dry.

Overall for a $15~ bowl of ramen, I was not impressed. I would only come back here if I was craving ramen at work and didn't want to travel far to get it.
author: Allison S.

description:
The Hokkaido ramen was delicious upon first taste, but a few sips in, I found the broth to be too salty/heavy. As for the veggies, I'm usually a huge fan of arugula, but I just don't think it's a good complement to Asian foods and especially ramen. I did enjoy the seaweed though, and the gooey egg yolk was perfection. 
Service was fast and there was plenty of seating. Would recommend this as a casual meeting place for weekday post-work dinners.
author: Amy C.

description:
Came here for lunch with my dad and it was PACKED. Line out the door and lots of furtive glances for a seat.

Service & atmosphere: the space is pretty cute with sake bottles and lanterns everywhere. Communal tables, bar seating, and patio tables for lunch time. Service was fast and friendly.

Food: so we had a salmon poke bowl, Tokyo-style ramen with extra pork belly and shoyu egg, and I had Thai iced tea with boba. Boba was pretty good. The salmon poke bowl was yummy; loved the seaweed salad, radishes, and other extras included. The poke sauce itself was richer and more savory than other poke but I'm not complaining. The ramen had a flavorful broth, lots of seaweed and noodles, and juicy pork slices. HOWEVER THE EXTRA PORK BELLY WE ADDED WAS AMAZING- I'm talking fatty, flavorful, juicy af pork belly slices.

The only downside is the price for portions. The poke bowl could have used bigger cubes of salmon and I've had bigger ramen portions for less money at other ramen spots. Anyway, still go and try it and get the pork belly for God's sake.
author: Marissa F.

description:
We missed the lunch hour rush and had plenty of seats to choose from. We sat outside and I noticed that the condiments were not covered. Seeing as the table was outdoors, the condiments are exposed to dust, city dirt and possible spit from previous table conversations. It's just good practice to have shared condiments covered.

The ramen itself was pretty disappointing.The shoyu tonkotsu ramen lacked flavor. However, the broth in the hokkaido ramen was very flavorful but felt a little too heavy as I kept eating. The soy cured egg was different than other eggs I've had, it had a slight smokey taste to it. When we finished our ramen, I glanced down at our bowls and was grossed out by how much oil was floating at the top. I'd like to add that within an hour of eating this, I felt extremely exhausted and felt like I was coming down with something. Possibly from all the oil and dehydration from the broth.
author: Carmen C.

description:
Another place that my workplace loves! This review solely highlights the poke. 

Food: Poke has become my comfort food, so I was stoked to try the non-traditional Poke Trio which includes octupus, tuna and salmon. The fish has consistently been fresh in flavor and vibrant in color. I tend to order only the salad (sans-rice) and appreciate that they use really fresh greens that include some herbs, they top off the fish with fresh chunks of avocado, cucumber, green onions, furikake, poke sauce and their house mayo. Overall, tasty and super fresh!

Price: A little pricey, however quality and flavor is always consistently great.

Service: Quick and friendly service. Also, if you order beforehand they are punctual. 

Ambiance: Clean and spacious. 

Overall: If you don't want to stand in the long lines at the handful of poke spots in the FiDi, I highly recommend Ramen Bar's poke. Fresh, fun and flavorful.
author: Astrid Z.

description:
Good walk up location, great outdoor seating.
This place was really good and hip. 
A large selection of Raman and everything tasted super fresh. I still don't know how they get the egg yoke cooked so perfectly. I look forward to going back.
author: Moe F.

description:
Not gonna lie, I wasn't expecting much of this place, cuz, let's face it.. ramen.. in the FIDI.. opened by a non-Asian person?
But it was unexpectedly good!

Falls into the average price-range for ramen in the city ($12-16).

I ordered the TanTan ramen for $14. I was expecting skimpy portions, but I was wrong! It was just right.

Overall very good - I'd give it a solid 4! The only thing that I would knock off was the temperature of the ramen.. it was just warm when it arrived, which was a little disappointing, but everything else about it was really good (noodles, broth (depth in flavor and consistency), and toppings!). My friend got the Tokyo Shoyu and she said she really liked it. I didn't try it, but man, the soft boiled egg looked ON POINT - that barely runny phase, with a nice deep brownish color for the yolk :3
It took maybe 15 minutes to come during lunch rush hour, which was a little long, but I didn't mind as I was catching up with a friend. 

I would return and definitely recommend!
Hopefully, the other ramens are just as good.
author: Emily C.

description: I was waiting 20 mins (WITH NO LINES AT ALL) to get this "today special". Look at this, it's nothing! And it's cost me $16 including tips. So regretful that I tipped before getting the food. Nice location couldn't make me a little cheerful when eating this. It wasted my whole Friday! Will never come back here.
author: Doan Y.

description:
I have come here a few times for lunch during the week. Office is literally next door.  The process runs suitably fast for a lunch in FiDi, so no complaints there.

I have had only ramens, the Tokyo Ramen and the Ginger Chicken.  It is pretty good stuff, I mean it is not the best you can have in the city, but I enjoy the convenience and the food is fresh.  The sauces can be on the heavy side, and the chicken is a little bland, but all in all it is a good deal of food for the $12-$15 you pay, and that reduces the pinch of the cost, which is on the high side for ramen, but then again, their rent must be sky high t 101 Cali.
author: Massimo M.

description:
I've been to Ramen Bar's physical location a few times and ate dinner a la takeout from Caviar tonight. While the restaurant's ambiance is nice, and that it offers a great selection of appetizers and rice dishes, the ramen is by far the worst I've ever had. A couple of reasons:

1) There is no richness to the broth. It's clear and the flavor comes from being purely oily, without any depth. It's not that far off from oily instant ramen broth

2) The noodles are instant ramen-like and clump together

3) The chashu literally tastes like rubber. There's no softness to it or smokiness on the exterior

I recommend coming here to try their other food items.
author: Amy G.

description: The Ramen here are descent, you can order online. It's not ship but on the range of other place around the financial district. Good value for me, will appreciate to have a full eggs next time
author: Cédric F.

description: I am so annoyed with this place. I waited 30 minutes for a simple Poke bowl. The bag was on the counter and nobody called my name, when I asked if it was done yet they said it's coming, but it was there the whole time. Thanks to the delay, I got an $85 parking ticket for being four minutes late to getting back to my car, thanks to my 35 minute wait for a poke bowl. I'm never coming back here again, terrible customer service and slow.
author: Christine L.

description:
I didn't come here for the ramen as I had eaten lunch nearby beforehand. Instead, I ordered the lychee oolong tea with boba.

The lychee oolong tea was fantastic! Loaded with sliced lychee in the drink itself, it wasn't too sweet. However, the boba was not great because it was still hard and dense (probably from the fridge.)

If you're going to get a drink here, probably avoid getting the boba.
author: Dustin W.

description:
I must admit I did not know what to expect from ramen conceived by Michael Mina.  I knew it would not be really Japanese and expected it to be like the ramen place on College Ave in Rockridge, which I was not crazy about.

Actually, I liked it a lot.  I had the vegetarian ramen but added pork belly.  I enjoyed it and thought the soup was flavorful.  That's one of my biggest issues with some ramen places. My friend thought the soup was too salty but I was happy with the miso flavor.  She also did not enjoy the arugula

I wanted to try the ramen with seafood dumplings that many Yelpers mentioned but it is no longer on the menu.

The atmosphere is very pleasant and they still have the free ramen for board game offer.  It's only for specific games like Monopoly and Battleship and the games must be the complete set.

I will definitely be back.
author: Joanna S.

description: Second time in a week I went there for dinner and the doors were closed for a private event. If you want an event venue, make your space an event venue. Not a restaurant that is open sometimes.
author: Molly Z.

description:
The food was very average. I ordered the Mushroom & Soy Ramen ($12) with Soy-Cured Egg ($2). 

I didn't expect it to taste spicy! It would have been nice if the menu showed which dishes were spicy. At some points, I felt as if I was eating ginger even though I did not see it listed as an ingredient on the menu. The food was also kind of salty! I could not finish the soup. 

The portion size was decent. I felt really full at the end. I liked how there were so many mushrooms! I have never eaten so many beech mushrooms! It was interesting seeing seaweed and fried onion in my dish even though they were not listed on the menu.

The employees at the restaurant were nice.

The poke bowl looked much better than the ramen!
author: Kristina M.

description:
Fast and efficient service, but subpar ramen. Sadly, something was just off about the flavor.

I came here on a Monday afternoon around 5:00pm and found the restaurant mercifully empty. It seems like lunchtime in Fidi are their peak hours, because the restaurant was nearly deserted when I walked in the door. The lady at the register cheerfully took my order and my food came out within 10 minutes, which was great!

I tried the noodles and broth and it just wasn't very satisfying to me. The broth was rich and creamy, but seemed to lack flavor. Noodles were decently chewy, but not amazing. Pork belly also seemed to be lacking in flavor. It was mildly disappointing, given the convenience of the location (within 5 minutes on foot from Embarcadero BART) in the middle of the Financial District.
author: Allison T.

description: The ramen pork is like butter! The poke is great too but it's spicy and not really advertised as such from what I recall. You order first and they bring it out to you. The bowls are large but it seemed like they gave a little less this time around.
author: Ben L.

description:
Coworker and I came here and the place was jam-packed. He went early to line up and he was still in line when I got there. This frigid weather makes people want to eat ramen...lol

We both got the Hokkaido Ramen w/ pork and it was really good. Wish it was a little bigger cuz I coulda eaten more. 
My 3 fave ramen places are Ramen Dojo, Hokkaido Ramen Santouka and now Ramen House
author: Linda W.

description: ShoYu from Tokyo hahaha soap base is so weak compared to even the $2 dollar ramen In Tokyo. The cha Shu is chewy and super fat and under braised. It only lost a star because of the long wait. But other than that, greatful for a spot close to my office that I can walk and get a bowl of ramen
author: Carmin W.

description:
Horrible 
The host was unfriendly and unwelcoming. They removed my favourite kale salad from the menu :( and their service has slowed down! 
The cucumber salad I ordered to satiate my salad craving was boring and bland. Also, did I mention it was bite sized ? 
Will not be coming back to this place again. Bye ramen bar!
author: Yoshita S.

description:
Ramen bar gets 3 stars for the flavorful ramen - I wouldn't say it's that great of ramen for the price ($13 got tonkatsu) which is pretty expensive for ramen. I do take into consideration that they are renting a nice space in San Francisco and also have a ton of staff, which is why I keep coming back. Only thing I've really noticed is that their staff isn't very happy, at least that's what it seems from a costumers perspective. 

I would recommend on a cold, or even warm day. I mean its ramen! I'd say it's one of the better ramen spots in the financial district, and like I said I keep coming back!
author: Angella G.

description:
When I was interning in the financial district, this was my and my intern friend's go-to spot for lunch!

Okay, ramen here isn't the best we've ever had but it was good enough to fill us up, service is usually very good and speedy, and it was very much ~aesthetic~. It was also very convenient for us since it was quite close to our building. The surrounding area is gorgeous and we always opted to eat outside. 

The chefs definitely go the extra mile to get the eggs perfect and dresses the ramen well. Sometimes the items given in the bowl don't match well with the ramen and my friend thought it was added for looks. The seaweed, for example. The bamboo shoots are also surprisingly not bad! The broth is flavorful but also oily and salty most times.

My go to ramen is the Shoyu tonkotsu-the chasu is the best.
author: Annie P.

description: I wouldn't make my way specifically out here given the quality of the food, but I would consider eating here for an office lunch break. It's pretty standard ramen, nothing special or fancy. Everything about this place is average haha.
author: Kristi H.

description:
This place is not the best ramen nor is it the worst. I got the Hokkaido Ramen with both chicken and pork with the presumption that I would have a burst of Hokkaido flavor but it tasted just like any soup base.. just slightly more salty than I would have liked. Although, I do appreciate that 

I also got the Karage. That was nicely fried and the sauce was delicious as well. Probably one of the best aspects of this place is the fact that the customer service is good, ambiance is nice, and more importantly, we got 25 cent beers! 

I would come back here to try the other items on the menu but probably not for ramen. 

FYI, there's no line after work around 5pm and later but there is usually a long line for lunch so plan accordingly!
author: Amy L.

description: Ok, I happened to be in the city and lo and behold, this place was underneath the building I had a meeting at.  So, I popped in after my meeting was over and ordered the Tokyo ramen with corn and tempura mushrooms.  The ramen was ok- not the best that I've ever had but certainly not the worst.  It's just not as chewy as I would like and the broth was ok.  You order at the counter and they bring the ramen to you at your table when it's ready.  If I'm in the area again, I would come back to try the poke bowls.
author: Susan C.

description:
For what it is, it's a good place for the lunch crowd. Now that I live in the city I'm constantly on the lookout for ramen places. 

I would say the ramen here is gateway ramen, not the best I've ever had but not the worst either. 

You order at the counter and they bring your ramen to your table. FYI at lunchtime you're elbow to elbow with everyone else so maybe if you come at 11:30 or 1pm it'll be better for more intimate conversations.

I had the Shoyu Tonkotsu $14 (shoyu tare, chasu, ginger, kikurage, soy-cured egg): The bowl came out quickly and the slices of chasu weren't too fatty (which for me was good) and the soup was flavorful and had some depth.

Noodles were slightly overcooked but that may because I went after the lunch rush.  

Good place to go for a quick lunch if you're in the area.
author: Nette T.

description:
Another review from the office chair! The best way I can describe this meal is...this would be the type of ramen I would make at home if I threw random things in together.

Meh, I've had better. I got the Hokkaido ramen and the soup base was alright, thick, slightly spicy, but nothing spectacular. They give you a LOT of noodles, but not much else, but I guess that's how ramen tends to be. Noodles were kind of soft. This was paired with arugula-- an interesting choice, although the arugula lacked its usual spicy freshness and was a strange pairing with the ramen. It just wilted in the soup and didn't add anything to it. The bamboo shoots were tender. The chashu was heavy in pork flavor, but not cha siu sauce. The only redeeming thing here was the slow egg, which had a good soy sauce flavor. Yolk could have been a tad more runny. Corn was on the firm side and didn't complement the dish. 2/5.

The yuzu topped vanilla panna cotta with crunch, on the other hand, is something I would get again. Then again, I'm a fan of yuzu-flavored items. I though the two paired each other quite well. The other dessert I've had from here (can't recall what) was also tasty! 3/5.
--

Edit: I came back for the poke bowl, and you know, it wasn't half bad. There weren't any options for sauce, so when it arrived, a marinated, somewhat spicy bowl looked me in the face. The salmon was pretty buttery, but I think the taste was masked by the spiciness. The daikon's crispiness was a perfect balance to the oiliness of the salmon. The sumumono was less vinegary than I've had (I like this sorta style too) and the seaweed salad felt more upscale somehow (which is to be expected at a place like this). The nutty brown rice reminded me of the rice at Blue Hawaii. Not a bad poke choice, though I do prefer my fish virgin :P. 3.5/5.
author: Nicole H.

description:
I had high expectations, as there's always a crowd (and it's a great location in the California 101 plaza),  but the broth seemed to be too high in sodium for me (I ordered a  vegetarian ramen noodle dish with mushrooms I believe), so I didn't finish my soup.  Alas, I don't think I'll be coming back.

On the plus,  there seemed to be some interesting desserts, pastries, etc. for sale on the side.
author: Roni K.

description:
My friends and I were craving something warm with all the rainy weather so this place was a great spot. Ramen Bar gets crazy packed during the lunch rush even around 11:30AM so I definitely recommend ordering online and scheduling a time to just pick it up. The location is great in that there's quite a bit of indoor/outdoor seating as long as you get there before the rush. 

I ended up getting the Tokyo Ramen which was pretty good for the convenience. I enjoyed that the noodles were nice and chewy and added plenty of bamboo. I felt that the broth was on the salty side, but that could just be me. For $15 it was a decently priced/filling lunch option in the area. Service is friendly here as well. Even if you order to-go you can sit at one of the tables and they'll still clean your stuff for you. 

My other friends had some of the rolls/poke bowls which they thoroughly enjoyed. Not sure if i'll be a regular here since I can get cheaper & larger portioned alternatives in FiDi, but it's solid for a quick meal.
author: Keizzel C.

description: Not sure why I keep ordering ahead on chow now since even at the least busy times of day , well past lunch rush hour, they still can't be bothered to even start on my order until I arrive, 10 minutes past what the email confirmation promised. It's great showing up and seeing the staff standing around perplexed about why I'm there hoping to get the lunch I already ordered.
author: Craig S.

description:
With a show to attend nearby, our group decided to check out the Happy Hour at the Ramen Bar for pre-show drinks and food.  Their "Happiest Hours are Mondays to Fridays from 4 - 7pm.  The menu included ramen, udon, poke bowls, salad, side and dessert selections and daily specials.

They also had monthly dine-in specials.  For May, you could get any beer, draft, bottle or can for $.25 with a purchase of an entrée.  For June, $25 gets a pitcher of beer, choice of two appetizers and popcorn.

Since we were here on a Thursday and I decided to try the Ramen Bar Wagyu Burger.  The double patties were perfectly cooked medium as ordered with Japanese pickled vegetables condiments in a black sesame bun with house made chips on the side.

Tokyo-style Ramen - friend enjoyed the ramen and impressed with the beautifully prepared soy-cured egg.   

We were all impressed with the Ramen Bar Happy Hour offerings and agreed it goes on our "HH List".
author: Al L.

description: Service was great and food came out fairly fast. My tan tan ramen and my friend's black miso ramen were both a little too salty, but also a bit bland at the same time. Not the worst ramen I've ever eaten, but also not the best. Portion sizes are more than I had expected and each dish was presented nicely. I'd give it a try if you are unsure, but personally I don't think I'd be back.
author: Elaina N.

description:
I work close-by and was craving soup so I stopped in for my lunch!

It can get pretty busy during the lunch hour....be prepared or schedule your lunch before or after the lunch rush. And don't forget your stamp card (or make sure you get one). 

Staff is friendly and helpful in spite of rush periods. 

I ordered the Chicken Ginger ramen. The broth was pretty flavorful for a lighter broth. Hearty and filling without the super guilty feeling you would get from most ramen broths. 

Overall, I like this place and I plan to come back for my lunch one of these days.
author: Sofia R.

description: Best poke I've ever had, and spectacular ramen. And yes, it better be for the price. I love order at the counter places. Went here with coworkers on a cold day and my only complaint is they left the door open and it was absolutely freezing sitting inside.
author: Natalie H.

description:
only just okay. more expensive than it should be (IMO) and kinda disappointing for the price. I'll continue to eat here because I love ramen and it's really close to my office, but value is not great.

lines are long at lunch but it does move quickly. add-ons are $2 (!!) and the spicy soup isn't very spicy. 

but with the dearth of good ramen in FiDi and SoMa, it's worth a visit
author: Bob U.

description:
I feel Ramen bar has come a long way from maybe what they used to be when they first opened as i've heard just okay things about this place. I've been here twice in the past year and a half and had pretty good experiences with the ramen quality and service. Prices are a bit steep, but it's expected being in FiDi.

There hasn't been much of a wait when I've been here, and I think this would be considered more of a treat for me than to get it often. They offer a limited selection of ramen: ginger chicken, shoyu tonkotsu, Tokyo style, Hokkaido, and mushroom&soy all ranging from $12-14 a bowl. I've gotten the shoyu tonkotsu both times and my other friends have had the mushroom&soy and the Hokkaido. I am a huge fan of the broth, egg, and noodles here because it's so flavorful and everything is done well. I feel no matter what you get, you'll enjoy a rich bowl of ramen here. They also have poke, udon, and salad selections if you aren't feeling ramen, and they offer a variety of teas and beer on draft. 

I think this is one of the much better ramen joints in financial district/downtown area. This month of May they had a special for .25 beer with a purchase of a meal after 4pm. Not bad for a happy hour special!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
I might be biased because I didn't eat for the whole day before coming here for dinner, so bear that in mind. 

I came at 7PM on a weekday, so it was relatively empty. I got the tonkotsu ramen and maybe I was starving so that's why I thought this but it felt like forever until they got my food out... which was strange since there weren't many people there, but could just be me being impatient. This place gets super popular on certain days - I tried to come for dinner on a weekend once and couldn't even get a seat. 

The food itself:
I am personally a big ramen fan. Maybe I just enjoy eating noodles for a reason, so I was pretty excited to eat here especially since it seemed so popular and my friends had all recommended it. Location is also super convenient. The noodles were decent as was the soup. I ate it so fast I can't describe the details, but I would've liked there to be more The pork was sliced very thin but that's how I like it. I would've definitely put less ginger in the soup as it felt like every other bite I was getting was overpowered by ginger (which I am not a fan of). Overall, I don't think this is the best ramen I've had, but I did like the decorations and vibe of the place.
author: Michelle L.

description:
$17 for a Hokkaido Ramen to go. The broth was sweet?

Not my fav but I was in a hurry.
author: Natalie P.

description: Solid spot for veg mushroom and soy ramen. I love their liberal use of toppings - mine had corn, bamboo, seaweed, ginger, and small brown beech mushrooms- yum! It's hard to make a veg broth umami-rich, but they did a pretty good job with miso. In terms of wow-deliciousness, I don't think this is on par with Mensho's vegan tan tan mein, but I appreciated the quick in and out nature of this place for lunch.
author: Jean L.

description: I came here for dinner after work one day and I ordered the chicken ramen. I thought it was really plain and did not have much flavor. It was a pretty mediocre bowl of ramen and it wasn't cheap either.
author: Jamie N.

description:
I've been here a few times, to try the poke bowl and have their ramen and milk teas. I honestly want to like it, and thanks to the Thanx app, when I spend money at Pabu, it earns me a free entree at ramen bar! 

It's a quick lunch, and I like the environment but the ramen just isn't that great. I see them churning them out at the open kitchen, and I just feel like something's missing. Some veggies or garnish or just some umami taste that's missing in a one dimensional bowl. The $16 poke bowls are not worth it, but I tried it once. It's a big bowl w rice, lettuce and fish. The poke seasoning was very basic and there's just too many fidi options to spend that much on such a bowl.
author: Joanna S.

description: Solid but not great. It's a very laid back ramen spot which is nice. You order at a counter then go sit down and they bring the ramen to you. Not expensive or cheap, good portion size.
author: James A.

description:
Overall, this place is Not Bad. If you need ramen and are nearby, it'll fit the bill. But if you are looking for your favorite ramen, I'd be surprised if you find it here.

The ordering is theoretically efficient but still a bit on the slow side - ordering ahead online is a much better idea. Somehow the menu manages to be both compact and multi-faceted, so it feels like there are plenty of options. I went with the Tokyo Ramen, which was fine - the broth was pretty flat, but the other ingredients managed to perk things up a bit, especially the bitter greens. The mushroom broth seemed a lot more interesting and umami-packed.

The space is sort of hectic at lunchtime, but once you get yourself situated, it works out all right. I liked the interesting drink options they had! I guess if you're nearby it's an ok ramen option, but I'd definitely go elsewhere if possible.
author: Lisa K.

description:
First time I tried this place I wasn't convinced but after going back I am really starting to appreciate it. Great spot for lunch but get there a few minutes before noon because the line will get long quick during this time.

Also, found a bug in my ramen once and the manager was very apologetic and treated us well the next time I went back. 

Overall good food and good vibes.
author: Rosy C.

description:
# 14 The Ramen Bar *Rod Boba SF Rating * 6/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 

My ranking is simply for the boba. The boba is solid which is why this place checks in at #14 of 51 in my rankings below. I like that they have the extra big version option and the location is obviously good. 

Rod M tours San Francisco area in search of the BEST standard milk tea with boba. I have individual reviews for all the places listed below.  I have a more comprehensive Tiered Bay Area boba list 104 boba spots and counting. 

I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank most of the Milk Tea/Boba Places in the area.

Rules: I ordered a simple milk tea with Boba (regular sweetness, ice etc.)

* Please note that I like my boba a little bit sweet. I don't like it too milky, too strong of a tea taste or too watery.  I prefer fresh tasting larger "boba".  Powdery drinks (those places that simply have a plastic carafe that they pour out of ) and boba that tastes "old" get docked on my rating scale.  A place could have a higher Yelp rating than it's boba score would imply , if it sells things other than Boba that are good.

author: Rod M.

description:
During the week, get there early because there is a line and if you intend on eating in, fills quickly and it's first come, first serve. 

The food is delish - I had a ramen both times, and they give you gluten-free noodles that are pretty accurate in taste (as accurate as gluten free can be). 

I've only been there twice, and even though I got my food promptly, my lunch companion's food did not. 

I love that they have different teas and you can add boba. You can also buy one of their mason jars and get a discount on more tea.
author: Eve E.

description:
I had Thursday special here *finally*
Their burger was unique. It had radish and make it a bit sour too. 
Their kettle chips had ichimi (spicy sparkles) on top of it. It was good.

For ramen wise, every one of them are good flavor and especially egg is properly cooked so it's has juicy yellow with I think soy source based flavor in it. Long word short, I love their egg. 

I gave them 3.5 star( but it appears 4 in Yelp) since this is a bit pricy for SF and ramen.  

Over all it's good
author: Ryutaro M.

description:
Ironically I don't like their ramen -- maybe 3 stars.

However, huge fan of their poke bowls -- salmon poke bowl is my favorite. Fish is high quality, it does come with a lot of rice though, which may not be a good choice for people looking for low carb. 

Outdoor area is also nice to eat at on a sunny day.
author: sharon s.

description:
I had a great meal here, despite not really liking the ramen all that much. The noodles were the smooth skinny kind, which are just not my favorite. Soup flavor was fine, nothing too outstanding. Ramen egg was good.
The best part of the meal was the gyoza! Perfect texture and juicy flavorful insides. Got an eel tempura shrimp roll and that was pretty good too. Sangria sake was tasty like juice. 
Two of us had lunch for $80, which isn't exactly cheap for ramen though!
author: Kris F.

description:
If you happen to be in the Financial DIstrict of San Francisco and are looking for a quick, good lunch, you can do much worse than the Ramen Bar. I stopped in here for lunch with a colleague on a cool weekday afternoon and found a long line of hungry office workers. To my surprise the line moved fast and we were able to find seating with no issue. Our food was served quickly and was hot and tasty.

Overall the Ramen is good here, but can't compare to many of the Ramen spots in NYC, nor, I suspect, to the more Ramen focused, less fast-foody spots in the Bay area. The broth was tasty, but not especially flavorful. The pork was cooked just right, but once again seemed to be missing something in the flavor department. The noodles were al dente enough and the veggies were fresh. I was happy with my dish for the price and service time, but it's not a spot I would go out of my way to go back, unless, of course, I was looking for a fast and quick lunch. If you are in a similar mindset, you should check it out.

One item I do like, aside from their 5 or so flavors of Ramen, they have a number of add-ons/options, which is not seen often. Go crazy and customize!
author: Nick M.

description:
I liked the variety of flavors they offer. I wasn't super impressed with the ginger chicken I ordered. I had to add salt and other spices to make it palatable. The flavor balance with the ginger and citrus was off. It didn't have that good ramen umami taste.

Fast ordering and fast food to table. Impressed that they make noodles and everything in house. Good service. Lots of space to sit.

Will try again.
author: Ryan B.

description: Great place for ramen but go before noon or the wait in line is long. Also ideal for 1-2 people because the place is small. The food is delicious, and it has been consistent since I've been about 5 times. Lots of broth options, all are tasty! My fave is pork belly + egg.
author: Julia M.

description:
The king of comfort foods on a crisp San Francisco evening is a piping hot bowl of ramen. That's why I had no hesitation when my colleague suggested The Ramen Bar. Between the food and memorable recollections of my friend straw-firing boba bubbles into my mouth, this was an experience well-worth repeating in a city replete with notable ramen houses. 

Everything on the menu looked appetizing with the exception of the sad, sickly colored tea selection next to the cashier. I opted for the Shoyu Tonkotsu, a classic of the ramen genre featuring melt-in-you-mouth slices of fatty pork belly, ginger, cabbage, soy-cured egg and a subtle yet spicy broth that had me draining my bowl. I washed it down with a classic bottled Coca Cola, although I wish I'd gone with a Boba Tea after tasting it. 

Get rid of the unappetizing gurgling liquids next to the register and maybe expand the menu a little and you have a repeat fan. Damien - I can still taste your pre-sucked boba bubbles in the back of my throat.
author: Alex L.

description: If you want upscale Raman, this is the place for you. Delish broth, meats, variations. Great on a chilly SF afternoon!
author: Teresa B.

description:
Got the Tokyo Shoyu... not worth the long line and slow service. You can find better lunch for $13.

Unremarkable broth -- too salty and not enough flavor. Really weird tough, flavorless chashu.

Noodles actually okay, but not good enough to save the rest of the bowl.
author: Arlan J.

description: It's overrated. I'm sorry, but The Ramen Bar doesn't live up to the hype. I really wanted to be blown away by this place bc I kept seeing it on the "Best Ramen" lists. After queueing up for 30 minutes and then waiting for my ramen to come for another 15, I was feeling super excited...but it just wasn't amazing. It was average at best. I just felt like the broth was missing something that'd give it the umami and depth to it--and we all know the broth is the most important component in ramen! The noodles were also a little too soft with very little texture. The chashu pork was nicely flavored, but a little bit on the tough side. The presentation was nice and appetizing though! Mind you, I grew up eating the best ramens in Japan, so my standards can be unreasonably high sometimes, but if I'm going to be spending the same $13 on ramen, I think Kirimachi Ramen's No. 1 Ramen is a better option.
author: Rie U.

description:
Hokkaido ramen played second fiddle to shooting boozy boba bubbles in to the mouth of a dining companion. Truth.

The $14 bowl of pork belly, miso fish stock, butter corn, eggs, seaweed, arugula and tight, thin noodles has so much going on visually, I dammed up the drool prior to the first bite. The final product, though, is middle of the road in flavor. Full disclosure: I'm a fan of big, bold flavors perhaps found in a saltier, fattier ramen. This one didn't have much depth, unlike my colleague's tonkotsu broth, which was baller.

Wakame salad ($4) comes in a hefty portion that could be sweeter, and the aforementioned $7 Boozy Boba is a refreshing bourbon laced honey tea with more ice than punch. Order at the counter, take a number and get table service from a friendly staffer.

Easy choice for a broth and beer lunch, or a casual dinner, but the culinary caliber of menu items varies, so sample with a group and remember what sings.
author: Damien S.

description:
Ordered the Shoyu Tonkotsu - $14 comes with shoyu tare, pork belly, ginger, cabbage, soy-cured egg. MEHH, this is more of an fancy express ramen place. You order at the front register and they give you a number and they will bring your order to your table. I tried asking if I can choose the firmness of my noodles but unfortunately couldn't. lol worth a try to ask. 

Broth was flavorful and oily. I didn't care for the cabbage and red ginger tho (it was almost like a filler for me). Pork belly was dry and no fat! Noodles were decently firm and wasn't too overcooked. It's a thicker noodle which I like but I've had way better. 

I wouldn't be coming back here as this is expensive and not as good as other places I enjoy for about the same price.
author: Sherry Y.

description: Came here for dinner one night and ordered the tonkatsu ramen. It came with a good amount of ingredients and variety, but I didn't think that the noodles or broth were very good. The noodles were a bit too thin and not chewy the way ramen should be and the broth was kind of bland. Beyond that, the main reason why this is a 1 star review is that they charged more tip than I had written on my receipt. You order at the front register and pay at the front register, but they didn't give me a copy of my receipt but I do remember the exact amount of what I wrote as my total and my credit card statement says they charged me $2 more than what I wrote in as my total. If you come here, ask them for a receipt!!!
author: Jacqueline H.

description:
I was so excited to see that we were getting ramen catered to our office today! I wondered... how are they gonna pull this off? Soup came in beverage-like dispensers, noodles were sectioned off for serving sizes, and toppings were on the side so you could completely customize your bowl. It was very cool to see!

Unfortunately the food was only subpar for me. I liked the miso broth, it was very light yet flavorful. My favorite toppings were the spicy fried garlic and the perfectly soft boiled soy-cured egg! However, I was expecting perfectly cooked chasu, but it fell short.. for a Michael Mina establishment, I expected better! The meat was chewy and the pieces were not uniformly cut.. ranged from super large pieces to small pieces. I did enjoy the chewiness of the noodles, but I hope their fresh pork at the actual restaurant is cooked a little better. Meat is an important component in ramen! Overall I probably would not return to the actual Ramen Bar.
author: Tara A.

description: Love the ramen here! The broth is super flavorful and the noodles are super smooth. The line does get long here during rush hour, but you can actually order pick up to go online! The prices are pretty expensive ($14 a bowl) but I guess it's because it's located in the Financial District.
author: Victoria T.

description:
Ramen is my comfort food.
In Chinese, I affectionately refer to this as my childhood cooking education of boiling water, unwrapping that bright orange package, boiling the enclosed noodles, and tearing then pouring from a foil package some brownish powder. 
Fast forward forty plus years, ramen is probably the hottest trend for the past three years running.
Well, when a celebrity chef (Michael Mina) and a local popular Japanese chef (Ken Tominaga) partner up at the 101 California building, you get two Japanese restaurants of different genres, Pabu and Ramen Bar.  My friend brought me to Pabu when they first opened to enjoy their omakase menu.  So when another friend suggested buying lunch to take back to my office, how could I resist?!
Arriving about when they opened on a weekday morning, I studied the menu and read a specials board before ordering the Hokkaido pork ramen (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=cTHAWR_VBENq5RqYnqTpsA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) and the special, their gyoza (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=sFY7ZWJf-2f9MEQHooWZQg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), that day.  About an hour later, I reconstructed my soup and noodle/ingredients boxes into this (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=3wCl3uBL4iulexx0RYGHAw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  Not as pretty as it tasted, but the flavors were on point and the portions were okay.  I ate about half of the gyoza, saving the rest to accompany my dinner at home.
The cashier was helpful and efficient in taking and packing my order. 
Given the price point these days and the added competition, I'd categorize this as moderate for its quality ingredients.  
I probably would have enjoyed this more dining in as I'm sure the presentation is probably a lot better there.  As I left, the local working crowd was slowly flowing into the restaurant.  
Will be back to give this another try.
Wonder when I'll get over this ramen craving... maybe never?!
author: Mike C.

description: Location is conveniently located across the street from the ferry building, bus, and Bart stops. I ordered the shout tonkotsu and added pork belly, and extra $3. I was quite hungry before coming, and the ramen hit the spot! The broth was good and the meat was tender. I don't know if the food is worth the price, hence 4 stars. Atmosphere was great! They also serve beer and poke.
author: Serena W.

description:
I enjoyed my experience at Ramen Bar - though my rating is more 3.5 than 4 stars.

Even though it's a little overpriced, the people who work there are really, really eager to help and I appreciate the different style of ramen here.

I decided to get the Ginger Chicken ramen - to try something other than Tonkotsu Ramen for once - with a side of Ramen Bar deviled eggs and Matcha milk tea.

The Ginger Chicken ramen was on the lighter side - a broth that's fragrant, but not too powerful. I made the mistake of getting deviled eggs, forgetting that I already got a nice soy-lathered egg in my ramen. Fortunately, the two eggs were pretty different that I didn't mind at all. 

The deviled egg was creamier with some crunch from ramen noodles. I don't think I'd call it a must when you come here, but it was definitely interesting to try. The Matcha milk wasn't anything extraordinary either.

Nevertheless, the food was fairly good overall. A decent bowl of ramen is pretty difficult to come by in the City, so I give extra points to Ramen Bar for doing it better than the others in the area. Plus, it's suuuuper close to the Embarcadero station.
author: Sara C.

description:
Despite long lines, I was surprised at how fast everything moved + came out. Decent for business lunch - though hard to find a seat sometimes:

What I've tried:
- Ginger chicken ramen (~$14): good portions, flavorful broth though could be served a bit more hot.
- Kale chicken caesar ($13.95): super tasty with the bonito shreds for flavor, the quinoa for a crispy crunch and the thinly sliced kale for the extra healthy mental plus 
- Chicken avocado bowl (~$13): ALSO great, and served with a ton of brown rice. good scoop of avocado and enjoyed the mushrooms
- Sunomono: acutally a bit more vinegar heavy than other places and IMO not marinated long enough so they're super soft, sweet and crunchy

The killer combo is mixing the kale chicken caesar with the chicken avocado bowl. It's a money combo. They've also got pearl milk teas if that's your thing, and online ordering.

TLDR: healthy options including grilled chicken breast, salmon, brown rice. Excellent shaded outdoor seating.
author: Kristie C.

description: The Ramen Bar is catchy and I should've stuck with the namesake. Here, I haven't tried the ramen, which was a brain fart on my own doing, but the poke simply isn't worth it. The trio poke bowl had more rice and salad than fish! Oh, I'm sure it's organic this and non GMO that but please have some more actual fish in the poke bowl. I mean, it's advertised as a trio and I got it because I wanted the full experience but was severely disappointed.  In terms of taste, my meal was bland because the spicy mayo wasn't spicy.  The best part was probably the avocado which I quickly devoured.  I expected much more from a collaboration between such renowned chefs but it wasn't meant to be.
author: Quoc N.

description:
So I came here for lunch today and I was slightly disappointed that all the staff picks weren't ramen, which made me a bit skeptical.  However I made my way to the counter and ordered a bowl of  Tokyo style ramen.

First off I want to start by saying it wasn't bad at all, however even though it wasn't bad at all it also wasn't great.  The egg itself wasn't runny enough and a little too cooked on the outside of the yolk which started getting that hard boil color,  the noodles were somewhat bouncy and chewy but not bouncy and chewy enough, the pork belly was cut very thick however in the meat's defense I do have to say that it was tasty and not chewy, the broth itself wasn't bad.

All in all this place is pretty good however I definitely had better ramen.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
The Ramen Bar is wonderfully... Average.

Given its Michael Mina pedigree, you would assume that this would be great. It was great, but just not exactly something to write home about.

The Ramen Bar is your classy and modern yet hipster-y in vibe ramen shop jam packed in one of the busier districts of San Francisco. You'll see a line out the door filled with men in suits, iPhones out everywhere, and prices through the roof: exactly what you'd expect in any poppin' SF lunch joint.

With the Michael Mina name, it had high expectations to live up to. I ordered the Hokkaido Ramen and an Earl Grey milk tea, and my only conclusion is that it's really painfully average. No wow factor, besides the fact that it's a decently average bowl of ramen you can grab for slightly above average price in SF.

Not to say I won't be back, but it's a bit pricy for what it is, and it's not exactly the best ramen I've ever had. I'm not going to try to compare it to Japan, but even within the Bay Area, you can get better elsewhere in the bay for a much more affordable price.

If you're looking for something with a bit more pizazz, I'd recommend heading over to Ramen Shop in Oakland.

I will however note that it's non-ramen options look fantastic, and I've got to give those a chance.

TIP: Skip the milk tea. It's nothing special.
author: Brian L.

description: Fast. Delicious. And really solid ramen for $15. Is it the best ramen you'll ever have in your life? No. Is it perfect for lunch and really good? Yes!
author: Abigail S.

description: Not bad, not the best tasting though. Has a weird taste to it. They are trying to do something inventive with ramen but mine was just kind of gross, tasted like seaweed.
author: Grant R.

description: I love the salmon poke bowl with just greens. I also love their ramen. It's pricey but what isn't in San Francisco.
author: Ola P.

description:
Lots of varieties here - ramen, burgers, salads, etc 
I had the shoyu ramen. The soy sauce based soup was rich and silky. The problem is the noodles here aren't authentic enough. They are hard and tastes like they were taken out of boxes. Also the pickled ginger came in the soup, which was kind of odd
author: Alex L.

description: So gross...what did I just eat?  Broth was luke warm and tastes like water.  Noodles were way over cooked and mushy.  Only saving grace was the egg, which was the only thing that had flavor.  So gross...Never again.
author: Vi Y.

description:
I gave Ramen Bar another chance because I'm a believer for second chances. 

One Mushroom & Soy Ramen please. 

I learned my lesson from the first time to avoid the ginger ramen one and so this time I should be good. For 5:45pm, it wasn't busy. For FIDI, of course it wasn't. My ramen came out about 10 minutes or so. 

I wasn't enthusiastic for their presentation. Peep at my picture for reference. I didn't admire how bulky the mizuna made my bowl look. Mizuna are the greens you see in the picture. I love veggies, but was not a fan of how much space it took. Now on to their broth. AGAIN, it was on the sweeter side. I'm more used to that fatty and umami flavor that I was taken by surprise how sweet it was. Of course, this was soy based so it was expected. However, it should NOT be an excuse for their Shoyu Tonkotsu to be like that, too!!! Lastly, I was disappointed with their noodles. It was overcooked and so it felt like eating somewhat soggy and limp noodles. The great thing was that there were more noodles than anything else. 

There's so many dislikes of this bowl that I was left dissatisfied. On to the more happier side of things. I LOVED the mushrooms to this bowl. There were two kinds, one left as is and the other fried. That fried stuff hit the spot. Great texture and enough flavor which made it easily the star of the bowl. 

Upon finishing my meal, I have decided that Ramen Bar is not worth my visit. Like other reviewers, there are tons of better ramen but Ramen Bar is smart in attracting business during lunch hours. And extra smarts for being open in the evening. Although the ramen was sad to eat, the friendly service from the staff made it better. 

Final words from Fifi: It's worth a visit ... just to say you've been. But that's about it. Try all that you want the first time so you don't have to come back again.
author: Fiona L.

description:
I would only recommend this place if you are cold and hungry... which so happened to be my case today. There are not many noodle places in FIDI and my coworkers decided to give this place one more try. I decided to go with the Shoyu Tonkotsu Ramen  (to-go order) which came with pork belly, cabbage, and a sake soft boiled egg. Overall, it was good ramen as the noodles were chewy and the pork belly was tender. However, the soup was quite fatty and I didn't think it lived up to its hype. Tasted quite average for such a fancy and hip establishment in FIDI. 

-Minus one star for the long wait for the food (~10 mins). I did not hear my name being called, but I heard my other coworkers' name. I would advise you to stand close to the counter or your soup will get cold! :(

-Minus another one star for the cost. Yes, slap Michael Mina's name on a restaurant and you can charge $16 for a bowl of ramen. I wished you gave me $16 worth of ramen, but sadly you did not. 

I gave you two too many chances. Will not be returning.
author: Eva L.

description: The wait to get into this place during lunch hours was almost a little too much! I came around 12pm which is my bad, but it took about 25 minutes to even get to the front of the line. The staff was friendly though. I ordered a milk tea with boba and then ordered the Tokyo Ramen bowl with extra noodles. The broth was very good, but I guess I'm not huge on seaweed because it kinda threw everything off for me a bit. The ramen was good overall, but I was extremely disappointed in its lack of meat. It had some, but it was so little I barely even remember eating it. I would come back again and give it another go.
author: James R.

description: It is pricy, but you know there are not a lot ramen places around this area, got extra noodles and extra meat and it looks like normal size in other places, I mean the place not in downtown SF.
author: Kelvin Y.

description:
Full disclosure: I am a huge fan of grocery store Top Ramen. For those of you who are on your quest for authentic and flavorful ramen and two hour waits, you have my permission to disregard my favorable review for The Ramen Bar. For my folks downtown SF trying to find a modern and cozy joint for Happy Hour and you're craving ramen, this will hit the spot.

The location of The Ramen Bar was so convenient to walk to from my office. My friend and I arrived at 5:15pm on a Friday, and there were only a few other customers there. I ordered the shoyu tonkatsu, which is your generic bowl of yellow noodles, pork shoulder, a piece of seaweed, some bamboo, and the most delicious soy-cured egg. You can add on other toppings for a charge, as well- I'll probably add on extra eggs next time. For $14, the bowl of ramen felt overpriced compared to places I've eaten at in Japantown which is why I rated 3 instead of 4 stars. This place also serves boba and cocktails- I sucked down my delicious chai milk tea (can't ever get enough of those tapioca pearls!).

The ambiance here is pretty cozy and lively compared to other ramen bars. It was pretty warm inside so my Minnesota blood opted to sit outside. The server brought us free appetizers that are part of their happy hour menus. The steamed pork gyoza (normally $3 on their HH menu) tasted like the frozen potstickers from Trader Joe's, which I enjoy - this might not come as a surprise since I already admitted I like instant ramen noodles.

Overall, The Ramen Bar is a convenient and satisfying experience when you want to grab a bowl of ramen and cocktails with friends after work. Great staff and service and a welcomed change of scenery and food type compared to the other nearby joints, so I'll be back.
author: Tanya B.

description:
I had been looking forward to my ramen date all week and I was very happy with my experience. The menu is pretty basic and not overwhelming which I appreciate. It's a very cool vibe that somehow mixes casual with intimate with bench and shared table seating in a restaurant with dim lighting and a visible kitchen. 
Now to the ramen, it was delicious! The egg was probably the best part and I wish I had ordered extra because I am still dreaming about it. I ordered the Ginger Chicken ramen with extra noodles, which I probably did not need since I wasn't able to finish. The broth was warm and soothing and left me filled without feeling gross and overly stuffed. Would definitely recommend this restaurant to any ramen fan!
author: Meghan P.

description:
A lovely addition to the Financial District with lots of room for parties of all sizes. I appreciate the fact that they're trying to use good ingredients in their ramen bowls, and that the noodles in particular are quite good, but the overall equation just doesn't really sing for me in the way I've come to expect of authentic Japanese outlets. Same goes for their rolls - there's nothing wrong with them, but they don't sing, either. 

Nevertheless, the servers are friendly and super efficient, and again this isn't a bad spot for a FiDi meal.
author: Vincent L.

description: I just ordered delivery and my ramen didn't have a single piece of chachu...seriously?
author: Jonathan T.

description:
The place is very homey, and great for friend gathering. Really happy to eat with some of my favorite people at this place.

I had the tuna poke bowl, you can choose either brown or white rice. i'd say the taste is normal but nothing special, given its a bit high price. But it's worth paying a little more to stay for the place's atmosphere. Maybe ramen next time :)
author: Xuaner Z.

description:
Nice open space and pretty simple menu with option to build your own ramen. 

Decent ramen, but if you are looking for traditional Japanese ramen, this is not the place. Popular ramen is the Tokyo, but Hokkaido is pretty good with a spicy kick. The eggs are cooked pretty nicely with the liquidy yolk. Tsukemen already has the dipping sauce mixed in so it is pretty goopy and not that good. Dipping sauce is for dipping... I couldn't eat more than several bites of it. A friend ordered their udon and he said it wasn't that good either. Stick with the ramen.
author: Iris H.

description:
Decent ramen and conforms to what you expect ramen to be. I enjoyed the Hokkaido broth a lot--nice and clean taste. The noodle was good but I didn't feel compelled to finish all of it.

There was a bit of a line for weekday lunch--not a surprise. But the line moves fast enough so it doesn't hurt to be patient.
author: Yad L.

description:
I'm a huge tonkotsu ramen fan so I must order that broth whenever I see it on a ramen menu.  My ideal broth (as experienced at a ton of places in Tokyo and at Ippudo in NYC) is full of pork bone goodness so it looks cloudy and tastes like a fat bomb with each bite.  Sadly, their tonkotsu just didn't live up.  My meal was decent though, hence the "A-OK" 3-star rating.  The rest of their menu looked enticing.  So I might have had a 4-star experience if my tonkotsu expectations hadn't been dashed.

Deviled Ramen Egg: A tad too much mayo for me and I'm someone who likes his mayo.  Good spices though.  Nice crunch factor from the fried ramen noodles.

Shoyu Tonkotsu Ramen: The broth is more salty than fatty/meaty.  I really wouldn't place it as tonkotsu at all since it's rather light.  The pork belly is really good though with melt away fat and tender marinated meat.  Noodles are firm and chewy.  The soft boiled egg is really good since it has a nice creamy center.
author: Adam B.

description:
line goes through quickly, food comes out fast, so if you're feeling like ramen for lunch, then go for it. 

Except - 
the soup is really salty, not enough broth in the ramen. we still finished our bowls of ramen because my friend and i are faithful carb loving ramen loving human beings who always finish our food.... but i had to drink like 5 cups of water when i got back to my office. 

I don't think I'd come back for ramen but I'll come back to try other foods!
author: Jimin O.

description:
Loved the mushroom tofu ramen! Finally a good veggie ramen option where the broth isn't lacking color & flavor or is meat based! 

A variety of veggies- (corn, a couple different type of mushrooms, bamboo shoots, seaweed, greens, and green onion) topped a good portion of noodles. Wish it came out a little hotter in terms of temperature though!

Super busy during the lunch hour- took over an hour from waiting in line to waiting for our order ( 2 ramen)  to arrive. Not a good place for a quick lunch during the week (1130-2pm) since it's located in the financial district.
author: Ruby S.

description:
I came here one night with some of my girlfriends before we headed to a concert. Heard this was one of Michael Mina's restaurants, so we decided to give it a try and it was on the way to the show.

I ordered the Tokyo Style Ramen and we shared the crab wontons. Honestly, not worth coming here. It didn't taste authentic at all, I rather eat a kimchee cup noodle or something, but then again I am very particular with my noodles :).

The staff was great, very nice. One of them tried to get at my friend and asked for her number when we were leaving. Sorry bro, maybe next time when she is single :)
author: Natalie L.

description: Took 45 min for my to go ramen. Had to ask 3 times where my order was. Food was cold and salty. Do not come here
author: Shivani V.

description: I'm surprised by how many low ratings this place has. It's a more upscale ramen place or sit down lunch place but their usually pretty quick. It's always packed and yes it's a bit mainstream (nothing crazy, overly creative or authentic) but everything I've had here has still been really good. My favorite is the hokkaido ramen w/ pork. I also had the thai iced tea with boba which was also super yummy! It's a bit over priced for ramen but so is everything in FiDi and its way nicer than anything towards or on the edge of Chinatown.
author: Gabriella M.

description:
$32 for avocado chicken bowl and shoyu tonkotsu ramen w/extra pork belly.  Better than the last time I was here, but this places is still expensive.  Pork was a little salty for my taste.

Still one of the better ramen restaurants  in the area.
author: Angelica C.

description:
An upscale interpretation of simple Japanese comfort food. This is somewhat of a quick service sit-down restaurant, where your order your food and drink at the counter and then they bring it to you. There's a few tables inside, some counter and cafeteria style seating inside, and an adjacent fancier restaurant.

I ordered a Tokyo Tonkotsu bowl ($14) and a milk chocolate Namelaka from the restaurant next door ($10). The ramen broth was decently flavored, the noodles had a nice consistency, and the meat was pretty good. Otherwise I didn't think it was amazing quality ramen- no umami and the flavor could've been stronger. The egg was the highlight - so savory and soft, one of the best ramen eggs I've ever eaten. The namelaka was pretty disappointing, with a not super pleasing appearance, only a small amount of custard, and a small portion of pudding in general. I did like the crunch and texture, it was just very overpriced. 

Overall, there's a few varieties of ramen that make for a quick meal if you're close to Embarcadero.
author: Steven V.

description:
I'm not a ramen aficionado, but I know a good bowl of noodles when I eat one. I got the mushroom and it was fabulous. Rich, flavorful broth. Good assortment of veggies. Excellent broth to noodle ratio.

Plus, they do takeout right. And online ordering is a snap.
author: Kim C.

description:
After numerous lunches at this place since my last review, I thought I should give an updated review about this place! I believe it's safe to say that this place is still a pretty solid 3 stars restaurant, which also probably means there are no improvements from 2014. 

Their ramen here is still mediocre. The broth is way too salty and not rich in meat/bones flavor. I have tried their Tokyo Style ramen (shoyu) to change it up from my usual Hokkaido (spicy miso), and the broth was literally almost like soy sauce mixed with water and sugar. It almost surprising that you would think that from all these people complaining about how it's too salty that they would get their salt measurements right by now, but nope! Their ramen broth here is still way too salty every. single. time! 

Anyways, on a brighter note, I HAVE FIGURED THIS PLACE OUT. I have recently tried out their rice bowls here to escape from their overly salted ramen and they were actually quite delicious! My sesame salmon rice bowl was beautifully presented with some salad greens layered on top and the salmon was flavored nicely. It was fortunately salted perfectly when blended with rice, so I was happy! My coworkers also enjoyed the beef shogayaki and chicken avocado rice bowls as well! I will be going back just for the rice bowls and staying far far away from their ramen!! 

TL; DR: DO get the rice bowls! DON'T get their ramen. 

Cheers!
author: Hoyan L.

description: Ramen was not tasty; Soup was too greasy.  Happy hour okonomiyaki tots were not fresh and kinda cold.  Kirin draft beer was nice.  I do not think I will go back to this place.
author: EunJoo C.

description:
Lots of hot things here. Ramen. Boba. Wagyu beef burger. They're hitting a lot of hot items, and it's a good place to be introduced to those things. 

It's counter service, so you order, pay, and then they shuttle it out to you. It's pretty quick and everything on the menu has enough personality and character that you can snap your pics and post to the appropriate places so your pals know you're getting yours.

As for the food itself, it's fine by me. Expect nothing fancy and get nothing fancy in return. Big bowls of ramen, a simple burger; there's really nothing to complain about here. Grab a few items from off the menu and go for it, super quick style. If you're looking for creative or boundary-pressing stuff, there are other spots in this city. But there's nothing objectionable about bellying up to the Ramen Bar.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
This was good. I got the mushroom & soy ramen (i think thats what its called?) and it was definitely satisfying, and a large portion. It wasn't overly salty (just right - but also: i like pretty rich & flavored broth, so if you like yours bland... this may be salty for you), and the mushrooms were really good. The noodles were just right - fresh and just chewy enough. 

I also got the Lychee Oolong tea & mason jar. FINALLY someone offers fresh, awesome, affordable boba in the area. its $4.50 for a large + boba, and a couple extra bucks gets you a pretty nifty mason jar, which they'll refill for $3. 

Is it pricey? yes. but everything is in the Financial District. I'll def be coming back.
author: Alana V.

description: Really like this place and the decor felt like a fancy restaurant with fancy high prices.  Where can you get the 3 most popular and trending food items in one place?? This is it!! Ginger chicken ramen $12 was good but pricey for just 4 thin slices of meat, poke trio $15 was excellent, flavorful and filling, the tea with the ice, felt watered down but I luved the Mason jar and to be honest, I got this purely for the Mason jar,  who doesn't? However it cost $3 extra.  Will go back to try other dishes.
author: Elaine Y.

description: So here is the deal. Your food is decent nothing to write home about. I received a lot of attitude from one of your employees after I waited for a to go order. I walked outside for a minute to wait, poked back in to see if my order was ready, seemingly not. Nbd. Walked back in a few minutes later and looked around, they could see I was waiting for a to-go order but missing something. I got their attention and we figured out my order was sitting aside. Nbd. I apologized and said sorry i was just outside, I guess my order was sitting there for a bit. Guy replies "YEAH! Well WE CALLED YOUR NAME AND YOU WEREN'T HERE!" I told him He'd be better suited dropping his attitude and I'll never come back again. Neither will my friends, or family or coworkers of confidantes. It just takes one shithead employee to ruin everything. Bye!
author: Penguin P.

description: Probably the worst "ramen" I've ever had, and I've had quite a bit of ramen. The gyoza were equally disappointing. After waiting more than a few minutes for a table (when they were not at all busy), we waited just as long for service, and didn't enjoy a bite of our food. More than 40 dollars later for 2 people, I can firmly advise you not to bother with the Ramen Bar.
author: Alexandra S.

description:
I pass by this place every day, walking to BART. I thought the logo looked really cool and wanted to check it out one day with a friend.

The ambiance of the place is pretty mellow and the size of this place isn't that big - it's more for smaller groups of people. The have a decent variety on their menu and I ordered the Hokkaido Ramen with Chashu, it was alright... Kind of on the salty side and I feel like the noodles were a bit too soggy for my liking... I also would think that the spicy powder they had would help, but it didn't make that much of a difference in helping the taste... I also noticed that they serve beer depending on the pint verses a pitcher and unless I did the math totally wrong, but it's not worth it getting a pitcher, LOL. So weird??.... But anyway, I ordered a beer here and I was really bummed to see it... It wasn't even a 16OZ or whatever they said it was. It was in this hourglass lookin' glass... I refuse to believe it was a pint - I'm pretty sure I was getting jipped!

In the end, this was probably the most expensive ramen experience of my life and I wasn't satisfied when I left.. I was actually still kind of hungry which is VERY weird. 

I give it 3 stars because the service was really good. I can't remember the name of our waiter, but she was really good at checking up on my friend and I as well as coming over when we had requests.

I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, it'll probably be impossible to find street parking so garage is the only way to go and that's like $18+... So might as well BART if you come here and only come here if you're too lazy to walk elsewhere.
author: Nicole C.

description: I can only speak to the happy hour.  $1 for 7oz Miller High Life pony!  Plus free popcorn.  The do have a few appetizers that are in the $3 range as well. But we just come to stack up the ponies.
author: Mark K.

description:
My first ever visit here was because of Restaurant Week!  I saw what they were serving for the $40 dinner special and it sounded splendid!

So I arrived here on the first day of Restaurant Week around 6:45pm to get a table for my friend and I.  I was here earlier than scheduled in case there was a long wait. Nope! I was immediately seated by a friendly staff!

During my long wait for my friend to arrive (who was also running late) I decided to take a closer look at the Restaurant Week Menu (which listed 5 items!) and decided to play match up with the prices that was on the regular menu...and heres what they were:

Beverage: Kirin Draft - $4
Appetizer: Pork Gyoza - $8
Ramen: Spicy Yasai Miso Pork - $14
Dessert: Green Tea Mousse - $6 
Take Away: Pate De Fruit - $2

Now the ramen and dessert were not on the menu and I assume it's a specialty so I just took the prices from that category.  Now all that adds up to $34...but wait the restaurant week special is $40!  That's not a deal! Unless the ramen was super duper special!  Anywho, I felt I didn't need all that and pay $40 +tax and tip.  So plans have been changed and I haut went with the regular menu, and they are:

WAKAME SALAD - $4
A tiny portion of seaweed salad thT is placed lovely on a dish with a nice lemon slice garnish.  It's really your typical standard salad that I found quite tasty...nothing to complain about! I don't recommend sharing unless you order another appetizer and have your own main entree :P

CRAB WONTON - $7
This appetizer comes with 3 tony fried wonton that is filled with little carb meat, some corn that gave it a sweet fun texture, and just a bit aioli that I barely tasted.  I guess I was hoping for more of a creamy filling...but the wonton part was crispy and not greasy.  It's pricy for what you get and I don't recommend it at all.  It tasted okay.

RAMEN - CHASU MISO-BUTTER HOKKAIDO - $14
braised pork, garlic, sweet corn, soy-cured egg (richer, bolder flavor).
I as happy to see that this bowl had 2 halves of the cured egg...which I thought was perfect! There was plenty of chopped green onions, but I barely saw any corn...which was fine to me.  The chasu pork was ok--it had a black pepper flavor (you can see it rubbed into to the meat) which gave it more of a western flavor in my opinion.  You get one big thick slice.  The north is thick and creamy and the overall bowl was not bad.  It was old but not the best to me because for the price of $14 with the name Michael Minna slapped on it, I guess I set myself up for higher expectations.  I didn't finish it, but had the rest to go, which came in this really cute container with a seal on it.

GREEN TEA PARFAIT - $6
Huckleberry sake jam, white chocolate green tea mousse, green tea cookie.
I enjoyed this! My only minor complaint was that the huckleberry jam was too sweet...but if you get the right amount of that with a spoonful of the green tea mouse and a piece of the cookie, it's perfect!  I never had anything like this and I am really glad dessert was ordered!

The service here is over the top great.  The staff checked on us many times, in addition to the 45 minute span I had to wait for my friend to arrive.  My only complain is that parking isn't great (not that I expect it considering its location), but you can easily bart and walk to. The restaurant is cold and it's probably because the door is always left open.  I had to ask them to close it but it ends up being open again.  Would I come back? Probably not.  I came to give it a try and I am pleased I did.
author: Tu-Anh N.

description:
I "heard" of this place through the latest Bon Appetit Magazine. It was noted as one of the best ramen places to eat in the country. 

Eat sure lived up to it's name!
