My friend and I dined here last night. We got the cod fritters to share, he got the shoyu ramen and I got the veggie ramen. The cod fritters were good, could have been a little less fried, and could have been more of them for the price ($15 for 4 small pieces). 

The veggie ramen was insanely delicious, many great veggies in the dish; but they don't come with typical ramen noodles, more buckwheat type, so I will request that next time I go, fyi. My friend loved his, it made him smile. He said it was an end to a perfect day:) 

On top of it, the place is insanely charming, rust modern, cool. They had long wooden benches so you can bring a group of friend, as well as single table to just stop by for a ramen fix at the bar. Complete perfect.

Will I be back, um yes? Should you go and ignore the not so shinny reviews, to give it a good college try? Yes, and YES!
author: Sonia A.

description: First, I rarely write a review but felt compelled after my first lunch visit. One word. Disappointing. The tuna poke rice bowl is not worth the price. Lots of rice, too little fish.  Great atmosphere inside and outside. I'd try a happy hour but that's about it.
author: Anita S.

description:
I actually battled with myself over whether or not to write this update, but given my past two experiences, I think it's time I revised my review, and not for the better.

Finding bugs in your food is never a good thing. I've had bugs in my ramen twice now. Once is bad enough, though excusable as a simple mistake, twice is just irritating.

The first time this happened to me, I ate inside the restaurant; my ramen was brought to me, everything was fine and dandy while eating, until I went for another bite of noodles and found a dead fly (small, not housefly size, but a fly nonetheless) on top of the greens. I immediately put my chopsticks down, flagged down my waitress, and really quietly told her that there was a dead fly in my soup. She looked extremely embarrassed and took my bowl away, then went over to the chefs and looked very unhappy while pointing out what was in my bowl.

I felt bad for a fraction of a moment because I didn't want to embarrass them all, but finding dead flies in your bowl really isn't cool. They comped my entire meal as an apology for what happened while also getting me another bowl of ramen to-go, so I didn't write about what happened because of how apologetic they were and how they rectified the situation (though I didn't feel like they had to comp my entire meal, I was very grateful that they did). This incident was about three months ago.

Today, I got a bowl of ramen to-go, opened it up, and before I even got to pour my broth there was a live bug this time, crawling along my greens.

The explanation I got for what happened the first time was that The Ramen Bar wants to keep things organic, so I guess part of being organic is finding something dead in your food (or in today's case, still alive) that would normally have been eradicated through pesticides. But honestly, don't they wash their greens? I can't find any reason why rinsing greens off with water would be offensive to hardcore organic-lovers (I dunno though, correct me if I'm wrong), so why I'm finding bugs in my food (not to mention dirt, the last time I got take-out) I don't know.

I couldn't care less about organic - there, I said it, sorry I'm not sorry - so I'm really not buying the whole, "We try and be organic so you may or may not find something crawling around or dead in your food" excuse passable at this point.

Kirimachi is right down the street - haven't found anything weird in my bowl there yet!
author: Angela M.

description: Delicious ramen and great service! I've been twice so far and look forward to going again soon.
author: Astrohfiziks A.

description:
One of the things that seems to be overwhelming in this city is  the various ramen joints to try. It seems a new joint pops up all the time with even better ramen than the last. One of my coworkers once told me about this place a few blocks away from work. It served some pretty awesome ramen, so one day we decided to try this place out for lunch. Since then, I've been back two other times. 

When you walk in, you'll notice a really modern space for ramen. Concrete floors, exposed air ducts and dark wooden tables really help create this vibe. If the inside fills up, no worries. There's an outside seating area for your party. For lunch, you walk up to the hostess stand, order, take your seat and they bring  you your food when it's ready. During dinner times, you're sat down and waited on. During my multiple visits, I was fortunate enough to try a couple of dishes. Here's what I had: 

-Tokyo Style ramen for $12.00. Kurobuta pork, wakame, soy-cured egg, spinach and broth. The broth was lighter side and was more of your traditional broth. The soy cured egg was by far the best part of the dish! PERFECTLY cooked and flavored.The pork was nicely marbleized and packed with flavor. I thought they added a little too much spinach as it seemed to take over the entire bowl. Other than that, this was on point!

-Chasu Miso-Butter Hokkaido for $14.00. Braised pork, garlic, sweet corn, coy-cured egg. WOW, this was definitely richer than your average ramen. The broth was super buttery and had a lot of the miso flavor. It's great, a lot seemed to turn me off. I did like the crunchy sweet corn and the pork was marbleized nicely. Once again, I thought the star of the dish was the soy-cured egg. I could have that by itself and call it an evening. 

Talk about a ramen joint with lots of complex flavors. You've definitely gotta try this place out for yourself. Try the soy-cured egg and be prepared to be blown away. If you're in the area, get your butt down there!
author: Rockne H.

description:
It's been a cold and rainy San Francisco winter and I needed something warm, flavorful and soft. I was therefore super excited about the prospect of a big brothy bowl of ginger chicken ramen.  As soon as I received my food, the disappointment set in. The food was warm, not hot.  The broth lacked any depth and flavor.  The noodles were chewy  (that's a good thing) but tasted like flour  (that's not a good thing). The two stars are for the absolutely delicious egg. I could have eaten five of them. 

I know San Francisco is expensive and I don't mind paying more when I eat here, however I do expect the food to be good. This was a definite miss and I will not be coming back.
author: Shoole S.

description:
Stopped by fri night for ramen! Convenient location right off of market. Really cool ambiance. There's a decently large indoor dining area but really nice outdoor seating shielded from the wind where you can overlook the square. 

When we arrived it was pretty quiet. A few tables were finishing up a fri HH. I ordered the shoyu tonkatsu and a glass of white wine. Not cheap but also not pricey given the area. Wine was decent but could've been served in a nicer glass!! Food came out quickly and was hot and good!!! The broth was very well flavored (so much so I was worried there might have been msg) and the pork belly was tender and just the right amount of fat. Wish they would spice up the dishes to order. 

Overall great meal. Nice ambiance good food. Please serve wines in some nicer glasses and offer better selection of spices. My tummy felt good afterwards and I wasn't too dehydrated so yay there wasn't any msg used.
author: Yin H.

description:
People be harsh with the ramen reviews! Not me. I'm just gonna be honest and say this is some fancy ramen, with a lighter style broth. Perhaps not the same recipe anyone's grandma made, but this is SF in 2014... chefs wanna be creative. The chefs here assemble each bowl to order, with a rainbow of fresh ingredients which you can see through a glass window separating diners from kitchen. Otherwise, I would have jumped in that vat of enoki mushrooms. 

My first visit, I had ramen, of course. It was delicious, flavorful, filling, fresh, all that good stuff (sorry, I'm no ramen snob). On my second visit, I had the most amazing salmon salad I've had in my life:

"SLOW-ROASTED SALMON
soy, sake, radish, carrots, asparagus, cucumbers
with a base of
Local farmed greens, fall vegetables, kaiware, and
yuzu vinaigrette"

If you're a salmon fan, this salad will be a revelation. How interesting could salmon be? You won't know until you try this dish. For $12, it's an amazing deal, packed with exquisitely flavored salmon and other healthy stuff. I didn't for a second regret my salad vs. ramen choice. 

Desserts were odd, the coffee jelly being the exception (literally, like coffee flavored pudding with little jelly toppings).

What's cool about Ramen Bar is it's in a fancy area, with fancy clientele, but the atmosphere is super casual and the ordering system very low-key (order at the counter, check out their pre-made desserts, grab a seat, wait for your food).  

That said, it's not cheap. But, if you're looking for a decently priced work spot to take colleagues or clients, Ramen Bar hits a nice balance between upscale/hip and approachable. 

If nothing else, I'll be back for that incredible salmon!
author: Nique F.

description:
If someone places an order at 10:31AM with the intentions to pick it up at noon, the order should be ready.  I understand you are behind in fulfillment but I placed my order hours prior.  I cannot believe I still have to stand and wait another 25 minutes to pick-up my already paid order.

Get it together.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
As a person who eats ramen every.single.day., I consider myself a bit of an expert. 

Just kidding... sort of. I totally didn't even know ramen existed outside of microwavable packages until like 3 years ago... but I've been spooning my way through my 20s and 30s on a diet almost exclusively of the stuff, so I've definitely learned a thing or two along the way.

This ramen isn't like any other ramen I've had before, but that's not a terrible thing - just not what I'd expected. 

The average bowl will run you anywhere from $11 for the mushroom soy, to $17 for the shrimp and crab dumpling and you can get add-ons like pork belly, hen's egg, buttered corn, crispy tofu, extra noodles, and more, for $2 each extra. 

I was here for a work dinner so I kept within budget with the $11 mushroom soy ramen. Just kidding again! Work is paying for this? I'll throw in the buttered corn, crispy tofu, and hen's egg, son! Which, in the end, was still actually cheaper than any of my colleagues bowls so I didn't actually shred the gnar too hard. 

For appetizers we got edamame, duck wings, and crab and shrimp dumplings. My colleagues didn't seem too crazy in to the duck wings but the edamame was A-Ok and I loved the crab and shrimp dumplings. I totally could've devoured several orders of those on my own. 

The bowl was absolutely enough for two meals - mine even stretched to being two meals and an appetizer for me over the next few days. The broth was pretty creamy for what I'm used to and I would've liked to see more seaweed sheets as an add-on option on the menu, though I'm sure if I'd have asked they would've gladly forked them over. 

Noodles were plentiful, the hen's eggs could have been a little less cooked, but it was still good, but I thought for even just $2 that there could have been more than 6-ish little tofu cubes in there. 

I really liked that they had the chili paste out on the table because I basically can't live without heaping spoonfuls of that in my ramen, and the house-made togarashi didn't disappoint either. 

Oh, and also worth mentioning is their beer selection - not huge, but well selected for the cuisine and great with the price point, plus you can get the draft stuff in pitchers if you're really in the mood. 

Definitely don't leave without dessert. I'd go back specifically for the coffee jelly dessert, but the rest of the dessert selection (perfect for individual dining) is mighty tempting as well.
author: Candice G.

description:
I drank a matcha green shake with boba from the Ramen Bar at the Saturday Fallfest event (a fundraiser for Meals on Wheels SF).

This was the best cold beverage (since I don't drink beer) at the event.
Creamy with a deep matcha flavor. It reminded me of soften green tea ice cream but with a nicer texture.

I gotta get more of this...
author: Joanna T.

description:
Their ramen is slurpalicious here!  Pork belly was nice and tender.  Broth had a homely taste to it!  

The outside lounge patio is pleasant and breezy on a warm day!  Inside ambiance is contemporary and service is spot on!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I'm a skeptic when it comes to Michael Mina. One of my worst meals was at one his restaurants so when The Ramen Bar opened up, I had my doubts. 

Well. I was pretty much spot on. 

Ramen Bar sounded good, looked promising despite being overpriced for ramen. I get it that it's FiDi and it's Michael Mina but the price point isn't justified. Okay now don't get me wrong. I'm not saying it is terrible. HOWEVER I am saying it is not exceptionally great either, nor is it worth the money.

Ramen Bar offers donburi as well as ramen. Just note that the menu changes. By the time you get there, maybe what I had won't be on the menu anymore.

Hokkaido miso butter ramen chasu ramen - sooooooooo bland it was boring. the only thing I liked was my egg.. and that was at least done beautifully.
kurobuta pork donburi -  just ok. HUGE PORTION. 
Roasted chicken ramen - get this. the broth actually has flavor!! it's sorta salty! i liked this way more than my own miso butter ramen.. 

I would come back, but for chicken ramen. And yes folks, they don't do the ever so famous tonkotsu ramen. GET OVER IT.
author: Susy C.

description:
I like the convenience of ordering online and the menu, great for a cold winter day. I also like that they gave fish options for lunch. 

However today I got the rice bowl with salmon, and the fish portion was just measly. I was looking for the other half.   For the price I expect better.
author: Inga W.

description:
I'm going to be honest, I am by no means a ramen expert. Does that mean you should pass over my review in favor of one who has a bit more experience? Probably. JUST KIDDING! I had a great meal here and think you should too. 

Michael Mina is a well known chef who creates some killer restaurant concepts. While his ramen may not be the homey, old fashioned stuff you're used to, it's delicious! 

The menu isn't anything crazy. When going to a place called The Ramen Bar for the first time, it seems silly to not give their namesake dish a try. I tried the shrimp and crab dumpling kind and it was awesome. Others around me jazzed up their ramen with an egg, pork belly and tofu but I just tried it regular. As a spicy food fiend, I tossed in a couple heaps of chili paste and was in BUSINESS. 

To start, we also tried the edamame, pork buns, duck wings and crab and shrimp dumplings (I swear there were a lot of us). The winners here were undoubtedly the pork buns and dumplings. It was hard for me to stop eating those before the main stuff came around. 

Like I said, it was a party and that called for pitchers of Kirin. Those, combined with my seemingly bottomless bowl of ramen, definitely made for one hydrated diner! Even so, I didn't leave without trying a dessert (the waiter brought ALL of them over to us on a platter that made the offerings just too tempting). I got the yuzu bars which were like the sophisticated cousin of a moist lemon bar. It was the perfect ending to this kind of meal. 

I caught on from SF locals that this ramen costs a bit more than some other places. To an out of towner like me, paying around $15 for a meal that could easily suffice for two dinners is an a-ok deal in my book!
author: Cassie P.

description:
For date night, both of us had walked past the Ramen Bar and been intrigued by the idea of Michael Mina's take on ramen so we decided to try it. Sadly, it was exactly as other reviewers said and quite disappointing. I'm not going to give it 1 star because there was one thing I liked but I will warn any ramen enthusiasts to pass on this.

For starters we ordered the pork gyoza and the crispy miso duck wings. While the gyoza was average I'm really glad we ordered the duck wings because it was the saving grace of the meal. They were unique and tasty, albeit a bit dry. The dryness actually worked for it though because of how crispy and delicious the skin was.

I ordered the spicy miso butter ramen and it was underwhelming. The broth was too thin for my tastes which in turn let the butter take over the miso too much. The char siu was average and the pork belly which I added was disappointing as well. I did like the slow cooked egg that I added which was basically a poached egg that let you add some yolkiness to the broth, but it was not enough to save the dish.

Overall, this is not even a contender for good ramen destinations in SF. I will keep looking because "I've experienced better."
author: Mark O.

description: So slow. So F slow. And I have no sympathy, the fact that they are too cheap to buck up for an extra line cook is very much on display . Not sure why they don't get that more orders processed equals more money
author: Jim M.

description:
No, no, no, no, no.

How can you put Michael Mina's name on something and not have it stand up to Mina standards? 

Yes, this is an eclectic, casual ramen bar in the otherwise not-so-casual FiDi. I get that.

Yes, this is an attempt to make somewhat trendy otherwise basic food. I get that. 

But the food? Very meh. The miso ramen that I ordered was far more mediocre than other ramen joints on the Peninsula. You can have a ramen joint with trendy ramen. But a trendy ramen joint with not-so-good ramen? No, no, no.

And dessert? The server also mentioned that  the same desserts were served at Pabu (next door), so having yet to try Pabu, we ordered the sake roll cake. It sounded decent, but it looked so unappealing the moment it arrived and we were so disinterested in consuming it...in a plastic to-go container! 

And no, this dessert was not to-go. It was to eat in-house as we had eaten the rest of our meal. However, it was packed in a obviously refrigerated (hello condensation!) plastic container. How un-classy is that!? Seriously unappealing. I can't imagine Michael Mina ever being okay with the fact that dine-in desserts are being served in plastic containers at one of his restaurants.

As much of a Michael Mina fan that I might be, I'm definitely not paying to dine here again.
author: Mansi A.

description:
During my last trip to San Francisco I was lucky enough to eat lots of yummy sushi and other amazing delights at Pabu.* Sadly I didn't make it to Pabu during this trip, but that's OK because I did get to pay their little sister, The Ramen Bar, a visit.

To be honest I'm not really a ramen type of girl. I love noodles, but everytime I have ramen I'm less than impressed. However, after my experience at The Ramen Bar I realize I just haven't been going to very good places. My shrimp and crab dumpling ramen was beyond delicious. So delish that I ate way too much and was in a food coma for approximately 18 hours, but soooo worth it.

Our waiter was as good as my ramen. His enthusiasm was contagious and I couldn't help, but order just about everything he suggested for our table (hence the food coma). Everything turned out to be pretty much every app and dessert, but I didn't hear any complaints from my dining companions. 

I loved that the dessert was pre-packaged so you could take it to go in case you just happened to be too full from your ramen, which is likely.

The drink menu didn't do much for me (perhaps big sis Pabu could pass on some mixology drinks), but my glass of sauvignon blanc was sufficient.

Hooray for my new love of ramen! Now I just need to find a ramen spot in Chicagoland that compares to The Ramen Bar. Bueller? Bueller?

*http://www.yelp.com/biz/pabu-san-francisco
author: Andrea R.

description: Great Service and the food was steamy hot. The broth was flavored with fresh spices and noodles cooked with perfection.
author: Eddie G.

description:
My group and I ordered the HOKKAIDO MISO-BUTTER CHASHU and we all thought it was mediocre. We didn't think it was worth the $14 price tag. $14 is pretty steep for a bowl of mediocre ramen.... We all thought the broth was pretty tasty until towards the end of our meal, it ended up tasting rather salty to us...... which means they use MSG!!!!

I also ordered the green tea boba and I thought it was mediocre.

Would I come here again? Probably not....

The location was pretty nice though!!
author: Alice X.

description:
2.5 STARS

My lunchtime routine consists of staring at my computer screen while eating a pathetically paltry sandwich with the occasional glance outside my office window to see hobos sharing a 40. 

As you can tell, I definitely don't work in the FiDi so it's rare that I'm ever in the area. 

I wanted to kill two Michael Mina birds with one stone so I dragged Mr. NSS with me to check out Ramen Bar after we had dinner at Pabu. Yes, a second dinner but that's how they roll in Japan after an izakaya meal. Heffer status justified. =)

Walking into Ramen Bar, we were confused with the seating and ordering system. Apparently for dine-in orders, you have to wait to be seated while for to-go orders, you stand in line under the "order here" sign. 

We opted for counter seats at the window so we could be creepers and people watch. There's otherwise plenty of two-tops, several communal tables, and outdoor seating in their courtyard. There's a glass enclosed open kitchen and lots of wooden furnishings like their adjoining sister restaurant, Pabu. 

M E N U:
*Ramen: Tokyo Roasted Chicken ($12), Braised Pork Belly ($12), Shrimp & Crab Dumpling ($16) and Mushroom & Tofu ($11)
--Toppings ($2 each): Buttered corn, braised pork belly, soy cured hen egg, and extra noodles 
--Gluten-free noodles available
--Sadly, no tonkotsu broth available because according to an Inside Scoop SF article, Chef and Mina's Partner, Ken Tominaga (Hana, Rohnert Park) doesn't like tonkotsu. Ehhh, that's like opening a taqueria and not having carnitas on the menu. 
*Donburi ($12 each): Pork, Chicken, Short Rib, and Salmon
*Salads ($12 each): Salmon, Chicken, Beef Tataki, and Mushroom & Tofu 

There's also 3 desserts on the menu ($3 each): Coffee jelly, Sake roll cake, and Pabu chocolate. 

Beer and Junmai are available. 

Ramen Bar is definitely ramen made for the masses where the focus seems to be to produce as many ramen bowls as possible to feed as many FiDiers as possible. Understandably so, it's the FiDi after all. 

Portions are small and it doesn't seem like you're getting a full bowl of ramen (broth filled 1/3rds of the bowl, scant amount of noodles and toppings). For a filling meal, you may want to consider adding extra protein and extra noodles which will bring your total to over $20 including tax and tip. Pricey for a bowl of ramen but not very surprising given the prime real estate location. 

Since we just ate dinner at Pabu, we shared the Braised Pork Belly Ramen w/ extra pork belly and buttered corn ($12 + $2 + $2) which quickly came out within 4 minutes of ordering: http://bit.ly/1j2J5Kd.

The quintessential components of a solid bowl of ramen are the broth and the noodles, both of which Ramen Bar were severely lacking execution in. Opening kinks I hope. 

While I appreciate that Ramen Bar doesn't use msg in their broth, it seems like they tried to compensate by adding more soy and/or salt. The lukewarm shoyu broth was incredibly salty and one-dimensional with no depth of flavor. No umami whatsoever. I'm not trying to be a sarcastic beeeatch but I'm shocked that some reviewers found the broth to be "light". Maybe if I was slurping "light soy sauce" then yes, it's "light". 

The spaghetti-like noodles were nicely al-dente which is great except I'm not eating at a Italian restaurant. The noodles lacked a springy, toothsome chew that good ramen noodles should have. 

While the broth and noodles left little to be desired, the chasu pork belly was very tender but you're only given two minuscule slivers for a regular order. Other ramen places usually give you two palm-sized slices. 

We added "buttered corn" which wasn't buttered but added a sweet crisp to help make the very salty broth somewhat bearable. 

The best component of the ramen bowl was the "soy cured" hen egg which had a perfect lava yolk consistency except it wasn't a "soy cured" egg as advertised on the menu. The surface didn't take on a tawny brown color and didn't have a mild, savory sweet flavor. It tasted like a plain, soft boiled egg. They should update their menu to reflect that because that's false advertising. 

Ramen Bar offers typical condiments like togarashi and white pepper but it was a huge turn off to see the togarashi chilling at each table in an uncovered saucer. Who knows where Joe Schmo's fingers been right?

For dessert, I did enjoy their Sake Roll Cake ($3) which was light, fluffy, and delicately sweet with fresh berries; just like how Asian cakes should be: http://bit.ly/1qUWYKm.

Service was very upbeat, friendly, and fast so kudos for that and rounding up to 3 stars as a result. 

If I still worked in the area, Ramen Underground would be my choice for a much more satisfying bowl of ramen at a fraction of the cost. That and sharing a 40 with a cutie in a Burberry tie. Guys in suits and ties. Hubba hubba.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Noodles: OK
Soup: Too cold. Too salty.
Eggs: Decent
Chashu: Good.
Interior: Very good. 
Price: $14. On the pricey side but it is FiDi.

Will I come back? Probably not. But if friends insist then I'm OK with it.
author: Joseph L.

description:
I didn't quite believe it initially when I saw the average yelp ratings on this place. After all, it is the brainchild of a celebrity chef... it has to be good! 

I decided to give this place a try myself, and am disappointed to report that the rating is indeed mediocre. I had the hokkaido miso ramen and it tasted more like a plain bowl of noodle in soup rather than a good bowl of Japanese ramen. While the ingredients making up a bowl of ramen noodles were all there, there was just something off about it... it just doesnt come together as one. The broth was plain and not rich enough, noodles were not the best - tasted more soggy than chewy/ springy.

The restaurant itself is pretty large. Order and pay at the counter, and free seating within the restaurant. it gets busy during lunch hours though, but I doubt I'll return again to worry about that!
author: Christina N.

description:
Oh Michael Mina, I had such high hopes for you but this place just didn't hit the spot for me. 

I came here around 6:30PM on a Wednesday, the patio was packed with a waiting list but there were plenty of regular seats available and the bar area, so we were seated immediately.

I ordered the Soy & Mushroom ramen and my man friend ordered the Seafood ramen, both were mediocre, the flavor was lacking and the broth was a tad too thick. We also ordered a matcha green milk tea w/ boba, boy that was a huge mistake! The matcha was too overpowering, the milk tea was disgusting and hard to digest. Michael Mina did not do justice to this place, the food was not impressive and I've had way better ramen than this place!
author: Katie N.

description:
3.5 Stars

Chasu Miso Butter Hokkaido-broth was flavorful, robust garlic notes, good mouthfeel

Adding more noddles was definitely well worth it, if they let you I would order one bowl with extra noodles and ask for a extra bowl to split 

Noodles were well cooked and tasty 

Pork was tender, decent in portion, and somewhat flavorful 

Price is definitely steep for ramen but not too outrageous of a markup 

Overall Thoughts

Definitely stick with the Hokkaido broths if you want something with more depth of flavor
author: Eddie W.

description:
I like this place! The menu is expansive and includes ramen bowls, rice bowls, sandwiches, etc. I opted for a rice bowl with tuna poke and it was tasty and filling, though more on the expensive side for an everyday, grab and go lunch ($16). I can also see why some reviewers don't think this place is 'authentic,' but that doesn't bother me at all. I kinda like the modern touch on Ramen Bar, since there are quite a few hole-in-the-wall spots in San Francisco already.

I would come back for lunch with a friend or coworker - I love the clean interior and ample seating, including outdoor seating for warmer months! You still order at the counter and have the food brought out, so it's also way faster than a formal sit down restaurant.
author: Connie Q.

description:
WHEN ITS MICHAEL MINA... you expect quality. He was there AND I GOT SERVED!
(4.25 stars)

Came here on Day 2 opening. Lined up 10:55am as lunch starts at 11am (at the front area of the line). Line was out the door and it took a good 20 minutes to get to the cashiers. Ratio of cashiers to customers was overwelming, 3 : 20. Order food, get a number, sit, and eat. It's small inside but FiDi crowd moves through quickly. The food was delivered much faster then standing in line. and portions were fair. The food was quality in my books.

FOOD.
DONBURI SESAME SALMON ($12) - umami spinach, spicy kewpie. I did not expect much but presentation was nice and taste was good. I really tasted the quality in this dish compared to many other donburi i've had elsewhere. The salmon was fresh, perfectly seasoned, and the spicy kewpie added that light spicy element to the dish. Enjoyed the plays of protein and veggies. 

PABU CHOCOLATE ($3.95) - white chocolate green tea mousse, plum sake. desserts should always have texture! The green squares on top were crunchy like a biscotti, the green mousse had the after-taste of green tea, and the bottom was the plum sake jam. The plum sake jam was a bit sweet when tasted on its own, might be best to mix it with the rest of the mousse.

SWEET (MINI) MILK ROLLS ($2.50) - comes with butter and jam (i chose the raspberry ginger jam). The rolls are typical sweet rolls, nothing special. The jam tastes really good, its sweet but not overpowering. They mix it with sugar and honey to cut the acidity from the fruit. 

Will I be back? YES. BUT... after the "new restaurant on the block" phase passes. 

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description:
Fast and simple service when I arrived around 11:30am. The ginger chicken ramen was delicious, not too salty by any means! Chicken was a little dry so let it soak up the soup flavor. 

Decent portion size, you can take home half for two sufficient meals.
author: Lexy C.

description:
Ramen Bar is underrated.

Having a famous chef creates alot of hype, which is why I think expectations were high and ratings were low. Ramen Bar may have long lines but it moves QUICK, and I love their gluten free options and premium ingredients (mmm mushrooms). For a heartier bowl of ramen in downtown I still prefer Ramen Underground or Katanaya but Ramen Bar offers convenience, speed and a unique take on ramen that would keep me coming back more frequently than all the others. 

Pro-tips for first timers:
1. This is an order/pay, get a number, type of restaurant. Arrive with your full party, come early to avoid the lines, but lines move fast.
2. Everything is tasty, fresh and it's a unique take on ramen. Don't expect Ramen Dojo or Santouka.
3. Favorite items: chicken and salmon (incredibly moist), gluten free noodles, shimeji mushrooms, duck appetizer, spicy miso broth, coffee jelly dessert. 
4. Least favorite items: Seared beef tataki, milk teas.
5. You can order in advance online.

* "HOKKAIDO" MISO-BUTTER CHASHU RAMEN ($14) - 3.5 STARS:
Nice, rich buttery broth but I felt it was missing something. The chasu a bit too thin for my liking but they provide a generous amount of corn and the egg is cooked to perfection.

* SPICY MISO CHICKEN RAMEN ($14) - 4.5 STARS:
My favorite ramen of all the flavors. Rich and spicy and the chicken in general here is moist and tender.

* SHRIMP & CRAB DUMPLING RAMEN ($16) - 3.5 STARS:
Interesting, flavorful but light broth. The crab dumpling had an odd texture, a bit mushy and pasty. 

* MILK TEAS (~$3.50) - 2 STARS:
The milk teas are premixed and could use some work on many fronts (far too sweet, low quality milk tea flavor). They offer a chai milk, regular milk tea, and matcha milk tea, with a fee you can spike it with alcohol. The tapioca balls are the saving grace and are cooked perfectly. They also give you a pretty large cup.

* COFFEE JELLY ($3.95) - 5 STARS:
soy-caramel pudding, coffee jelly, sesame. This did not taste like soy, it was rich creamy and luscious with just the right amount of sweetness. It's topped with a coffee flavored jelly and an amazing crumble. 

* SAKE ROLL CAKE ($3.95) - 4.5 STARS:
whipped cream, berries. I don't taste the sake, it tastes like strawberry shortcake with fresh berries and a light whipped cream. I could eat this all day. 

* GREEN TEA PARFAIT ($3.95) - 2 STARS:
white chocolate-green tea mousse, plum-sake jam. Super smooth but too sweet for me.
author: Jess C.

description:
Ken Tominaga and Michael Mina got together and opened a restaurant serves traditional ramen, salads, donburi. and other dishes. With big names comes a big hype. And unfortunately, I don't think the food lives up to the hype.

- Hokkaido Miso-Butter Chashu ($14): Broth is rich and creamy
- Tokyo-Style Kurobuta Pork ($12): Lighter broth, nice egg, but noodles could be better
- Beef Short Rib Kare ($12): Rice with curry, pieces of meat were delicious and paired nicely with the potatoes and carrots
- Wakame Salad ($4): nothing special and small portions
- Steamed Pork Buns ($6): good ratio of bun, piece of pork, and other ingredients

For higher than average prices, I'd go elsewhere for my ramen fix. However, their service is awesome and they have happy hour!

Happy Hour every Friday (3pm-9pm!). 
- Kirin Ichiban: $2/glass or $16/pitcher
- Momkawa Junnmai Ginjo Sake: $4
- Daily Shochu Punch: $5
- Beer and a sake shot: $6
- Little Bites: $4-7
author: Christine S.

description:
Ah, The Ramen Bar. Similar to my experience with Pabu, I can see the INSANELY long line that starts around 11am right out my window, and for the last two weeks, I've asked myself, do I really want to stand for that long?  Having had a lackluster experience at Pabu, I delayed my visit until a friend of mine wanted to try it and needed a person to go with.

Naturally, we got in line when it was about 20 minutes deep.  Accept this fact; you will have to wait if you want to eat here. After debating on what to order, my friend and I decided to go halfsies on the Hokkaido Miso Butter Chashu Ramen and the Beef Short Rib Kare Donburi. Ordering was easy, but the wait was equally long as the line leading up to ordering.

The ramen was...meh. The soup was surprisingly very tasty (maybe even a little salty, and I never met a sodium molecule I didn't like) and was SPICY!  The noodles were a little too chewy for me, and the thing I really enjoyed? The egg.  The Beef Short Rib Kare was also spicy, so the two dishes combined made me feel like my mouth got a huge kick in the ass. Not a bad thing, but you've been warned.  I loved the crispy shallots that were served on top of the rice, but wasn't a huge fan of the mostly raw potatoes and carrots that came with the curry. The pickled onions and ginger on the dish were also delicious, despite the fact that the curry itself wasn't anything special (or anything you couldn't make yourself or find at Nijiya).

So, after all of this, my conclusion is similar to how I felt about Pabu - it's a halfway decent place when you aren't the one paying for it.  Paying $15 for ramen and $12 for a rice bowl seems silly in mind, but most definitely OK if work's telling me to spend skrilla on lunch. So, to sum everything up, here's how I'm feeling:

- Do I think there are better options for ramen? In the FiDi, not really.
- Was what I ate worth $30? No, I could probably find better ways to spend that.
- Am I going to come back? Eh, maybe, but only for special occasions.
author: Lisa I.

description: Horrible service. I put up with it for a while because I liked their poke trio but not anymore. Took over 15 minutes to get my food. Asked the servers multiple times and they told me it would come out soon. Finally I asked the manager and he said my ticket never made it to the kitchen. Manager didn't apologize and gave me an attitude while telling me if I still want my food the chef can fire it up right now. Manager don't know what customer service is and this will be another restaurant to fold because they think they're the $hit.
author: Sandy L.

description:
I had never heard of Michael Mina before I went to this place for lunch, but supposedly that meant this place had some built in cachet. It's serviceable, for the FiDi crowd, but honestly, nothing they do here should be cause for concern for my San Mateo benchmarks of Santa Ramen and Ramen Dojo. It's not bad, but it's not great. In fact, since Kirimachi opened up at Embarcadero 3, I haven't been back to Ramen Bar. There's something about paying upwards of $17/$18 for meh ramen.

It's well run, and I wouldn't say it's bad here, just nothing particularly special. If it was the only game in this part of town, I'd probably still go, maybe once a month, for those times mid-week when I just had to have ramen. With Kirimachi on the scene though, I likely won't be back to this place.

If you come for lunch (as I imagine most people do, vs. dinnertime), best to show up sometime around 11:30, to ensure you get a table). With all of the various high rises around it, it does fill up at lunch.
author: Rod V.

description:
First of all, you'll really appreciate the menu if you dine with an open mind. That means... don't walk through the door expecting a bowl of noodles like it's straight out of Japan because you'll be very disappointed. I was actually in Japan about a month ago and that ramen was amazing. Ramen Bar, however, does hold its own. 

I can't compare Ramen Bar with places like Katana-Ya, Orenchi, etc. because.. Like any Mina restaurant.. Ramen Bar wants to be unique.. And it is!

The biggest difference between traditional ramen and the stuff served here, to me, is the broth. The broth does't taste as rich but rather more refined, with a slight "West Coast style" as they say. When I eat a good bowl of traditional ramen, it's more like "punch in the mouth" flavor and hits me with one spoonful. Ramen Bar's broth is more like a ballet- complex but elegant. 

Food: The Tonkatsu ($14) is a little one off.. Made with pork belly, shoyu Tate, soft boiled egg, benishoga and cabbage.

Drinks: Does not offer a full bar and can't order drinks from Pabu BUT I did try their Boozy Boba ($7) which is vodka, green tea and honey with honey boba. The drink was pretty boring (or rather highlighted the boba?) and the boba was some of the best I've ever had, even topping several places in Taiwan.

Service: Excellent, as usual! The server was very attentive and stopped by several times to ensure our meal was going well. 

This place is definitely a 5 star establishment, especially if you're not a drinker, but I'm pretty disappointed I can't order actual cocktails when Pabu is down the hall. Next time, I'm going to sneak in a small bottle of Yamazaki and ask for sparkling water for a DIY Highball.
author: Chris W.

description:
I am glad I tried this place despite the low overall rating it gets from the other yelpers (since they usually are spot on).  I ate here 3 times before deciding to write my review.

It's a good ramen soup lunch spot. I tried 3 different kind of their offerings (2 of the pork ones and the chicken one). The broth is tasty, the noodles are great, and the portion is just right. I like the way they season their eggs, which come with all of the 3 ramen bowls I tried.

Service is quite excellent for a casual place. They bring you water and refill your glass too. They bring your soup to your table, clear your table, and yet no tips seem to be expected. I tipped because I appreciate their service. 

Price is ranging from $11 to $14 per bowl. Considering the location and ambience in additional to quality of the food and its portion, I think it is fair. I would return especially during a cold winter day.
author: Tracy L.

description:
This place is great! I came here on a weekday for dinner, it wasn't busy, as I heard the line for lunch can be long. 

I got the Hokkaido miso butter chashu ramen. It was wonderful. It's definitely on the richer side for ramen. But I never got tired of it through the entire time, which I do sometimes with some ramen. There was the very flavorful and slightly spicy broth, a perfectly cured egg sliced in half, very nice ramen noodles, some roasted seaweed, and sweet corn. 

The shrimp and crab dumplings are nice too. It had no meat in the broth, so it's a flavorful clam broth, some crab dumplings, and the same noodles. It's a lot lighter than the Hokkaido which was nice. I thought it could use a bit more spice in it - but you have the condiments (some homemade, some not) on your table. 

I'm very happy with the food I got there. Definitely happy to go back again.
author: Wendy K.

description: Relatively flavourless and well under par. Hunks of chicken (with skin/fat in places) that were too large to eat in a bit, yet only fork, spoon or chopsticks..... Want to like it, but didn't
author: Scott D.

description: Truly some of the worst ramen that I've ever had. Do not go here. There is a Peet's across the street, you can probably get a sandwich or a yogurt parfait.
author: Nan L.

description:
My ramen bowl was served luke warm to me.  On top of that, their front door was left wide open for a big draft in the winter to chill my ramen bowl even more.

My ramen had a ton of lettuce, which is odd to have in ramen.
author: D D.

description:
Definitely not a great place to go for lunch on the weekdays. I would recommend to order pickup online in advance. The line during lunch time usually extends outside. 

I've ordered here twice, only because it was the closest ramen shop to work. And let's just say there are nights when I crave RAMEN. I've definitely had better ramen for the same price. 

I've tried the Hokkaido Ramen and had asked to make it more spicy. But when I received my bowl of ramen, it ended up being sweet rather than spicy.. The broth was also on the thicker end. Therefore, if you wanted something a bit smoother/lighter, I would opt for the Tokyo-Style ramen. 

Being the harsh ramen critique that I am, I wouldn't order ramen from here again. The broth, noodles and chashu weren't amazing enough to justify its price.
author: Anais G.

description: I write this to give some constructive criticism, especially to the manager.  I work in the building, I order the poke bowl(s) mostly, at least once a week, and everything is usually fresh and delicious (except for once)-BUT, every time I order the poke bowl, the ingredients are different.  A few times lately, I have gotten back to my desk with a poke bowl that has rice, a small amount of salmon, a few little cucumbers and zero greens--most of the time, the poke bowl has some nicely dressed mizuna type greens included (and there is a menu option to pay $1 extra for "greens only").  Today, I noticed before I left that my bowl had no greens at all.  The woman who took my order said that was a mistake (which I knew from my past orders), but the manager insisted that greens are never part of the poke bowl--huh? So, he huffed off, and threw some dry greens on top.  The woman ahead of me ordered half greens, and half rice (so she clearly thought greens were part of the poke bowl).  She said she always has some problem there as well (we both waited almost 20 minutes, and it was 11:45 and not busy yet-they had clearly forgotten my order--I was nice about it).  Anyway, Ramen Bar could be so much better if it were consistent with the ingredients, and as others have said, a tiny bit more generous when you are paying $14-$16 for a bowl.  If the bowl now has no greens (as the manager indicated), I won't go back--it is not tasty or substantial enough without them.  In addition, as others have mentioned, friendlier service would go a long way.  The manager is busy and efficient, but he is gruff with everyone and never smiles.  Makes it a negative experience unnecessarily.
author: Barbara M.

description:
The line was long, it went fast(ish) - I think we waited for 15-20 min, and this was during prime lunch hour. Got a seat at the bar alongside the window. Ate and was satisfied. 

I'm not a HUGE ramen fan, so I was surprised I actually ate most of my bowl. I had the Tokyo one.

They ran out of royal milk tea by the time I got to the front of the line :( But the matcha was pretty good.
author: Angela L.

description:
So the first time I had Ramen Bar, I ordered something pretty heavy, either the Hokkaido or a special they had that day. As I was heading back to work, I started feeling extremely sick. Maybe it was the car ride or the food or a combination of both but even after I got out, I knew something was off and I felt disgusting from what I'm assuming was the ridiculously high concentration of oil in the soup. 

I knew I should have ordered the salad or a rice bowl..IF you do come here, do not try to consume more than half your ramen broth! You're going to wish you hadn't!! 

Also it seems like lunch gets pretty packed here. Their dessert was interesting. Bumps up the rating a little bit. Rating: 2 stars 

I wanted to give it a second try and this time I had a better experience. No feeling of nausea. We got the salad with sesame salmon ($12) and chilled noodles (+$2). Not too shabby other than the spinach being drenched in vinaigrette. The chilled noodles were a nice addition. 

To make sure we satisfied our ramen craving, we also got a pork belly ramen to share. But they couldn't split our order into two different bowls because the ramen was prepared beforehand. What?!? That was a bummer. Also random but why does the strawberry mule come in such a tiny glass??? Rating: 3 stars

Ramen Bar is in a convenient location and is relatively affordable compared to Pabu next door, but after eating here twice, I know that this won't be at the top of my list anytime in the future.  The ramen wasn't awful but it also wasn't the best. Passable if you're in the area and have nowhere else to go. Final Rating: 2.5 stars
author: Ingrid C.

description:
FiDi's latest addition has opened!  (resounding cheers are echoing throughout the Embarcadero Center!)

Luckily the weather was near perfect today and I did not mind waiting 25 minutes in line outside to order.  Heck!  I even made a few friends in line and had fun responding to a gentleman in a suit who heckled "it better be worth it!"

The cashier was more than friendly and responded promptly when I asked "for the salad, should I try salmon or beef?"  I went with his suggestion, the salmon.  

The dining room and patio were obviously full of patrons shoveling colorful spoonfuls of ramen into their mouths.  The atmosphere is clean, hip/trendy, and the patio is lovely on sunny days like today.  

After about a 5 minute wait my name was called and my to-go order was ready for pickup.  

The portion appeared to be decent sized and packaged neatly in a takeout bowl with chopsticks and a soy sauce packet wrapped in a napkin.  However, I view this as a $13+ lunch salad and I simply expected more.  The dressing was abundant and VERY salty.  There was no need to add that extra soy sauce packet!  Also, the salmon was very, very "fishy" tasting.  The ramen noodles were not as tender and plentiful as I had hoped.  I did enjoy the fresh mixed greens, peppers, and green beans-- they were delightful......I'm all done with my lunch now and I'm still slightly hungry.  This shouldn't happen with a $13+ lunch meal :(  

Meh, I'll probably be back to try a ramen dish and give it another shot.  Also, the to-go brittle, cookies, puddings, and other desserts look like an appetizing afternoon snack.
author: Andrea H.

description:
The ramen here is ok, but definitely not worth the price. Then again, it's fidi and everything here is jacked up in price. 

The line here on the weekdays goes out the door. It's a pretty long wait if you're coming here for lunch in the fidi.
author: Grace T.

description:
Upscale ramen bar? Check
Prime downtown location? Check
Can't get enough gourmet ramen? Come here.

When one of my international colleagues had yet to try ramen, I knew where I was going to take her for lunch. The Ramen Bar is another Michael Mina success and is located right next to Pabu. The atmosphere is classy, yet completely accessible. It's a popular lunch destination, so if you're taking your food to go, calling ahead is a good trick to skip the line.

The Ramen Bar has a wide variety of delicious broths, both meat and vegetable based. I chose the mushroom and soy and my coworker tried the ginger chicken ramen. With a plentiful portion of noodles and creamy, rich broth, there's every reason to enjoy. Perfect for chilly "SF summer" days.
author: Shira W.

description: V ordinary. Ordered the Hokkaido and it wasn't impressive at all. There was no flavor in the gravy. Not sure if I am going to come back here. Have definitely had better.
author: Ver C.

description: Their ramen is probably the best in the fidi area, in my opinion. Pretty good broth with the soft boiled egg yum! I've also tried their boozy boba, which is pretty good! You can't really taste the alcohol that much but it's a good slight buzz :) this place is kind of pricey, but you get what you pay for! For the chef, convenience and taste :) I've recommended this place to quite a few people and I would definitely come again when I'm craving ramen!
author: Bailey L.

description: Michael Mina style ramen - innovative ramen creations. The ginger chicken ramen is my favorite, with tender chunks of chicken marinated with not over powering ginger. The soft boiled egg is the best part. The broth has a more intense flavor than the usual traditional ramen in other places. Bear in mind that this restaurant is not exactly your typical ramen shop. It's more like fusion Japanese - California style cooking. The other ramen selections are good too. Try the hot tea. I think the jasmine pearl balls of tea pair well with the soups. Nice country style interior and lots of wood decor.
author: Lucy L.

description: The Ramen Bar is a little overpriced and overrated. The ramen broth is tasty but it's always lukewarm vs. piping hot whether I get take out or eat there. I actually prefer take out because then I can warm my soup in the microwave and it's cool that you can order ahead online. I really enjoy the soy-cured soft cooked egg and the pork belly and ginger chicken but the overall ramen bowl is nothing to rave about. I've had both the regular ramen noodles as well as the gluten free noodles and they are both good though their noodles tend to stick together in a blob. Their gluten free noodles actually look similar to the regular ramen noodles and have a nice chewy texture. I don't know of any other ramen place with gluten free noodles so this is a plus at the Ramen Bar and their Deviled Ramen Eggs are delicious.
author: Jen L.

description: I went back on a cool SF Fall afternoon for some ramen - perfect!  I had the Tokyo Ramen - loved the egg, the pork belly was so tender and flavorful, and the broth was soooo good, not too salty - just right.  I heard they added some sandwiches and salads to their menu.  I need to go back and try those sometime, but I have a feeling when I go, I'm going to want ramen!
author: Maile N.

description:
There is nothing better than a hot bowl of quality broth in chilly Downtown San Francisco.  Get there early and beat the lines, otherwise you will maybe seated outside.  Like many restaurants, in Japan, you order and pay before they serve you.  Stand in line to place your order and be sure to grab your drink from the cooler as you are waiting in line.  Place your order and pay, the cashier will provide a number which you post at your table.  Don't worry, the wait time for your food is very fast!  
Food 
Hokaido Ramen - spicy, pork broth with corn, thin slice of char shu pork, and marinated soft boiled egg garnished with a piece of nori (seaweed) and ramen noodles.
Tonkotsu Ramen - pork broth, six pieces of fried, breaded pork, with marinated soft boiled egg garnished with green onions and red, pickled ginger and ramen noodles.
Shoyu Ramen - thinner, darker soy sauce broth thin slice of char shu pork, with marinated soft boiled egg garnished with green onions and red, pickl,ed ginger and ramen noodles.
Hawaiian style Ahi Poke served with won ton chips, avocado, small seasoned chunks of Ahi (yellow fin tuna), and seaweed.
author: Richard H.

description: I was really looking forward to trying this place since it's close-ish to me. Ramen Bar has a few different options for broth. Between me and my friends, we all tried each of the different broth and thought they were all just okay. One of my friends also ordered poke and it took FOREVER to come out. We were all finished eating before he got his food.
author: Anny T.

description:
Pretty great ramen, especially for this part of the financial district. For lunch on the Friday before a holiday weekend, there was absolutely no line. The Tokyo Ramen + Thai tea with boba came out to about $23 -- a bit on the pricey side for lunch. When the ramen was delivered, I knew I was in for a good time. The broth was rich, tasty and not too salty. The bitter greens were portioned perfectly, and did a great job cutting the fat of the four pork slices. I added just a touch of sichimi powder to bring up the spicy level -- really complimented the flavor. 
I quite enjoyed the experience and will be back. The happy hour also looks like a great deal!
P.S. - There is a small poster near the exit door that describes a special deal: if you bring in and donate a fully functional (all the pieces, nothing broken/missing/torn/destroyed) board game and talk with the manager, apparently you get a bowl of ramen for free. If you're interested in trying this place and (assuming this special is still happening) you can probably end up financially ahead if you find an old/used/intact board game at Goodwill or a garage sale or something and trade it in for a free ramen.
author: Paul L.

description:
We came here on a weekday for lunch and got a seat. It was pretty full, with people constantly coming in and out. I got a matcha latte, which was not great.

For ramen, I got Tokyo style. It was mediocre. The noodles and broth were flavorful, but I thought the north was slightly saltier and oilier than it needed to be. It tasted good with the noodles, but it was hard for me to drink it by itself. I liked that they cut the soft-boiled egg in half, which made it easier to eat. The ramen here was also on the pricier side, but it was SF I guess.
author: Aimee Z.

description:
I must confess I went to the Ramen Bar and didn't order the ramen.  I did however, order the Salmon Donburi and it was pretty satisfying.  I'm thinking of making a run over there now.   The service is quick and efficient. 

I work in the financial district and am always running short on time during lunch so it's great to know that I can place an order online to save time.  I definitely recommend the Salmon Donburi which is a bit pricey but definitely worth the money. 
 
I also highly recommend their cheesecake dessert!  I'm in love with it and bought a couple to take home to share with my husband.  Although, unfortunately they never made it home because I couldn't resist the temptation to eat them at my desk.  I'm stopping by to try the ramen soon!
author: Christine P.

description: So service was fine, and they had gluten free ramen...but it really wasn't very good. The broth just didn't taste very good at all. The mixture of flavors was not pleasing to the palate it was conflicting flavors. You could tell the egg was old. They burnt the chicken that was for the soup...plus it was dry. I wouldn't try again, but the people were very nice.
author: Eldar B.

description:
What an odd ramen bar. It was not at all what I pictured before going. It has a cool look to it, but I was disappointed in most of their ramen broths.

It's a strange blend of a Japanese Ramen Bar and a Wolfgang Puck Express, in particular the Wolfgang Puck Express at Chicago Ohare International Airport. The layout and approach is almost identical. The only difference is at Chicago Ohare, you are in airport captivity and Wolfgang's is the best of the less than ideal fast food options inside security. This is why I have eaten at this Wolfgang Puck's a zillion times. The Ramen Bar on the other hand, has to compete with all the other great food options in San Francisco.

Just like Wolfgang's there's the fridge to the right as you stand in line, and the relatively limited menu to keep the kitchen simple.

The problem is the food, I tried 3 of the broths and only really liked one of them, the Hokkaido Miso-Butter Chashu Ramen. The rest were just too plain or salty with no depth.

That said I did enjoy the Hokkaido Miso-Butter Chashu Ramen with the extra pork belly. The cured eggs that come with the ramen are quite good. I also liked the coffee jelly on soy-caramel mousse dessert.

The staff was friendly, but the wait of 10 to 15 mins was longer than I expected if you are doing take out. My takeout noodles were overcooked even though they were packed separately from the soup. I'm not sure they have the takeout formula optimized yet. I'd recommend calling ahead or ordering on-line to save time.

A good local fast food option, but it did not quite live up to my earlier hopes of a Japanese Ramen Bar like the one in the Jûzô Itami' classic movie, "Tanpopo".
author: David T.

description:
I really have liked this place the couple times I have come here.  First off, I would say they have a crazy lunch rush but the line does move pretty quick.  If you prefer not to wait just come in the afternoon.

Everything I have tried here tastes great.  The duck wings are amazing, but they're only available on the evening menu.  The gyudon bowl was absolutely delicious.  For those who like beef and rice, I strongly suggest trying it.  The edamame was what you should expect.  The mushroom ramen bowl was quite tasty with a little bit of a spicy kick.

The location of this place is one of the best parts.  It's right in the middle of the financial district, and as hustle-n-bustle as that area is, the patio is incredibly relaxing because there are plenty of beautiful plants, people, and buildings to look at while eating.  It's also a block away from Bart so it's very easy to get to from across town.

The restaurant was very clean.  The servers have always been polite.  The Manager (I believe his name is Ricky) came out to make sure our orders were all correct and tasted well.  He even made a few suggestions we might like for drinks and desserts.  I have had a great few visits here and I plan on coming back sometime soon.
author: Justin H.

description: Nice little lunch spot with a chain feel to it. The staff aren't the most friendly and the ramen is decent. It's an OK place to grab a bite in a pinch.
author: Derwood A.

description:
My coworkers and I decided to come here yesterday for lunch. Since it really is about less than two blocks from where we worked, we decided to get here at 11:30 to try this ramen place by Michael Mina. 

AMBIENCE: Darker lighting, wooden tables all around. Can get a bit crowded where sometimes you will have to get comfortable with sharing a table with someone next to you.

ORDERING: wait in line to order, and they give you a number, seat yourself. 

DRINKS AND FOOD: Ramen, Wagyu burgers, boba, desserts, japanese salads etc. 
I had the Tokyo Style Ramen ($13), the pork belly was good and flavorful, and I did like the soup base. The egg was cooked to PERFECTION. However, it was a bit overpriced for the amount of food for lunch. But it was great to at least try. Not sure if I would come back again, since there are better food options around the area that is more bang for your buck. 

One of my coworkers ordered the Hokkaido ramen (*$14), which has spicy yasai miso tare, corn, pork belly, soy-cured egg. But... it wasn't spicy at all.. 

We also ordered two hong kong milk tea's with boba. They ran out of the large cups so they ended up giving us three boba milk teas instead of two to make up for it.. They also sell mason jar's for your milk tea but it's an additional $3. 
So, 
Milk Tea: $3.50
Topping: .50
Mason Jar: $3

TIMING: Come before 12, the line goes out the door or can get pretty busy between 12-2.
author: Tiffany J.

description:
Let the Kirimachi Ramen vs. Ramen Bar Battle Begin!
(Here is the link to the sister review http://www.yelp.com/biz/kirimachi-ramen-san-francisco-2?hrid=PMFs0y56fxg8lI4rd8mFAA)

INTRODUCTION:
So, everyone is buzzing about the fact that there are 2 higher-end ramen shop concepts in FiDi now (no, they are not tying to be like your favorite $7 ramen hole in the wall).  This is a big deal.  Partly because I love ramen/noodle soup so much I have written it a sonnet my life-time.  Also, because artisan ramen had an all time peak in popularity in 2014.  More importantly, this is one of the unique times in my over 500 reviews I am pretty confident I can do a very apples-to-apples comparison.   Being the over analytic person I am, this is exciting.  Lastly, because less face it, I want to do something more exciting than my regular reviews. 

In case you were wondering about my ramen-eating qualifications, I have reviewed 13 ramen places so far on yelp (http://www.yelp.com/list/2-ramen-eating-san-francisco).  I have eaten at way more places than I have reviewed.  Also, if I made an "asian noodle soup" list, nobody would read it because it would be over 50 restaurants long...

THE ATMOSPHERE/WAIT TIMES:
Dining In- At ramen bar, you wait in a reasonably fast moving line at 12:00pm (longer at 12:30pm) to order at a register.  You get a number and your ramen and wine are delivered VERY quickly.  There is surprisingly ample seating despite the line even on a Thursday at 12:00pm (see how I went on Thursday at 12:00pm both days for even more accurate comparison?!)
Take Out-  I think this would be great take out, just like Kirimachi.  I'd call in my order and pick it up.  

THE FOOD:
There were two ramen types that were the most similar between the restaurants.  I enlisted my cousin to help me try both at the same time at each location.

1) Miso Ramen (Kirimachi) $13-Dashi based broth, chashu pork, baby arugula, corn, green onion, soy marinated soft boiled egg.
VS
Spicy Chasu Miso Butter Ramen (Ramen Bar) $14- braised pork, garlic, sweet corn, soy cured egg.  (To see the detailed review, go to the sister review)


2) Shoyu Ramen (Kirimachi) $13- lighter pork broth, chashu, Tokyo scallion, memma, soy marinated soft boiled egg
VS
Tokyo Style Ramen (Ramen Bar) $12- Kurobuta pork, wakame, soy cured egg. (To see the detailed review, go to the sister review).

THE COMPARISON:
Ramen Bar Tokyo Style Ramen was better than their Chasu Miso Butter Ramen.  We felt that the broth was much better.  The spicy miso broth was too concentrated and almost too salty for me (and I seriously eat pure salt for the taste/fun).  The heat was there but did not fix the problem or have a distinct flavor.  The Shoyu broth was a better balance and was much more pleasant to eat.   The Ramen Bar noodles were smoother and even thinner than Kirimachi.  They had chew but somehow, it was not quite right.  The soft cooked egg was perfection, you get both halves of the egg (this is a big plus!) and they packed in a whole lot of excellent flavor into the cured egg.  This egg is a superstar.  Go egg go!  I thought the corn was kind of dissappointing because it was obviously canned and lacked the crispness and flavor of the fresh or good quality frozen corn.  I thought the greens in the Ramen Bar ramen were classic, plentiful, and good.  I loved the portion and quality of the wakame, spinach, large piece of nori, green onion, and bamboo shoots.  Lastly, loved the chasu meat at Ramen bar because it was soft, fatty, and juicy.  I could have eaten more than one slice for sure! My cousin said he prefers leaner cuts of meat.


The portion sizes here are a heavy lunch portion.  Not quite enough to take half home unless you eat like a tiny bird, but not enough to feed that person you know who can never get enough food.  I thought it felt quite decadent eating the whole thing. I could have left about 1/4 of it...but who does that?!  It was a good temperature and came out lightening fast.  

Kirimachi's Miso was better than Ramen Bar's Chasu Miso Butter Ramen
(See Sister Review for more detail http://www.yelp.com/biz/kirimachi-ramen-san-francisco-2?hrid=PMFs0y56fxg8lI4rd8mFAA)

Kirimachi's Shoyu was not as good as Ramen Bar's Tokyo Style Ramen
(See Sister Review for more detail http://www.yelp.com/biz/kirimachi-ramen-san-francisco-2?hrid=PMFs0y56fxg8lI4rd8mFAA)

THE OVERALL WINNERS:
Noodles-- Kirimachi (Susan and Cousin Agree)
Broth--Miso Better at Kirimachi, Shoyu Better at Ramen Bar (Susan and Cousin Agree)
Meat--Chasu better at Ramen Bar (Susan-who likes more fat on pork) Chasu better at Kirimachi (Cousin who likes leaner pork).
Egg--Better at Ramen Bar (Susan and Cousin Agree)
Corn--Better at Kirimachi (Susan and Cousin Agree)
Greens-- Better at Ramen Bar (Susan and Cousin Agree)

P.S. I hate that my "as you type" spell check red-line thinks that Ramen is misspelled.  This whole review is covered in red.

P.P.S. The $6 tiny glass of crappy wine is barely worth the money.
author: Susan C.

description:
I went here with coworkers to see why there was always a line... I still don't understand why there would EVER be a line...

The ramen broth was lukewarm... All of our ramen had zero flavors and they were supposedly all different?

I know you're dumbing down the food and flavors for the fidi crowd that probably never had any exposure to ramen but really... No salt or msg can be found? Oh are you too health conscious for flavor? 

Avoid this place! Ajisen at the mall has the same prices and flavors... And perhaps aren't as pretentious in what they feed their customers...
author: Nathan D.

description:
Have been here a few times since its opening. Yesterday I had the Miso butter ramen with Chasu (pork shoulder) because Me-so hungry. (I had to). Although a bit skimpy on the meat, the broth definitely had a silky smooth buttery taste. Quite savory. 

My colleague had the ginger chicken ramen and seemed to enjoy it, but he's from Texas where anything non-BBQ is "foreign" and therefore unique. Just kidding Sal, you're my boy for Austin eats!

I also like how they serve both sake and Sapporo on tap. I'll keep that in mind the next cold, slow SF afternoon. 

Only downside: pricey. $37 for those 2 bowls and 2 teas? Thanks, Financial District wallet gaugery!
author: Sandino N.

description:
I love ramen. It's comforting, delicious, filling, tasty, full of healthy food, you can pick what you want and don't want in it. San Francisco has many options for ramen in it and some are better than others. With the popularity of ramen, more and more places are popping up and we try them out when we can. Sometimes though, it's hard to justify the cost of what is essentially noodle soup. 

The other day I decided to order from Ramen Bar through their online tool. I went through the menu and found their online ordering tool, and picked out what I wanted (mushroom and soy ramen with no extras included since I wanted my first order to be just the default soup). I ordered for pickup since it was literally one block over, as ramen shouldn't be allowed to sit and soak in its broth or given a chance to cool down much.

I walked over and picked up my order as soon as I placed it, and despite the really heavy line up out the door, was able to skip all the way to the front and get my food right away. I headed back to the office and pulled my containers out in the kitchen only to be really annoyed/frustrated over the set up: everything is divided up in separate containers, which is great, but without having a large bowl to put everything in, I had to rely on the containers they gave me to put everything in, essentially a large, tall upright skinny container. Not exactly the best option, but something to keep in mind for future take outs.

Once I managed to get everything put together, I dipped into the hot soup. It's extremely mushroomy and flavourful, but I wasn't much of a fan of the taste once I got into it. Now, this is personal preference so I can't complain there, but on the flip side, ramen noodles should feel slightly undercooked, chewy, with a solid bite to them. These weren't overcooked but they weren't the solid al dente style noodles I expected. After sitting in the soup a bit longer, they became soft and a lot more meh, totally not what I wanted in ramen. 

I got through about half of my soup before I was just bored and done with it. I was disappointed and let down, like I'd gone on a mediocre date after being so excited for it. In a city that has such amazing, awesome food and can serve up some beautiful ramen, there's no reason to settle for "just adequate".
author: Cassandra J.

description: I absolutely LOVE the Chashu Miso-Butter Hokkaido here. This is what keeps me coming back. Well, that and the fact that it's across the street from my work. The hokkaido is one of my favorite ramen dishes in the city. I just wish it wasn't so expensive.  I get it, we're in the Financial District and the partner chef is Michael Mina. I just can't get myself to pay that much on ramen all the time. With tax, it's like $16+...and that's on a to-go order.
author: Resa N.

description:
The "ramen" here is not real ramen. I think it may be geared toward a "fusion cuisine" audience. 

I ordered the Tokyo-style Shoyu Ramen. The noodles were very basic, off-the-shelf noodles that were somewhat overcooked. The soup was way too sweet... like kakuni-level sweet. Why is my Shoyu ramen sweet?! And why is there Mizuna on my ramen? Random. All in all, my "ramen" was just not worth $12. 

That being said, a lot of other people seem to like this place because of it's easy-access & fast-service.
author: Manami K.

description:
I really don't buy into the hype for this place, and luckily on the 2 occasions I've come, it hasn't been overwhelmingly crowded, or else it would have been a bigger disappointment.  The interior architecture may have been the only highlight of my lunches here; the decor reveals the concrete structure, and that juxtaposes against the wood counters and tables really well.  I like the tall exposed ceilings and the way the counter wraps around the restaurant, leaving the chefs visible to the restaurant goers. However, along with high ceilings comes really accentuated acoustics.  The place is loud, almost difficult to have a comfortable conversation over a meal when it is crowded, and like I said, I was eating there when the restaurant was not at max capacity.  Luckily, from my experience, the cashier service and the serving process was efficient and quick; I did not have to wait long for my meal. 

Both times I came for lunch, I was ravenous.  I don't have a preference for traditional vs non-traditional ramen, I am pretty open minded to the ingredients and seasonings for noodles in general.  I didn't expect it to be so hard to find a good ramen fix in the diverse city of San Francisco, but with the co-branded hype, this fell short for me at each visit.

1st visit - 
Hokkaido 3/5: The sweet corn in this dish was probably the most unique part, and highlight, of my meal. The pork tasted a bit washed out and plain, as though the fat in the meat was the only part that brought out any taste at all.  The broth was light and buttery as described without being too oily which I appreciated.  On a rainy day, this was a decent place to stop in for a late lunch.

2nd visit-
Tonkatsu 2/5:  The noodles were firm and chewy with a smooth slurp-able texture which is what I prefer, however, it was a bit tasteless.  The soup tried to compensate for the lack of flavor in the noodles by being ridiculously heavy and salty.  Each scoop of soup dehydrated me further, and each of the ingredients were fresh as advertised, but added very little flavor.  I did enjoy the pork and how it was seasoned, but there was literally 1 small diced up thin sheet of pork that topped my soup, and seemed like a rip-off considering I had paid a $3 premium for their "special" Tonkatsu dish.  The soft boiled egg was bland as well, but tasted better when seasoned with some of the black pepper they offered at the tables. 

Overall,  The ramen flavor I've come to love and expect is lackluster, and the portion size is medium at best.  I rarely finish a meal without feeling absolutely stuffed, but after my lunch here, I still felt a pang of hunger as I left. With the ramen priced at $12-14, I can't say that I'll likely be back when there are more flavorful options around for the same price point.

I suggest Ramen Underground for better ramen at the same price, and Ajisen ramen for slightly cheaper ok ramen if you don't mind eating in a food court.
author: Kathy T.

description:
Expensive and mediocre. 

This place is expensive and the ramen is just average. To top it off, they only give you a few slivers of pork. Not a good value and not worth it.
author: James D.

description:
I went here for lunch with my gf today. She ordered the poke trio (salmon, tuna, and octopus) with half brown/white rice. She ordered it for pick-up so I can't really comment on the service or wait time. However, while we were eating it outside in this public seating area we saw that the line was redonkulously long.

I'm not really sure I understand the whole commotion. The dish was good but not anything out of this world. I'll admit it's different from the usual cafe sandwich place so maybe that's why everyone is all about this place. I have nothing bad to say because the food was good but nothing beyond my expectations. I'd recommend it to anyone else and will go back for sure, but I would also recommend that one shouldn't enter with such a high expectation.
author: Elliott J.

description: The portion for Salmon poke bowl has gone down. they cut into small pieces and charged is such a RIP off. Ordered Black Noodle in vegetarian style ... not worth $9.
author: Rose C.

description: Not authentic in style or flavor. True Japanophiles don't eat here as this will disappoint.
author: Gav J.

description:
I'm not a ramen expert but eat my share of pho and Thai soups. Occasionally get a bowl at SFO when heading back to Texas. 

With that as a preamble, grabbed a bowl of Tokyo-style pork ramen. The pork was very tasty and not to fatty. And the broth...delicious. The marinated soft boiled egg was a tad bit sweet and had perfect texture - also great. Nice, fresh greens and onions as a garnish. Didn't need any additional seasoning. I'll be back tomorrow to try something else.
author: Chris C.

description:
Had ginger chicken ramen. It was really tasty, but just a little overpriced. It was good in a sense that it reminded me of my mom's home cooking - not too salty or overly flavourful - every slurp is nice and refreshing.

Would come back if I have someone else's money to spend. lol.

Environment is fast casual: you pay first and then get a number so that food will be delivered to you later.
author: Lucy C.

description:
Poke, yes, Poke. At a Ramen Bar you say? Yea, sure, why not. 

Came here during the lunch hour with a coworker because we received a coupon through my "Thanx" app. I am glad we got that coupon because we came to check the place out. The other poke I have had is just rice and the fish with a few add-ins, but this one comes in mixed in nicely in a bowl. I got the poke trio, so it came with tuna, octopus, and salmon. It was a great choice and the fish was fresh.

Shout out to the staff, great customer service for prime time lunch hour in the Embarcadero area!
author: Mayra E.

description:
This place is excellent.

I am unsure as to the experience of some of the reviewers. I used to live in Japan, and while there, I got to taste some incredible ramen.

Unnecessary to say, most places outside of Japan are, in fact, pretty mediocre, if not less. 

The Ramen Bar, however, is unique. The menu is reasonably diverse, and most of all, the dishes actually deliver different tastes (as opposed to the usual "ramen with a) meat, b) chicken, c) special meat" sort of thing).

Also, their salads and Donburi are incredible. The management is very accommodating and friendly, too. I usually give more negative reviews but even after a year coming here, I have nothing negative to say about this place.

Forget the other "Asian" restaurants. This place will give you a good experience. The prices are also pretty average for eating in the Financial District. Not really overpriced.

Keep in mind, this is not a place for a date, or family dinner. This place is for lunch (business lunch) and thus, very practically orientated.
author: René X.

description:
You can't beat The Ramen Bar for service!
Although you can't Reserve a table.  Just order a drink if your early and put there.  You can always ask for extra noodles too!
author: Brian W.

description:
Expectations are high since this is a Michael Mina restaurant. 4 stars only because the dessert menu seemed a bit thin. But other than that, ordered the Poke bowl and the ahi was fresh. Cubed in small pieces mixed with fish eggs to appear to be plentiful, but when it came down to it, it was just the right amount. I was full and ate all my ahi pieces. We also ordered the pork gyoza that was fresh as well. A friend ordered shoyu ramen and substituted it with chicken. her rating of her meal was not too salty and ono. 

This place did not disappoint. Quality fresh ingredients were on point. Meal size was just right as well. And for me, that's what matters.
author: Gwen K.

description: The staff here is always very friendly, so that's a plus. I've had difficulty with their menu. When they first opened, I tried the pork belly ramen several times and was never happy with the meat. Recently, I went back to try new menu items they had and really enjoyed the tuna tacos and cheeseburger. Unfortunately, they got rid of these recently and their menu seems to have lost a lot of selections. They offer sushi rolls, but they are pre-made at the restaurant next door and just sit in a refrigerator. I live in the Financial District so I typically go here during dinner time and there's never a wait. I hope they bring the tacos and burger back!
author: Alexander C.

description:
I love a good bowl of ramen, and this is a really great stop. It's not super traditional, and the restaurant offers cool ambience and delicious food in a casual setting that's not gladly not oozing in pretentiousness or stuffiness. They do good food in a fun environment that should make everyone feel welcome. We came with a large group and were able to be seated and accommodated easily with our large party. We ordered up some pitchers of Kirin and settled in for a relaxed night.
