We started with edamame, steamed pork buns, and crispy miso duck wings. The pork buns are steamed to tender and delicious puffiness. The duck wings weren't really a huge hit with the table, but if you like duck, they're worth a try. 

But let's talk ramen. The main event. I ordered the shrimp and crab dumpling ramen with ginger miso broth and sweet corn. And because I believe in going big, I threw a soy cured egg in that bad boy. The broth is light and flavorful. The crab is tender. The sweet corn really kicks the whole meal into a higher level in both texture and flavor. The sweetness balances the light, meaty flavors of the broth, and the plump and tender crunch adds a nicely interesting pop to the slurpy noodle goodness. The egg is definitely a game changer, but y'all know I'm Team Egg in and on all things. It's a great protein shot that satisfies in this dish. 

The house made chile paste and sweet and salty spice mix kicked the flavor profile up in a melodic symphony of complementary tastes. This bowl takes all of my favorite flavors and stirs them together so every bite hits the salty, sweet, meaty, umami soaked high that I crave. 

Do I have room for dessert? No. But I order it anyway. Our amazing server brought out a tray to show off the imaginative and creative sweets The Ramen Bar showcases. I was tempted by the uzu dessert and the peanut butter toffee brittle. I asked our waiter which he recommended, and he said hands down the uzu, which he described as a cross between a lemon bar and a shortbread, "but like way better." Sold. It's so light and refreshing while still being substantial enough to satiate my sweet tooth. 

All in all, I highly recommend The Ramen Bar. It's the perfect spot to have a loud, group meal and be taken care of attentively. The service is above and beyond, and most importantly, the food satisfies. This whimsical and fun take on comfort food should please any lighthearted food lover. Enjoy your slurp.
author: Lindsay R.

description: We had poki bowls.  Pretty disappointing. Fish is minced.  Pieces were so small they carried no flavor to the pallet. Service at the counter was unfriendly. No horrible but not friendly either. A smile would have been nice.
author: Greg M.

description: When I heard that Michael minna opened up a ramen joint I was super excited to try it. I expected it to be the best ramen I've ever had but sadly we were disappointed. My boyfriend and I came for dinner Monday night and the place was empty. We had the box sampler that came with duck wings, edamame, crab wontons, and a pork belly bun. I didn't care for any of them but my boyfriend liked the wontons so he got another order.  For ramen he got the chasu miso butter corn and I had the Tokyo style ramen.  The portions were really small, they only give you one piece of meat, an egg that's been bathing in soy sauce, and some seaweed and bamboo shoots.  Everything was pretty salty and usually my boyfriend loves soft boiled eggs but these he said had a really weird flavor to it. We tried it, don't need to be back.
author: Linz C.

description:
Having lived in San Mateo and experienced some of the best ramen that the Peninsula/South Bay offers, The Ramen Bars more than earns a hearty 4-stars.

Is it comparable to Santouka or Ramen Dojo? No! And they're not trying to be. Consider this gourmet ramen with a funky edge.

One of the many great things about TRB is that the line moves fast! Order at the counter, grab a drink/dessert and get a number. That seriously cuts down on the long wait that many other ramen places suffer from.

I tried the seafood dumplings and was pleased with the flavor. There are many spices/sauces to add to the broth if looking for an extra "kick", but this was lunchtime and I didn't want to go back to the office with dragon breath :)

Probably my favorite two things about TRB were 1) Sitting at the bar and watching the kitchen staff hard at work preparing the food and 2) Milk bread, fresh baked with butter and jam. So good.

Again, this isn't the typical ramen so don't go in with any preconceived notions of what ramen "should" be and you'll have an excellent experience!

Note: I received a complimentary lunch sampling as part of an upcoming event menu preview. Though I have since returned and just suggested this as a great spot for a work dinner as well.
author: Abby S.

description:
Came here to get lunch with my coworker. We got here just before noon and beat the lunch rush! This place is very popular and by the time we were done people were leaping to grab our table. I ordered the tonkotsu ramen and a matcha milk tea. 

Tonkotsu ramen: 4 stars. I actually really enjoyed this ramen. There was a generous serving of tonkotsu, perfectly soft boiled egg and the broth was flavorful and creamy. They have the spicy powder on the side so I could make it spicy to my liking. There was also a generous serving of noodles. I could barely finish my bowl! For $14 this is a good option if you love to have a lot of meat in your ramen like me! 

Matcha milk tea: 3 stars: this was just very okay. I don't think I'll be ordering it again. Since ordering both brought my lunchtime bill up to $20! Ah woes of working in the Fidi...

Service: This is the type of place where you pay first and then grab an empty table and pour your own glass of water from the cooler. I like that it's more casual so you don't have to wait forever to be seated. Our food came pretty quickly as well!
author: Jasmine Y.

description:
Okay, so it's very likely not the best ramen you can find in the city, or the most authentic, but if you don't want to wait in line for an hour or just want a good meal in the FiDi (especially in the evening when everything else is closed!), this is a pretty good ramen spot.

Ramen had good flavor, not too salty, which I appreciate. And they had a decent chicken ramen, which some of the more authentic places do not.

On the flip side, the fruit tea was much too sweet. Had a sip of the unsweetened tea to taste it before I ordered, and that was better than the sweetened version.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Did anybody experience the Ramen Yokocho Festival in J-Town last weekend? It was like a scene from the Hunger Games. Literally. Post Street was packed with desperate people waiting 2-3 hours for small bowls. Ramen is apparently the new black. Actually it's the old black. Lukewarm, however, appears to be the new black because the heat is what was missing on the two occasions I've dined here. Also the paucity of noodles was rather disappointing. Where is David Chang's gluttonous approach when we need it so badly in this city? Probably among the most unlikely chefs to open a ramen house, Michael Mina has partnered with chef Ken Tominaga of Rohnert Park's Hana to unleash a casual spot targeted to softer FiDi palates.

I have to say I'm a bit mixed on the results. On the upside and indicative of Mina's usually immaculate style, the ingredients in the bowls are fresh and tasty. However, I was bummed on my first visit not to see a tonkotsu selection on the menu. When I asked, I was informed that lunch customers are not usually looking for something that heavy, so they made a conscious decision not to offer it. Say what? If I want a milky broth made of boiling pork bones, fat, and collagen, I think I should have it, don't you? Alas, I was left to try the $12 Tokyo-Style Kurobuta Pork Ramen with wakame, soy-cured egg and spinach. For an extra $2, I ordered the Braised Pork Belly since I'm usually not satisfied with the amount of chashu I get. I was right.

What got me was that it cost me yet another $2 for buttered corn kernels (photo: http://bit.ly/1pJOaoD). In hindsight, I kinda wonder if I should have spent the last $2 on extra noodles since they were a bit skimpy compared to any bowl you'd find at Yamadaya or Men Oh Tokushima. It was still quite good because it's Mina-endorsed after all, but the $16 price tag gave me pause. I did save room for the $3.96 Coffee Jelly, a more fanciful version than you'd find in a J-Town grocery fridge but still in a disposable plastic cup. It was anchored by a mousse-like soy-caramel pudding and topped with sweet sesame croutons (photo: http://bit.ly/UpBglZ). To the manager's credit, she sought my feedback to which I directly responded that I missed a tonkotsu option and wished the broth was warmer.

On my return visit a week later, she remembered me and recommended the new addition to the menu, the $14 "Hokkaido" Miso-Butter Chashu Ramen. Ah, better. It was even billed as a "heavier style" with the sweet corn already thrown in with the egg as well as garlic (photo: http://bit.ly/1pe9iC5). This time, I ordered neither the extra pork nor the noodles, and the bowl was a bit lacking in quantity for dinner at least. Temperature was still an issue, and I'm not sure why since it wasn't as crowded as it was at lunch. Lines, however moved pretty quickly on both visits as did the ramen, so kudos to them for conquering the phobia I was clearly feeling at the festival last weekend. I did notice Mina in the kitchen on the second visit, so he's definitely not phoning this shop in while focusing on the more upscale Pabu next door. Good for him as I wait and see if they get into the right mojo here.

FOOD - 3 stars...fresh ingredients but temperature and noodle quantity was lacking...ramen takes time to perfect, bring me the tonkotsu please
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...pretty good space. not too challenging to get a table even at lunch (photo: http://bit.ly/1A9Jkbh)
SERVICE - 4 stars...attentive and kudos to the manager for taking my (and everyone else's) feedback seriously
TOTAL - 3.5 stars...could move up to a 4 if they turn up the heat on the stove and add a few more Sun noodles to the mix
author: Ed U.

description:
This review is based off my first visit! It's subject to change (hopefully for the good lol).

The food isn't half bad here! I'm highly critical of Japanese food restaurants and all I have to say is that I'm glad the food is fresh. I ordered the poke bowl with salmon and it was good! I also grabbed a spicy tuna roll which is premade and it wasn't half bad either! What I liked the most was the matcha(sp) iced tea with boba. That drink is to die for! I'm still getting to know the area as it's a new work location and I've been figuring out what I can do for sushi. This is the place for me! If you're looking for sushi/ramen to go (or dine in!) with a bar vibe this is an awesome place!

I'm looking forward to trying all their dishes including the ramen!
author: Destin M.

description:
This is plated art ladies and gentlemen! 
My favorite place for Ramen in the city,  great ambiance, super friendly and DELICIOUS.
author: Gaby B.

description:
No tonkotsu broth!!! Yeah, deal with it.

While I myself do love the milky white viscous broth that is so prominently associated with ramen, I am happy that a fresh lighter yet flavorful take on ramen broth is being served here.  In fact the first bowl of ramen I ordered here on opening day was the Tokyo Roast Chicken.  The chicken was perfect, the egg was perfect and the broth was a welcome surprise.  It was the best chicken noodle soup I've ever had.

I've been back several times and noticed that the ramen and donburi options change slightly on each visit.  This is going to be fun!

Other items I've ordered are the short rib kare, seated beef tataki salad and finally today I went full pork with the Tokyo kurobata pork ramen with buttered corn added.  The short rib kare had tender beef and a savory curry.  The seared beef tataki was refreshing with fresh veggies, bright ginger, punchy yuzu and wonderful seared beef.  I really liked the pork ramen, with a broth that wasn't going to leave me feeling bloated or ready for a nap when I got back to the office.  And I do need to mention how great the cured eggs are! At every visit, but today, they were beautifully soft boiled and have a wonderfully pronounced flavor.  My egg today was overdone but still tasted great.

I've also had a couple sweets in the form of their milk bread and the green tea parfait.  The milk bread was light and served with butter and house made fruit compotes.  The green tea parfait was very rich and needs the plum sauce at the bottom to balance out the mousse on top.

I'm looking forward to coming back and seeing what new variations of ramen and donburi make it on their menu.
author: Luis M.

description:
Not much has changed in my opinion of the Ramen Bar.  So I've left most of my first review below as it's pretty much the same. Seating was a little easier and the broth was a little better. This time around ordering took a long time as they never seemed to have cashiers at both registers. It would help if they had someone working the line to give suggestions and answer question so there is less hemming and hawing from people when they finally get to the counter. We all spent enough time in line to figure out what to order. I just think some people unfamiliar with the format could use a little help and they could provide someone to do that. Similar to what in and out does by having someone working their drive through when it's really long. 

My one big change with my opinion with the food is charging for a side of kimchi. It's a large side that for even two people is too much. They'd be better of giving out complimentary sides of it like a lot of places do. Other than that the ramen experience is the same as you'll read below. 

I'll admit I was drawn in by the hype. In the end it's all it is. My friend and I got in line around 1 and it was a quick wait as the cashiers ripped through 15 people.  Problem is you have to fend for yourself with seating.  I'd prefer assistance from staff at this point as it's possible in my eyes that you could end up getting your bowl before sitting down.  Maybe they're watching for it but I'd prefer organization in that respect.  

The ramen came out efficiently. Noodles were made well but the flavor of both of our broths was not very deep in flavor. We had the Tokyo Style and the Hokkaido Miso Butter.  Definitely needed help from the spicy paste and the togarashi at the table. The pork was a bit firm and not as fatty as I'd like.  If I worked in the area I could see being a regular as a ramen fan simply because they have 0 competition aside from Ramen Underground which is tiny and the occasional appearance by Hapa Ramen. I can see how people will like it and it will be a nice addition to the area.  In the end it's just not for me nor was it for my lunch partner. I'd give it a 2.5 if I could give half stars.
author: Joco F.

description:
I swear this place had 4+ stars just last week.. how quickly it's gone down. I think it's still worthy of 4, though!

I came here just a few days after opening. The line was super long out the door, but it moves really fast. They've got a large number of staff, and they move things efficiently. Not your typical ramen sit-down joint, but more like a "fast casual" ramen shop.

As for the ramen itself, it's quite good. I wasn't expecting much since Michael Mina isn't traditionally known for Asian cuisine, but hey, him and his chef got a good thing going here.

The typical American "ramen lover" seems to only know tonkotsu (and if I see you spelling it, "tonkAtsu", I'm going to discredit you immediately). If the broth ain't porky and milky, then they assume that the ramen sucks. Well, tonkotsu is only one  in a large array of ramen styles, and for this particular style (Tokyo-style, shoyu-style, whatever you wanna call it), this was legitimately good. Good broth, tender meat, and solid noodles.

So why not 5-stars?
...portion size.

For $12, I was still a bit hungry. Only 3 tiny pieces of meat, and maybe about 2/3 the amount of noodles of a typical ramen joint's bowl. All they need to do is give a little more food and it'll easily get higher reviews!
author: Kazu O.

description:
Known more affectionally as "Ken's Chicken Soup", a collaboration between Ken Tominaga (Hana) and Michael Mina. 

A few notes:
1. Don't go into here looking for *authentic* Japanese ramen. You're best off going to South Bay. To me, I would consider it still a good bowl.
2. Consider where you are eating, SF's Financial District. OF COURSE everything is going to be pricey. If you're not willing to spend the money then don't eat here.
---
VENUE: It's a 5-10 minute walk off Embarcadero BART located right next to Pabu. There's outdoor and indoor dining with bar space perfect for eating solo. 

If you go during peak lunch hours expect there will be a line. When I went on Friday ~noon, line was present but it was around 12 minutes from the time I fell in line to placing my order. Should you not want to wait there are 3 different ways of placing your order, but keep in mind that you can only do this for TO GO orders.
1. http://www.theramenbar.com
2. Facebook
3. App for iOS and Android.

SERVICE: Quite attentive. During both times I went the people brought your food items with a smile and they regularly kept on asking me if I wanted anything taken away. This was still true even during Friday lunch hour.

When I go I like to sit where I can watch my ramen bowl being made. There's an assembly line with the more experienced chefs towards the entrance handling the two most important parts of a good bowl: cooking and distributing the noodles and controlling the proportion of miso to broth. The rest of the chefs have an easier job of placing the rest of the ingredients and making sure the bowl looks aesthetically pleasing. 

Despite being called the RAMEN bar they also have a decent selection of non-ramen items. In particular I would like to try the donburis on my visit and this would be a convincing reason to bring the No1DP, who lives in the land of ramen... but doesn't like ramen all too much. There's a different menu for dinner but it's only slight changes. 

I had the opportunity to try the two most popular ramen, their "Hokkaido" Miso-Butter Chashu and the Spicy Miso Chicken ($14). Both are on the heavier side per the miso broth.
-Both bowls looked quite pleasing when served.
-Both bowls had their noodles al dente. This is a must in a good ramen bowl, the ramen should have the consistency of al dente pasta.
-The main difference between the miso bowls aside from the meat is that the meat imparts a different flavor to the broth. The pork really gives a feeling of "stick-to-the-ribs" comfort food and I enjoyed sipping the broth until my bowl was empty. I didn't get that feeling for the chicken, partly because I was rushed for time but also the chicken is less heavier than the pork.
-I really don't get the sweet corn. To me it just adds unnecessary starch. No1DP tells me that corn is actually a common topping in ramen in Japan.
-The soy-cured egg tastes somewhat sweet, I'm thinking this is soaked in mirin. The egg has a consistency that I love, one that has the yolk mostly done (not runny!) but still soft. 
-There's a decent amount of greens.
-The chashu is soft and tender and like I said before, the flavor really improves the broth. The chicken on the second bowl was tender for the most part but there were some chewy pieces that suggest that maybe the chicken wasn't cut up enough.
-There are sides that can spice up your bowl. I noticed there is shichimi powder and a spicy paste. I did this to my miso-butter chashu bowl and I ruined the taste by making it more spicy. Note to myself: next time don't do this.
-The spicy miso bowl needed more spicy. Note to myself: Next time add the spices.

I also had the ramen bowls with their milk teas, the Hong Kong and Masala Chai ($3.50 each). It's good for a milk tea drink that doesn't have too much powdery consistency.

Considering location and cost I can't be here too often but I look forward to creating more opportunities to do so.
author: Isabella B.

description:
I've had this bookmarked for awhile because 1.  I'm a big foodie/6 Year Yelp Elite , 2. I love ramen 3. I'm always looking for new lunch spots.  My coworker and I headed over what we thought could be early enough to avoid a long wait.  We were wrong, already a big line out the door when we got there around 11:25.  We waited probably about 15ish minutes in line, and around 15 minutes for our food.  It gave us time though to enjoy the decor, see the waitstaff's smiling faces and see Michael Mina.   We both ordered the Pork Belly Ramen ($12) and ordered them to go since our office isn't too far.

We finally got to dig in and the soup and dry ingredients (separated) were piping hot.  Portion did look a little on the smaller side, but still filled me up.  There were three small pieces of tender delicious pork...meaty enough but still had some of the fat for flavor.  The broth was a mix of pork and chicken dashi.  Also in the bowl was some seaweed, spinach, bamboo shoots, a few sprouts and a soy cured egg.  I'm thinking if I ate at the restaurant, the egg yolk would have been runny.  It was still gelatinous but didn't run when I ate it, one of the better eggs though I must say.  Noodle had the perfect bite to it too.  The broth could have used a little more flavor and was a little on the watery side.  Bamboo shoots were done right, as many places don't cook them for long enough.  Broth doesn't contain MSG and didn't make us thirsty.  

Honestly, I hope that they add more broths to their ramen menu as the Pork Belly one is the only one that interested me.  I don't like how the chicken ramen is combined with a seafood and chicken broth, and the shrimp and crab ramen sounds good, but it comes with a clam broth, and clams aren't my thing.  Definitely a bootycall ramen place, as it's pretty much the only ramen place in FiDI.  In fact, when one FiDi working friend and I really crave ramen for lunch, we would bus it to Katana-ya.  For the price, I'd prefer Katana-ya's signature ramen dish with all their goodies in it, even though they aren't on my top ramen list either.  If I'm seriously craving ramen in the FiDi, I'd probably come back for the same ramen as today, or I would possibly try one of their noodle salads or donburi (both also $12).  I asked one of the employees when they will expect their online ordering to be up, they said at least a week to work through the kinks and high demand.  The Ramen Bar is really a 3.5 and I was tempted to round down, but because everything really was cooked right it deserves a round up to the 4, just the broth and price/portion kind of made it more of a 3.
author: Cat C.

description: Just okay for ramen in fidi... it's by my apartment so it may just be my go to spot when i have no other options. There's also boba there and the matcha is good
author: Christine T.

description:
Ramen Bar is the latest addition to FiDi's sparse selection of ramen shops. Their take on ramen departs a little from traditional styles while still screaming ramen.

I stopped by on opening night and to my surprise there was plenty of room for me and my party of 6. The staff was super friendly and helpful and made us feel at home. If you come during the day, you would order at the counter and bring your number to your table. The interior of the restaurant is very trendy and classy, but casual. If I had a ramen restaurant, this is how I would picture it.

All the ramen choices sounded delicious as well as their donburi selection, but I opted for the Tokyo Roast Chicken Ramen with yuzu kosho while others got the Pork Belly Ramen. Our bowls came out steamy hot shortly after. It wasn't scalding hot like I like my broth, but definitely better than luke warm ramen at other places.

I first tasted the chicken broth. I didn't know what to make of the first sip other than it was rich in flavor. It is not as strong as a bowl of tonkotsu (my favorite) or spicy miso broth, but the flavors of the sea were very prominent. You could really taste the dashi flavor from the kombu (kelp) and the smokey bonito flakes. The more sips I took, the more the flavors began to unfold. I began to takes the citrus notes from the yuzu kosho. The flavors well rounded. I took a sip of my cousin's bowl of the braised pork belly ramen which had a nice rich lip smacking flavor.

The toppings were first class. The bamboo shoots were tender and marinated very well and the egg was heavenly. One of the best ramen egg I've had. The outside had a lovely sweet flavor and the yolk inside was creamy and silky smooth. A big plus was that it wasn't colder like other ramen joints.

The noodles, however, I felt like could use a little more snap to them. The flavor was there but it didn't have that bite to them that alkaline noodles should have. They mentioned on the menu that they use Chinese style egg and wheat noodles. While ramen noodles originate from China, both the original and contemporary ramen noodles do not contain eggs. They get their yellow color for the alkaline water (probably more information than you need to know). 

Overall I really like this place. Even though this was their opening day, it felt like they have been serving bowls of ramen for years. I am looking forward to seeing this place more often and seeing what is to come.

P.S. There is a lot of hate that they do not serve tonkotsu broth. I love tonkotsu broth for its fatty and overwhelming richness and mouth feel, but there is also beauty in shoyu or shio based broths that are often overlooked. That said, I wouldn't mind if a tonkotsu broth was added to the menu.
author: David C.

description:
Day 2 (July 1) Opening Week. Arrived at 12:22 PM to a line out the door. It went by quick tho and it took about 15 min to get inside to place our order for a party of 3. we ordered 2 braised pork belly ramen bowls, so wanting to try something else and be different ...

I ordered a mushroom & tofu ramen with added soy cured hen egg and 2x braised pork belly.

After finding a seat and waiting a couple more minutes, our ramen bowls came out. unfortunately, my bowl was missing the add on items, but that was easily fixed. to lighten the delay, I was told chef mina personally placed the egg onto my bowl. (oh snap, my order got some attention) 3 add-ons, who does that? =) My order came out to $17 before tax and tip. oops. I will try for the braised pork belly ramen on my next visit which is $12, but i might add another egg. lol.

But yea, back to what i thought about my bowl #nomnomnom

The egg was amazeballs. noodles, upon first bite, I noticed they were soft, but still chewy. it was different and i figured they were made from scratch (needs confirmation tho). The pork belly was delicious and i'm glad i got 2 orders. the broth was just right, it wasn't overly salty or overpowering. I finished my bowl until the very last drop.

The only thing i asked about was the temp of the broth. I was told, that in tokyo, it's all about speed and you can't be serving up a bowl of soup and have people wait another 5 min to start eating it after a cool down. That makes sense. Then i realized how many people walked in and out of that place in the time that i was casually having lunch with our group and thought wow. So as far as broth temp, it wasn't hot hot, but it wasn't cold or luke warm to where you didn't feel satisfied drinking it up.

-------------

Updating with 2nd visit =) 
Day 4 (July 3) Opening Week

Came back today with another group of 3 and tried the Braised Pork Belly Ramen ($12). Also shared the Beef Short Rib Donburi Bowl ($12). 

This review is already long so I'll be quick. Egg is still on point. The broth on this bowl was stronger, sharper. It all went well together but was a bit overpowering at the end when I ran out of noodles, meat, veggies. I still finished the bowl but I had to drink some water after finishing off the broth to ease the taste buds. 

The Beef Short Rib Donburi was really good. I'm not a curry expert but I like going to Curry House in Cupertino. This curry is thicker in comparison and quite flavorful. No added spice option, but there's powder on the table if you need that kick. A nice bonus was I couldn't smell the curry but the taste was there. A good change up.

------------

1.25  star for the egg
1.25  star for the food
1.25  star for the vibe
1.25  star for the staff
author: Karlo J.

description: This place is alright.  The noodles was a bit on the softer side and the soup was decent.  For the price you pay, you get a good selection of toppings on it.  Food comes out fairly quick.  Soup wasn't hot, warm at most.  Came here at 1pm and had a good amount of seating for a party of 3.
author: Henry T.

description:
This review is based on the beef tataki salad and pork belly ramen.

Ramen broth doesn't have the milky broth of a tonkotsu, so a different style for all you fatty broth lovers.  However, the broth has an unctuousness that does add to the mouth feel.  The noodles were however poorly executed, they were somehow overcooked and soft but still clumped together, as if undercooked.  Picture uploaded as proof to yelp.  Soft boiled egg was executed well, however, the pork belly was dry and not very tender, disappointing to say the least. 

Salad was way too salty as if the preparer was heavy handed with the salad dressing.  Ingredients were fresh and interesting but a poor sauce to ingredient ratio doomed the salad to dressing with a side of veggies.

Service and decor for opening night saved it from a 1 star.  I love that there's another ramen resto in fidi, it's desperately needed, too bad it's $12 for a pretty poorly executed bowl.   Would rather go to sozai, Fujiyoshi, shalala, or izakaya roku for ramen.
author: Paul C.

description:
When I heard that Michael Mina had opened a ramen shop I scoffed at the idea of fancy ramen.  Then I heard it was a fast casual eatery and the prices seemed reasonable, so I thought I'd give it a shot.

Props to the staff. The service was very efficient and the lines moved very fast.  

The ramen itself was good, although I was a bit disappointed that they didn't have tonkotsu broth.  Regardless the ramen was actually not bad, however my biggest complaint is the quantity for the price.  For $12 I would except a bit more meat and noodles.  I had three pieces of meat, but really two of them were so small that I would say I only had 1.5 pieces total.  Basically this is a cool place to try if you're in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way for it.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Doesn't live up to the quality of Pabu next door but it's still a solid option in the financial district for ramen. You won't find a nicer place (decor) for ramen and the price is reasonable. 

The ramen itself (tried the Tokyo-style) is good but not great -- I'd say the broth isn't as tasty as the best ramen I've ever had but it wasn't bad. The noodles were good but also not great. 

Food was fast. The place was lively. I'd come back if I was in the area during lunch or dinner and wanted something with no fuss. Ramen Underground (5 blocks away) is much tastier but much more cramp, less fancy, rushed, and cash only. So, depending what you want, Ramen Bar could win.
author: Victor W.

description:
I was a bit perplexed after finding out that Michael Mina had a restaurant opened in Japanese Ramen, as his expertise is in New American/Steakhouse fine luxurious dining.  Ramen is no where close to being in his genre and by far the complete opposite of what he's good at doing!  It got me worried that he was just jumping into the ramen craze band wagon that's been steadily growing more and more popular over this decade.  There use to be 2 ramen shops that I knew of way back in the days and they were in San Mateo (Santa Ramen and Ramen Club).  But now, there are so many more options for ramen and each has it's own distinct stamp on broth and noodles.  So, with a famous restaurateur, like M.Mina putting his designer name onto ramen, it was a must MUST try for me.

As we enter the rustic feeling Ramen Bar, it is quite spacious!  The walls are lined with neatly stacked jugs of soy sauce, hot sauce and all types of Asian ingredients.  They really wanted to make sure Japan stood out in this wooden box of noodle decor.  I liked the options of sitting at the open kitchen bar, wooden tables inside or bench seating outdoors.  Options are nice!

It was dinner time and we strolled right in and was seated immediately.  Our waiter, whom was friendly, was attentive and immediately begins educating us on the broth and how there's no popular tonkatsu broth available.  We already knew there was no tonkatsu but was ready to hear his recommendations.  Here's what our waiter recommended and we both ordered:

;-)  Bottled Shochu Hai ($10) - this was a nice grapfruit juice drink.  We didn't taste any sake but it did give us a light buzz on, which is all we ask for.  Next time, we'll try to get in during happy hour for this one, as $5 is more our liking.  - 3.5 STARS

;-)  Hokkadai Noodles with an extra topping of braised pork belly ($12 + $2) - First off, the noodles were really, really spectacular.  It was smooth, thin, al-dente and made great slurping noises.  Cooked to perfection and one of the best tasting ramen I've had.  The broth, which we were expecting to be a lighter version of tonkatsu was actually delightful with it's lightness.  I actually did NOT mind it was light because it still had enough fragrant to keep the flavors on my tongue happy.  The cha-sui was decent but I've had better.  The corn was immaculately freshly cut and so sweet!  Now, the waiter sold us on the braise pork belly as being the most tender fatty thing he put in his mouth, we beg to differ.  It was good but it was not the melt in your mouth pork belly that we were accustomed to.  Go to Santa Ramen and you'll understand why Ramen Bar's version was not up to par.  - 4 STARS Ramen & 2.5 STARS Braised Pork Belly

;-)  Sake Roll Cake with whipped cream and berries ($3.95) - It came out in a tacky plastic container.  At least take it out and put it on a dish!  At any rate, this sponge cake was a tad stale that night but the whip cream and berries were very light and airy.  It was good but we've had better...way better, especially the sponge cake.  -- 3 STARS

Overall, I was pleasantly surprised that I enjoyed their bowl of noodles.  I came in ready to be a hater because of a bad experience I had in Oakland's Ramen Shop (cost more, bad service, bad broth) and plus all the negative reviews I read on Yelp.  Now, to reconfirm that Ramen Bar has good ramen...go home and eat instant Top Ramen bought from a CVS store, then come back here and eat their freshly made noodles, delicious/light no-MSG broth and superior toppings, then you'll realize, damn, that's a really good bowl of Ramen.
author: Jenny T.

description:
So I came back 2 days later cuz I kept thinking about the other ramen bowls I wanted to try, lol. There's always a line but it moves quick and your food comes out just as fast. First time I was here I tried the pork belly ramen. SO GOOD! The broth was very light and flavorful.. I hear they do a 24 hour "brew" to make it! And it wasn't salty or fatty. I also liked how it was a perfect temperature to eat right away. I like to order mine with light noodles, extra broth and extra braised oh so tender and delicious pork belly. 

Today I tried the roasted chicken ramen bowl. Also very good! The chicken was tender and I really enjoyed all the added greens it came with. 

Other points of awesomeness:
1. You get a whole egg of perfection, vs the half egg at other places. 
2. Yummy spices to add on table
3. MANY DESSERT OPTIONS!! I've tried the brittle, green tea madelines, sake roll cake, and the miso cookies. There's more options too!

Price is fair ($12) for being a Michael Mina restaurant. Excellent food quality and taste. Happy belly for hours :)

5 stars because I haven't had a ramen fix like this in forever. Thanks Ramen Bar!
author: Kristine L.

description:
Expensive but very tasty. I'm vegetarian so the mushroom and tofu is the only option but adding egg is the way to go. This place will give ramen underground a run for its money especially since the space is much nicer and they accept credit card!

FYI I arrived at 1050am and was turned away until kitchen opens at 11. By 1058 there was a line out the door! Happily I waited around instead of going back the office.
author: Susheel D.

description:
Honestly, given all the mixed reviews, I wasn't expecting anything from Ramen bar. Actually, I was expecting to have a horrible experience. Since I came in with such low expectations, I was pleasantly surprised. Sure, there are some things that need improvement, but it was actually an alright bowl of ramen. (Well, if you don't take into account the actual ramen. We'll get to that a little later.)

When you enter Ramen bar, you place your order with the cashier. You're given a number and then you find your seat. Shortly after, a server brings by your bowl and the slurping begins!

I opted for the "Hokkaido" miso-butter chashu ramen ($14) which comes with braised pork, sweet corn and a soy-cured egg. I added Braised pork belly which was an additional $2. The bowl was nice and hot when it arrived. There isn't much chashu in the bowl so I'm glad I added the pork belly. Even though I got 2 small slices, it added enough extra protein for my hungry belly. The menu describes the broth as a "richer, bolder flavor", which I guess it was for miso broth. But I'm a huge fan of tonkotsu, so it was on the lighter side for me. The soy-cured egg however was cooked perfectly! The yolk had a nice consistency. My only issue with the ramen were the noodles. They were on the smaller side in terms of thickness (think spaghetti like noodles), so they didn't have that nice chewy consistency I love in ramen noodles. I'm not a big noodle eater anyways, but I normally have a couple of bites. I basically left almost all of my noodles in the bowl this time.

Service was fast and efficient. The server delivered my bowl of ramen with a smile and asked if I needed anything else. The cashier also made a point to tell me to keep the receipt until I got my food, so make sure to hang on to it until you get your ramen.

Maybe if I'm in the area again, I'll drop by to try their other ramens. But if I'm craving a nice comforting bowl of ramen (without the pretentiousness and high price tag), I'd probably hit another spot.
author: Elena N.

description:
Let's just say that I may as well have picked up a packet of Top Ramen at the local Walgreens. I ordered the Pork Belly Ramen. The noodles were like spaghetti, the broth was so damn boring and nasty - literally tasted like the beef flavored Top Ramen broth. I had to pour on some spicy powder to give it something. BLAH. Don't waste your time or money SF friends. Thank GOD I was first in line and didn't have to wait for this mediocre dish. 

Moreover, I was highly disappointed in the price to portion. I understand a Michael Mina restaurant is going to be expensive because you're paying for "quality," but come on. I ordered the pork belly WITH EXTRA $2.00 pork belly and I received two VERY THIN slices of pork belly. If you've been to Ramen Underground and have ordered the pork belly there, think about 1/2 of once piece of pork belly and that's what you get for the bowl plus $2.00 for extra pork belly. I'm really hoping they just forgot to add the extra that I paid for - which is still just as annoying. The egg was good though (1 star extra). 

Also, please tell your staff that if they are going to run around like chickens with their heads cut off, then they should watch out for peoples belongings. My purse was knocked off of my chair twice and the second time, the guy grabbed it and tossed it under my table. Are you kidding me? This is a very expensive LV purse. WTH.

Needless to say, I will not go back. Maybe the other bowls are better, but I'd rather have Ramen Underground or Ken Ken.
author: Noneya B.

description:
Wow!!  To start off this review.....I'd like to say I was lucky to have been invited to an event where The Ramen Bar was part of a sponsorship and contribution to the new Chinese Hospital Building.

At this event there were several vendors serving samples of some of their fabulous dishes.  I just happen to come across The Ramen Bar booth.  I was greeted by General Manager Anthony Kinn and he had allowed me to sample both Ramen that they were serving.

I first sampled the Tokyo Braised Pork Belly  (Bamboo, Wakame, Ajitsuke Tomago, Wilted Spinach and Negi.)

Very tasty and smooth.  The Ramen was done just right and the way I liked it.

The second sample was the:  Soy Mushroom (Yasai Miso, Greens and Mushrooms).

This one was tasty just as well....I think I like the Pork Belly one a little more only because of the Pork Belly.  The noodles was done right as well.  The broth had just the right amount of flavor (seasoning) in it.

Overall both samples were very good and I can't wait till the restaurant opens up.

The Ramen Bar
101 California Street
San Francisco, CA

Opening June 23, 2014 is the targeted date.

For the 2 samples I had.....it was awesome!!  

Thanks for the samples!!
author: Alan L.

description:
Is this the best ramen in town?  No, don't be silly.  But, is it the best ramen in the FiDi?  Probably, but it's because your options are limited!

A few years ago, I made the mistake of ordering duck ramen at Michael Mina (the restaurant up the way).  I left very angry at myself for letting my noodle addiction get the better of me, and compelling me to order ramen as my entree.  But, given my past history with ramen and Mr. Mina, I actually didn't have high hopes that The Ramen Bar would be any better even though Mr. Mina collaborated with a Japanese chef.  But, I digress.

At The Ramen Bar, I ordered the Chasu Miso-Butter Hokkaido.  It wasn't a disappointment like the duck ramen many years ago.  But, while this carboholic appreciates having noodles in the same building as my place of business, I'm not drooling up on the XXth floor for another bowl.

BTW skip the milk tea (eh, Quickly can make it better?!?!?).
author: Christina L.

description:
Overpriced, nondescript pseudo-Japanese bowl of noodles with a sickly-sweet aftertaste. The farthest thing from authentic ramen you can get :(

IMHO, not worth the money (even on an expense account). There are better options in SF; even more so if you are willing to venture outside the city!
author: Chris T.

description:
Best. Ramen. Downtown.  

I've been to a few hipster Ramen joints, and this one was definitely what I would consider a 'treat.'  Ya, it's expensive ($12 for their cheapest soup).  But it's also quite delicious.  I had the Tokyo-style ramen and the balance of flavors was perfect.  They didn't look like they were hurting for business since there was a line past 1:00 pm lunchtime....I'm definitely going back.
author: Angela I.

description: I was in the mood for something sushi-like today so decided to try the poke bowl here. I've tried poke bowls from all over town.  I got the trio bowl, which was pretty costly for what I received. Of course, they tried to fill most of the bowl with brown rice, then a layer of kale and lettuce and then a mixture of salmon, tuna, octopus, avocado and cucumber cubes.  I have never had poke cut so small before! Traditional poke is usually mostly fish and cut in large cubes.  Also, they skimped on the amount of poke with filler cucumber.  The taste of the fish was fine,  but I never got a full bit of fish. I'm always disappointed when places try to skimp on the main ingredient.  Maybe a single fish poke bowl is better but still not good value for a downtown lunch spot.
author: Heidi D.

description:
First off, if you're going to make me order a "Soy Cured Hen Egg" you better (1) cure the thing and (2) live up to the pretentiousness that comes with adding the word "Hen" to an egg. I mean seriously as opposed to what?

The ramen itself actually reminds me of the Hapa Ramen stand at the Ferry Building Farmers Market. Creative and quality ingredients but lacking the basic fundamentals. There's no choice in broth, so you will get something lukewarm, clear, and severely lacking in depth. The noodles just couldn't hold up to the broth and seemed more like spaghetti than ramen noodles. My egg was taken out a minute too soon and was definitely not "soy cured." I know ramen in San Francisco is not the greatest, but this isn't even good by SF standards. To top it off, you're paying a premium for beautiful decor and the name, but get nothing in return. 

The servers were very attentive and polite and the ambiance (outdoor patio) was great, but the ramen leaves much to be desired. This all bring me back to the point that a $12 bowl of ramen and a place that uses the term "hen egg" should be a lot better than this was.
author: Amanda B.

description:
I really liked this spot.  It's new, clean and perfect for the Financial District.  The price is a bit on the steep side, but it's what you should expect for the area as well as the quality of the product.

I had the Spicy Miso Chicken Ramen and I really enjoyed it.  I typically don't eat pork and, when most of the flavorful ramen out there has pork in it, it's a bit difficult to enjoy.  My ramen had a very flavorful broth with some nice, tender chicken pieces, well-cooked eggs, vegetables and a good portion of noodles - it was great.  They have a good size menu of ramen options so there's something for everyone.
author: Ken G.

description:
Let me start by saying I don't know a darn thing about ramen noodles outside of "Maruchan Ramen Noodle Soup".  So, get in the state of mind of someone who was not raised on noodles

I came here via a Yelp Elite event and partook in some items:

Crispy Miso Duck Wings-I couldn't get enough if the sweet delectable treats. I don't even cook duck, but it seriously had me considering purchasing some...

Shrimp & crab dumpling ramen-I get it's a big bowl and such, but not being raised on noodles I'm having a hard time wrapping my head around the price point. $17 for some soup!!!! Okay, now that's off my mind...it was soooooooooo darn yummy ALMOST every last drop. I would eat again (if someone else paid for it) minus the dumplings. I didn't quite like the consistency or the taste of the dumplings.

Sake roll cake-It was tasty, nothing really worth mentioning 
Green tea parfait-It wasn't to my liking plus it had too many crunchy things on top

Add-on:
-Price point very high for this
-I didn't want to put this, but...once dumplings hit stomach/I swallowed them I wanted to throw then back up. Was it the gooey (not in a good way) consistency or something about the ingredients? I don't know
-The desserts seemed like...what follows an afterthought? That's what they were to me...almost something they felt forced to add, but could do just, fine leaving them off the menu
author: Eboniña E.

description:
Third Mina restaurant in my history and I should have less and less expectations. As many have noticed with the massive crowd in Japantown for the Ramen Festival, nobody should mess around with ramen. It's serious business in the Bay Area. I've been wanting to try this place about a year ago, before all those constructions have started, before the ramen bar instagram was flooded with posts. I heard of the restaurant concept from friend of mine who is in the restaurant business. My god, I was so hyped up, I would round up any friends who were interested to countdown with me. 

Anyway, this is a casual spot. Service is mediocre, the place is spacious, casually modern atmosphere. You have a to go line up front and dine in eaters can be seated at tables outside, tables inside, bar seats on the inside. They have a few different types of ramen to choose from with some bold/flavorful broth and light broth, few types of donburi add ons for your ramen, alcohol and desserts. Pretty small menu in my opinion, they could have added some small dishes or appetizers. The regular sized ramen was arguably enough for one, its definitely enough if you finish the soup. 

Anyway, I went here with two others, we ordered a Hokkaido ramen, a spicy miso chicken, and a short rib donburi. None of us were impressed. Presentation was quite deceiving; as promising as the ramen had looked, taste was lacking. I thought they used food coloring in my broth. Maybe it was a certain style, but our broth was not as bold and flavorful as the menu had promised. Not even shichimi could save it. For mine, at least the buttered corn was plump and filled with the aroma of melted butter. My ramen smelled better than tasted. The noodles were daily chewy, probably the best part of it. I was expecting the meat to be a bit more soft and tender, perhaps its just too lean if not overcooked. I tasted a piece of the beef from the donburi, it's just all sad, too tough and too overwhelmed by the sauce. The ramen had better presentation that the donburi. 

With my personal preferences on thick broth, I would save my money to go to Yamadaya for a bit cheaper and more flavorful.

I'm so sorry, TRB, maybe I'll return when there's major improvements.
author: Connie C.

description: I ordered the chicken ginger ramen and the sunomono salad. Both of the dishes were subpar, the ramen was tasteless and the sunomono was salty. It's suppose to be sweet and citrusy. I know about sunomono cause I order it all the time at various Japanese restaurants. This place is in a great location but the quality isn't really that great.. I've had better.
author: Kissy F.

description:
This is the biggest disappointment by a famous chef I've encountered to date.
I ordered the mushroom & soy milk ramen.  It came out with cold greasy soup base + lumpy noodles, under cooked ingredients which includes the corn and pork belly.  

My friend and I sat by the bar area and actually observed how the line chefs put together the food.  They had no passion nor cared about the quality.  Everything was just slapped on.  A similar dish in any restaurant in J-town would had been done with pride, flavor to showcase the heritage of ramen.  

Michael Mina, for being a famous chef, the staff and flavor at the Ramen Bar was half a$$ed here and only relied on the name.  Utter disappointment and I'll not be coming back for a bowl of crappy $15+ ramen.
author: May W.

description:
Both times I ordered the $14 ramen with porkbelly and the vegetables for dinner. First time it tasted great. ...then, on the BART ride home, I felt Really Sick. 

Second time, I order the same thing for dinner. Weirdly,  this time there seems to be less ramen in the bowl, and the broth tasted too salty. I ate it. ...then, on the BART ride home, I once again felt Really Sick.

So yeah. Since I will not return to this place due to feeling Really Sick after the two times I visited, I must give it one star. (And I saw another review here about someone feeling sick too, so I guess it wasn't just me...)
author: C. D.

description:
Friday night dinner here wasn't the best. We expected a better experience considering it a Micheal Mina spot. The food was ok but not good enough to come back.
Totally disappointed. 
We dined in & got Hot Tea in a Togo cup. The pork bun was so dry it was breaking apart and salty 
The wings were ok
The ramen was nothing spectacular & the pork belly was over cooked & had no flavor. 
Totally bummer.
author: Mystie R.

description:
Light tasting broth, if you're used to the rich tonkatsu broth then your world is about to get rocked because this is totally different.  Overall it wasn't bad, but it also wasn't amazing either.  For maximum flavor and tastiness, do add corn, make sure you have an egg and add the stewed belly.  Don't get the shrimp and crap dumpling (totally not worth it).

They were a bit skimpy on the toppings and all the extras cost 2 bucks.  Definitely not worth it for the price, but if i'm just judging it based on taste then i'd have to say everything was mediocre.  If i were to factor in the price then.....lets not even go there.
author: Vince L.

description:
Food: salty. There is a diet where if you drink distilled water and salt, it flushes your system. Well this ramen was so salty that within 30m my system was flushed.
Service: the servers were so nice. It was only day 2 and they were still trying to work out the kinks. You could tell that everyone there really wanted the customer to have the best experience. The wait for food and the line was so long (naturally..it was day 2 and 12pm (lunch rush)) so they gave us complimentary dessert snacks to make up for it.
Price: $12 for mediocre ramen. I'll let you decide if that's worth it :/
author: Julianna I.

description:
Ambiance 5/5
The decor was beautiful. 

Cleanliness 3/5 
Some of the spices sat uncovered on the tables, exposed to the elements. 

Broth 2/5
Nothing really special about it. 

Noodles 1/5
Soggy. BLEH. 

Menu options 1/5
All the ramen really seemed the same. Maybe they should offer options to customize your ramen. 

Egg 0/5
I didn't particularly enjoy this sweet version of egg topping. 

Service 4/5
I don't think they could really mess that up because you order at a counter and they bring your food to you. You had to refill your own water. Whatever.
author: Laura L.

description: Good Ramen, great atmosphere, and awesome Sake on draft! Will definitely be back when I'm in the city.
author: Carlos M.

description:
One of the first things that comes to mind, simple clean flavors. The portion size was perfect for the ramen bowls. I felt that the ramen was a bit on the blandish side. that was defiantly not a big deal, there are plenty of ways to spice it up.

I have to say I have tried it all, almost everything they have to offer and it's all good!

I was lucky enough to attend a Yelp Elite Event here and I have to say, it's all great. I think I had an expectation due to some of the names involved in the venture. I was trying not to have huge expectations, I also am not going to lie ab out what I think about it. The ramen was lacking flavor. But the soft boiled egg in the ramen I had was one of the best I have ever had in my life. So its a mixed bag on the ramen itself. Everything else I got to try was great.   

The donburi is a great option and the salads are all loaded. The salads all have a delicate balance of flavor and ingredient portion ratio. This is I think what one should expect from a place like this, it defiantly delivers. The salmon salad was one of my favorite things along with the beef short rib donburi. The crispy miso duck wings are flavorful and absolutely amazing.

The best thing about this place, POWER LUNCH. Location and environment are perfect for such things.
author: Ben M.

description:
YUM! This was my first time trying "real ramen" so I'm well aware that there are probably some hole in the wall places that serve ramen that would top any restaurant in SF... I just haven't been there yet!

All in all I was very surprised to see that this restaurant only has 3 stars. It was PACKED (literally a line out the door in the SF rain) and the to go orders were piling in! The food was all being made to order and I had the hardest time choosing between ramen bowls. I went with the chasu bowl and enjoyed it a lot! So much flavor in the broth! The meat in the bowl was pretty fatty, but fit in with the soup over all.

The atmosphere is loud and busy but the staff seems to be organized and food comes out quick.
author: Kelsey T.

description:
My wife and I came here while on our honeymoon because we really wanted ramen, and we heard it was good. Certainly, the chef names attached to it carried some weight.

I ordered the shoyu tonkatsu ramen and a cocktail: an Original Lolita (which was hilariously creepy to order). The wife ordered the mushroom ramen. Being from Seattle, we've had a lot of good ramen, and we expect there to be one star of any ramen show: the noodles. Unfortunately, those were a huge disappointment. 

My shoyu broth was great. It was savory, meaty, and balanced, with a nice layer of fat on top. The pork belly was tender and delicious, and the soy-marinated egg was pretty decent. My wife's miso mushroom broth was bland and watery. It was pretty one-dimensional, and I had a hard time tasting the miso. Additionally, some of the mushrooms in her bowl were mush, and the spicy tofu she added was not spicy at all. She has no tolerance for spicy food, and even she thought it lacked heat. 

The cocktail appeared to be their Japanese twist on a Manhattan. It was whiskey, bitters, Okinawan sugar, and a yuzu rind twist. That got a staggered "meh". It was an interesting idea, but it really wasn't anything special without the herbal taste of sweet vermouth. It was just overly sweet. 

Sigh... let's talk noodles. To be totally frank, these were the worst noodles I have ever had in a ramen house. They had no tooth to them. They were mushy and floury. It was like slurping paste. I don't know if it was a freak thing, given some of the reviewers on here talking about the firmness of their noodles, but it was the case for both my wife and me. I choked mine down in order to get to the broth, but my wife never finished hers. We got a bite for her on the way back to our hotel. 

Really, there were some okay parts to the meal, but the noodles killed it for us both. They are the headliner, and how can you enjoy a show when the headliner sucks? Despite the good broth I had and pork belly, with three stars being average, the noodles, my wife's bland broth, so-so drink, and the noodles (Did I mention those?) drop this to a one star event. We will not be returning here on subsequent San Francisco trips.
author: Raffael P.

description:
FIRST AND FOREMOST:
I didn't actually go there. The Crab and Shrimp ramen was delivered to my office.

THAT SAID:
The trycaviar.com delivery far outclassed the meal. They got it to me from the Financial District to Pier 39 in about 40 mins, still warm and fresh.

BUT HOLY SALT BOMB:
The broth was not about subtle flavors of shoyu, miso or--as advertised--ginger/clam. Instead it was stunningly, overwhelmingly salty. Seriously, my grandchildren are gonna have high blood pressure just based on that one lunch. Local deer started following me around, treating me like a salt lick. If I added chicken and a couple carrots to my bath that night it would have turned into soup ... and salty soup at that.

WORSE:
The ramen itself seemed to be the packaged kind. C'mon ...

ON THE OTHER HAND:
The ingredients were pretty good. The seafood was fresh and abundant, veggies were crisp and the soy-flavored egg I added was very creamy and tasty. And (through trycaviar.com) I got a yummy fruit tea with the lunch.

IN BRIEF:
I love Japanese food in general, and this joint gets pretty good reviews. So it's pretty likely I'll try Ramen Bar out again. Probably onsite. But hey you chefs: Trust your ingredients and spare the salt.
author: Richard L.

description:
I work right across the street from this place so everyday I'm staring at the long lines starting at 11:30. Since there were such long lines, it has to be good.

In the evening, inside was pretty dim. The staff was super friendly with fast service.

I had the pork belly ramen and it smelled good. There were 3 small pieces of pork belly. Taste wise, broth wasn't very flavorful. It was a very mild to bland taste. Noodles were cooked well. Portion sizes are small for $12?! It's enough for a small eater like myself but I still want to get my money's worth. I guess I just expected more and got less...
author: Benita M.

description:
Being a ramen snob I knew I needed to try The Ramen Bar at some point. Since I work pretty near here and needed to grab lunch, this was a natural choice. The set up of this place is different from most ramen places that I've been to. You order at the counter and then grab a number and hope to find a seat. I was lucky and got a seat because I went before the lunch rush, but this place does get packed pretty quickly and my seat was poached really shortly after I left so there's definitely a crowd here.

I wasn't really sure what to order so I went with the recommendation of the cashier and got the ginger braised chicken. I was worried that the flavor might be too ginger strong and I'm not a ginger fan, but I was feeling a little ill so I really wanted a lighter broth and I was told that chicken was the way to go.

Food came out pretty quickly. Also self service water. I got my food in maybe less than 5 minutes or so? My take. I thought that the noodles here were really fantastic. They are on the firmer side but still very chewy. I do think they could be a bit more flavorful, but at the same time with a chicken soup, it may be harder to get he flavor into the noodles. They aren't thick noodles but I think are on the thicker side so I personally liked that. Soup is meh. Didn't really love it, but could have just been a pallet mismatch. I did think it was light which is what I wanted, which is good. But I do think the ginger overpowers the chicken flavor. I could barely taste the chicken and like I said, I don't love ginger. It wasn't overwhelming and i did think it was tolerable. The chicken was definitely on the dry side. The egg was really solid though, really want to call that out. The egg was perfectly flavored and you could tell it has definitely been marinated in something so that was awesome. Great texture and flavor so I loved that.

All in all, I love that the ramen here is unique and nontraditional, but it doesn't quite hit the spot for me.

tldr; decent nontraditional ramen. great noodles and egg. popular place for lunch, so get here early to avoid crowd and find seats!
author: Jasmine X.

description:
You order and pay at the front before you take your seat.

They have a water dispenser on the side where people can just go get it whenever they want.

Ramen is mediocre. There's just nothing outstanding about it, which is very disappointing considering its high price. A bowl of ramen can go be up to $15.

Unless you're filthy rich or bad with your money and like shitty ramen, this is the place for you.
author: Imma P.

description:
I had a pretty good ramen experience at the Ramen Bar today. I met a friend at 11:45 for lunch and we only waited about 15 minutes in line. The interior of the restaurant is really chic and I like the outdoor seating. It was pretty crowded so we sat inside. Once we sat down our order arrived within 5 minutes, which was a nice surprise. I ordered the spicy miso chicken ramen and my friend ordered the seared beef tataki salad. My friend's salad looked really good and she enjoyed it. There was a ton of rare beef and fresh greens. 

I really enjoyed my ramen. I thought it was a big portion and had a LOT of stuff on it: tons of chicken, corn, and bamboo. And the egg was so good. I did, however, leave thinking "pretty good ramen" instead of the "WOW RAMEN" experience I hoping for. The broth and noodles were satisfying, but it definitely wasn't spicy, and could have used more flavor (salt/MSG/soy sauce?). My ramen came to about $15.50 with tax, which is a lot more than I typically spend on lunch. But I do understand that it's an upscale place catering to FiDi business-people who can probably eat out every day for around $20. 

I'm not sure I would go back, but it's definitely worth checking out!
author: Regina L.

description: Great spot to get away from the days grind for a quick lunch away from the office.  I always get the Shoyu Tonkatsu, and it's great!
author: Jai V.

description: This place has a great ramen. But it's noisy as all heck, It's a closed a lot for "special events", and they will only let you have take out the last 30 minutes. No dine-in. So, in effect, it's not really open until 9pm, unless you have someplace else to eat a big bowl of Ramen at 8:30 pm at night.
author: Grace C.

description:
I saw that they had a mushroom ramen, so I stopped by for dinner one night with my co-worker. The waitress told me (without a shred of remorse or apology) that their mushroom ramen contains butter. Butter?! What a strange addition. I guess I figured ramen to be a broth-based Japanese dish.

The only vegan item, according to our rude waitress, was the salad. So I went with it. No big deal, I love me some leafy greens. 

When it arrived, it looked beautiful. Lots of vibrant color on top. Once I started to dig in, I noticed that it was completely soaked in dressing. All of the pieces on the bottom were wilted. I could only eat about half. The tofu on top was pretty tasty, but I wanted more than three pieces, especially to make up for the poor quality of the greenery.

I left feeling hungry and very displeased. Our waitress never asked how my food was, but she asked my dining companion several times. I haven't gotten such snobby service in a long time. 

I guess vegans are not welcome here. I won't make the same mistake twice.
author: Brandi W.

description:
so i really really wanted to like this place, but alas, this is not delicious ramen.

my parents are visiting from shanghai and staying at the hyatt, which is conveniently one block away.  it was raining and we wanted a quick bite, so decided to come to ramen bar.  was a thursday, and apparently there are happy hour deals on thursdays until 9 pm, so there was a big crowd. we settled in at the bar, which was fine, as we got a good view of the ramen action..

started off with the pork belly buns..mmm, 2 stars max. it wasnt great pork to bun ration, and the bun was stiff and hard! no bueno!  my parents and i had one bowl of ramen each, and...well...it was just salty, but there is no depth of flavor to the broth! not okay! meep! 

plus $14 for a bowl of ramen and $2 for any add-ons is kinda excessive! sad face.

sigh, oh well, im trying pabu next, and hopefully that will be better!
author: Christina L.

description:
Came here a bit early to escape the lunch rush and definitely glad I did. By the time our ramen came out around noon, the line was out the door and people were hovering around looking for an open table.

Though I'm not a ramen expert, I have to say there was nothing wrong with my bowl besides that I would have preferred more meat. 

Service here was great for my table also. Everyone was friendly that we talked to, and the GM even stopped by our table a few times to make sure everything was great. Definitely would come back again!
author: Nancy T.

description:
Great interior, service, space. The ramen wasn't my favorite ever. It is explained as Tokyo style ramen, which has a light broth. No problem! I had the roasted pork, which I had hoped would be a little more savory. It's very subtly sweet, lighter in texture and feel and .. Gentle.. Is the only way I can think to describe it. Maybe I've stuck with tonkotsu for so long (sorry if I spelled it wrong!) that I'm used to a very deep, rich flavor. Even so, i wish it were a bit less sweet!

My husband had the roasted chicken which I liked a lot more. The broth is simultaneously citrusy and a bit fishy. I thought it was really good. 

They both had really tender, melt in your mouth roasted meat. And the eggs were perfectly soft cooked (also slightly sweet). 

There were different noodles in each, both had the same texture to me - slightly chewy- and slightly different flavor. Overall the roasted chicken was my favorite, but be warned of the citrus/fish hints!

We also ordered the BBQ pork buns which I didn't like at all. The BBQ pork belly was too hard. Not a lot of flavor.
author: Jacqueline O.

description:
All wrong. This is not how ramen should be sold, prepared, consumed and the price you pay for it is not even worth the visit. 

The noodles were overcooked and too small of portions. The kurobata pork had no flavor for the extra price point. The shoyu base was bland, it needed salt...and it's shoyu based....which translate to English, SOY SAUCE. $2 to add corn was ridiculous. The Chasu bowl was marginally better, but overcooked noodle pretty much ruined it. The tables were too small to hunker down and use your elbows to consume your bowl, with a giant storage box of napkins, chopsticks and wonton spoons taking over the space. 

At least they had Kirin on tap. And copious amounts of hot sauce. Our waiter was also very on point, friendly.

I've lived in Japan for almost a year and consumed some of the greatest bowls of ramen you can come by and have found many close to good rivals in the Bay Area. Ramen is not meant to be a high-end luxury experience. It's ramen. You go and sit down in a tiny spot, cram yourself in a chair, post up your elbows, get broth all over your face, sweat because there is no air-conditioning and the kitchen steam for noodle overpowers, let your nose run and slurp in happiness. 

None of this happens at Ramen Bar. If you're really craving ramen for lunch and you work in the area, get it to go and build your own ramen-ya experience at your work desk if you must. Otherwise, save it for San Mateo, Japantown or any other hole-in-the-wall in the area you can stumble upon.
author: Alita M.

description: Had been wanting to try this place since it first opened, but never got around to it. I'm glad I made it out! The chicken miso ramen is pricier than some places in the area, but the broth was rich and flavorful! The staff were attentive and friendly and knowledgeable about the various flavors and broths. Will definitely be back!
author: Vinitha R.

description:
I love the chicken & avocado bowl rice !
I come almost every week and I'm always satisfied. Great service !
author: Charline D.

description:
I must say I had pretty low expectations for the Ramen Bar after reading all of the meh reviews. But considering how close it is to my office, I had to give it a shot.

Here's a run-down of my experience:

--customer service: 5 stars; all servers and cashiers were extremely warm and helpful-from the moment I walked through the doors, I felt welcomed.

--structure: 5 stars; quick-moving line, easy ordering, ample seating; not to mention, far cleaner than your average ramen shop

--food: 3; while better than I anticipated, this $16 bowl of ramen is not quite where it should be. I ordered the braised pork belly miso ramen. The broth was flavorful and the soft-boiled egg was delicious. But the noodles were subpar and too over-cooked. Overall though, I was pleased with the composition and quantity- I'll definitely have enough for two lunches! 

Soooo..regardless of the good/average ramen, I would give Ramen Bar another shot based on their great service and comfortable atmosphere. I am a frequenter of Ramen Underground. and this was a far quicker, more comfortable experience.

If you're willing to throw down a little more than you usually would for a pipin hot bowl of ramen in a clean/cool space, give Ramen Bar a shot!
author: Rachel L.

description:
I ordered a latte. They have really good espresso to go.

Nobody made the latte. In fact the barista made a huge show of pulling two shots about 5 minutes after I ordered the latte, then he and the guy who took my order started drinking them. 

I was standing there the whole time. I'm not exactly sure how they forgot about me, there was literally no one else there. I even tipped when I paid, guess I should have waited.

Once I asked if my drink was still coming, they hurriedly tried to blame each other, dashed off the latte surprisingly inexpertly (scalded milk poured onto the counter) considering how much flourish had gone into the previous shots, and offered me a free wakame salad or dessert from the case. But I just wanted my afternoon latte. Besides, you aren't supposed to take bribes to improve your Yelp review.
author: Scott L.

description:
Great place for lunch in downtown San Francisco.  If you have time, I suggest eating in rather than taking away.  Try to get there before noon or you'll find yourself in a long line.  Fortunately they have a quick turnover and there are typically seats at the bar.

This can run a bit pricey for lunch, ramen (with tax) will run about $12-16 and don't forget the tea (another $4-6) or other sides.  That being said, you'll be quite full after a bowl of their ramen.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Nice location and decoration. The Raman was not so great. Spending time in Japan I know the true taste. Perhaps my expectations were too high.

Good Americanized version of ramen. I will keep searching for a better place!
author: Marc W.

description: For the Fidi area, this ramen is decent. There's usually a long wait, so I make reservations. My first time here was not too good, but it has gotten better. On my 3rd time (yesterday) it was with my work team to for lunch. I made a reservation for 8 people at 12pm and when I arrived to tell the host, he said we were 30 minutes late for a party of 10 that was reserved at 11:30am - they clearly had some misunderstanding on their end, but they were accommodating enough to create a table for us. I had the Hokkaido ramen and the matcha boba - the Hokkaido ramen is a little spicy and has the choice of pork or chicken, I opted in for pork. The pork was too thick and fatty, but it was flavorful. The arugula in the ramen is not the traditional way, but it didn't bother me too much. I always love the extra chili powder on my ramen for extra taste, and if your broth needs more flavor, they have the spicy paste too. My matcha boba was better on my 2nd try here, but this 3rd time it was very diluted and doesn't taste like authentic matcha. Egg was perfect in the ramen and lots of noodles which was generous, however it is a $15 bowl of ramen. Will return when I am craving ramen, but there are better ones out there.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Day 2, and it's obvious they need to work out the kinks:

2 doors in, but no clear path to go (do we wait to be seated; do we order at the counter, then sit; if we do order at the counter, which register applies /signs are posted, but it was like a free for all).

Shrimp with crab dumpling in ginger broth with honey soy marinated egg, wakame, sweet corn and mizuna. $18.  Was it worth it?  The crab dumpling was tasty, and the egg is worth the $2 add on cost.  However, the basis of an excellent ramen, broth and noodles, really brought the bowl down to 2.5 stars.  The ginger broth was salty, and the noodles, were too al dente for me.  I must note though, that i had food envy of my friends' bowl of pork belly ramen, that looked amazing, with the good size portion of pork belly. 

Service was attentive.  Cashier not so much. Our group of 3, split the bill with cash and credit card.  The server understood what we wanted to do.  But the cashier told our server, we were short.  No, count again. After the second attempt, server comes back to tell us, we are experiencing technical issues with our credit card machine, and had wanted my friend to sign the total receipt as the credit card receipt.  Not acceptable.   Eventually, help came from the floor manager, as she comped our meal.

I'll give them another shot, but I'll wait, and I'm definitely going to try the pork belly ramen.
author: Marj P.

description:
Decent ramen. A good amount in the bowl, but the overall portion was small. I ordred the spicy miso chicken, and added pork belly into it because I saw the sizes of everyone else's bowls and knew it'd be too small. The soup base was good; I added some ichimi to put in some more spice. The bowl itself came with egg, nori, corn, spinach, and mizuna leaves. I was satisfied with the contents of the bowl, and the noodles were excellent. The meat was so-so; the chicken was very tender but hard to find in the midst of the noodles, and the extra $2 pork belly was honestly two of the smallest kakuni pieces I've ever seen.

Aside from the meat, why am I unsatisfied? The price. This bowl (adding the pork belly) cost $16, which is ridiculous for someone who lived in West LA & Little Tokyo for 5 years, but for its FiDi location I guess that's just what has to be done. I probably won't come back because of the price; if this was a $10 bowl I'd be back pretty often.
author: Ryan D.

description:
So I'm wavering between four or three stars. 

Why the three? Because both me and my coworker felt the broth was too salty! I even added water to dilute mine and it still wasn't something I wanted to drink. Disappointing. The pork belly itself, the egg, and the veggies were perfect, but the broth just tasted like soy sauce. I don't know where other reviewers got "light". I prefer Ajisen's broth over this!  I am really hoping it was just a fluke.

The line was long but moved okay. At about 11:30 we were in the line and had our food by about 12.  There is seating inside but it's really loud in there. The seating outside looked better which was convenient. The service was good and the overall atmosphere of the place was modern, clean, new.  Prices are fair. 

But the broth! Meh...another reviewer said "one-dimensional" which sums it up well.
author: Esther S.

description:
2.5 - not impressed with this place at all. Went here tonight with a coworker and was looking forward to trying this place. Store and ambience wise its a clean cut casual ramen bar. We got there around 6:15ish and wasn't that busy at all. They have indoor and outdoor seating. you order at the bar and they give you a number and bring the food out to you. They made the dessert in bulk as well as th ebubble tea it appears which is a downside i think. also its pricey for some milk tea too over $4 so you might as well go over to Plenta

I got the Salmon salad sans noodles for $12. Smaller portion and decent amount of salmon but not worth $12. You can get much more at Buckhorn grill. The salmon was soft but I thought it was a overly salty. Otherwise the salad is just mixed greens with a few super slim slices of veggies such as radish and carrots. nothing super special

My friend got the pork belly miso ramen which she wasn't very impressed. I tried the broth which i thought was EXTREMELY oily. She said noodles were a good consistency soft but crunchy but the broth was not impressed. The pork belly was kinda tough as well. Egg was poached nicely though
author: Tao Tao W.

description: Casual dining within the financial district of San Francisco. It is less than 5 minutes walking distance from the Hyatt Regency. The restaurant is small but cozy. You place your order at the counter and they will deliver it to your table. Service is fast and waitstaff is friendly. They welcome questions about their menu and are eager to give out recommendations. They have a good selection of fruit teas. I tried their golden nectar which I found refreshing with it's sweet and citrusy taste. I had their Tokyo style ramen with the pork belly and soy-cured egg. A little bit salty for my taste but my friend enjoyed her shrimp and crab ramen. The seaweed salad with the ginger-sesame dressing helped neutralize that salty taste. They have a lot more on their menu that I'm interested to try. For now, I'd give it 3-stars with Silverlake Ramen as my reference point.
author: Luzcel T.

description: Not the best ramen I've had but also not the worse. Broth isn't as rich as I would like but it definitely has good flavors. It is a bit pricey but if I'm craving ramen close to work, I'd probably stop by here. The line is always long but it moves fast. If you sit by the counter, you can see how quickly the procession line goes: noodles, pork belly, toppings, broth, egg, delivery.
author: Thao T.

description: Good for San Francisco but... that's not saying much. The ramen here is overpriced and pretty mediocre. It's definitely not worth paying $10 for this.
