I got the Tokyo ramen with shoyu tare, chashu, wakame, mizuna, soy-cured egg, green onion, bamboo, and nori. The broth was okay, but nothing special. The noodles were al dente and didn't have a chewy consistency that I love about ramen noodles. The biggest no-no for me was the nori. I can't believe the nori was placed so far down the bowl that it was soggy? This is like ramen 101. The nori should only be dipped in half-way so you can enjoy both the soggy and crispiness of the nori. The best thing may have been the soy-cured egg but the consistency of the yolk wasn't perfect.
author: Hana K.

description:
There's a new menu as of last week! 

I'll confess that I don't actually eat the ramen here and I don't even know what makes good ramen, but I was a big fan of the old Donburri and now I am loving the rice bowls. The chicken and avocado rice bowl is different, fresh, and a good size to fill me up and save some for later. My most favorite things about The Ramen Bar are the boba milk teas and the red spicy sauce on the tables - I put it on everything and you should too. The only reason I even considered docking one star is because it is pretty darn expensive, but I really love it anyway.  Try it out!
author: Noelle F.

description:
More like 2.5 stars....
It's OK, but nothing special, and certainly not worth the top dollar they charge.
I had the Tokyo ramen. The broth was too salty and the noodles not quite as springy as I like them. I think you can find better ramen at cheaper prices at several other places.
author: Ken P.

description: Service was exemplary. Waiter was really cool. Had the Tokyo ramen, not bad. Pork was a little dry. Had the gyoza. That was pretty good but the sauce was kind of odd. I'm a little more used to a vinegar sauce not sure what they used in it. Overall a good experience.  It was a little dark, but I guess it is a "bar".
author: Rob F.

description: I went here twice with my uncle and my boyfriend. The first time, my uncle had the ramen and had diarrhea and felt sick like he had the flu for the rest of the entire day. A few months later, I went back with my uncle in order to eat the poke (because my uncle liked the poke before and he was fine). Well, we should have learned our lesson. My uncle went away with diarrhea three times that afternoon. I had the poke also, but I had the gluten and dairy free version and seem to have escaped unscathed. I have a feeling the fact that I was ok both times with the gluten/dairy free option means there is something weird with their regular sauces. Diners, beware! We so wanted to like them too...
author: Fin D.

description:
This is legitimately a pretty average place. The ramen's not bad, but it's also nothing too special. This place would be a good occasional stop for lunch or dinner but I wouldn't come here for any special reason.

I got the Tokyo style ramen, which was decent.
author: Alex Z.

description: The ramen is fine, but it's nothing exciting and it sure it pricy if you add meat. This restaurant is the definition of a yelp 3-star place in that I'm not opposed to eating here if others want to, but I'm probably not coming here myself unless there's unique circumstances (i.e. it's raining and Ramen Bar is in my office building).
author: Cynthia S.

description:
Great addition to the FiDi. Friendly staff and large, attractive restaurant space. Don't be intimidated by the long line out the door as service is amazingly quick -- perfect during the work day.

Now onto the food. We ordered a bowl of the pork belly shoyu ramen and the mushroom and soy ramen with pork belly added. Both were beautifully presented with yummy, chewy noodles. I'm not sure how the sweet corn shows up in the mushroom and soy ramen or if my bowl was missing it? We also ordered the marinated chicken salad with a half serving of noodles (since we were already eating noodles in our ramen). The salad was fresh and flavorful, whereas we found the broth in both our bowls of ramen to be rather bland as compared to ramen we've eaten elsewhere.

I definitely would return to try out other dishes. I'm also hoping that we'll soon find the broth to be amazing. Can't wait to eat a hot bowl of ramen during the cooler winter months!
author: Kim N.

description:
This place was AIITTTEEE!! Not a bad location, but it was definitely a let down for being a Michael Mina resto.. :(

I ordered the tonkatsu ramen..and the broth was on the salty side. I wasn't terrible impressed..but it wasn't horrible. Maybe it was just a result of expecting amazeball food cuz of the brand. :\ Read: Manage your expectations!

I would probably still default to Ramen Underground for some FiDi Ramen...only because it isn't as salty, closer to where I work, and next to a boba spot. Shrugs.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Really disappointed that their ramen has digressed in taste from when I first ate ramen here, and has been awhile since last year in the fall of 2015. I was looking forward to a great bowl of ramen and ordered the ginger chicken ramen for pick up.  When we sat down to eat in the office, an elevator ride up in the same building, the soup was next to cold and  I could not taste nor smell any ounce, grain of ginger to save my life! The chicken was bland and the accompanying greens were skimpy; the eggs looked better than they tasted. To top it off, the noodles tried to infuse ginger, but they were al dente and the only taste derived from the whole bowl was a tart lemon taste.  Shall I come back for another chance; maybe for the rice bowls which I was pleased with and another type of ramen.  The ginger chicken ramen, should be renamed lemon chicken ramen, is a clear thumbs down.
On the upside, the place has a nice layout and ambiance with outdoor seating.
author: Liz H.

description: Quality food costs a little bit more but you get what you pay for.  Come here for a flavorful, clean and well executed bowl of ramen. There are other items on the menu worth a try like the poke bowl or the udon. After you are finished, head next door to Pabu for a night cap.
author: Hannah A.

description:
If you are looking for fast and healthy lunch/dinner and don't wanna spend a fortune come by to The Ramen Bar.

I came here after 10 hour long flight from London and must say ramen woke me up. The quality is good: you get a bowl with tasty broth and meat, fermented egg and of course noodles. I went for Ginger chicken that sets you for $12. Along with this bubble tea (unfortunately without fully covered lid) hot or cold with your own choice of milk. I chose Almond Milk and it was excellent - sweet but not too sweet.

The interior is very pleasant and the space gives ambience and is quite comfortable to talk there. Overall pretty impressive evening hence high score!
author: Tom D.

description:
Came to satisfy a ramen craving. Dining room pretty empty so I figured it was be a quick, simple experience. Ordered a Hokkaido ramen with extra soy cured egg and pork belly. Wanted something refreshing to drink so I got the Oolong Lychee drink.

Ramen arrived and I was off to the races. Midway however I was getting pretty thirsty. I went up to the bar and inquired about my drink - "still in the works." With no other solution offered, I requested a glass of water to hold me over.

Meal finished and signaling for the check - still no drink. I asked the waitress about it and she went and got it. She explained they were backed up.

I understand having a queue to make drinks but my ramen (unless it's pre-prepared) was put together assumedly among other orders. 

Ordering a drink at arrival and receiving it post-meal is unacceptable. Providing an excuse for that and still charging some for it is equally unacceptable.

Yes, my saltiness may have stemmed from the ramen, but don't leave a thirsty customer hanging.
author: Chris T.

description:
Came by after an interview because they opened at 10:30. Ordered a tonkotsu ramen and oolong milk tea.

The oolong milk tea came first and even though it wasn't too sweet, there was this lingering taste on my tongue which to me seems like they use some sort of non dairy milk. Overall regular milk tea, nothing special.

The tonkotsu ramen:$16 a little more expensive then I would like.
Ramen: noodles were too hard for me. I prefer softer noodles
Broth: the soup was pretty flavorful but a little oily
Pork: could be a little more tender but juicy and tasty
Egg: the egg might have been my favorite part (along with the first sips of broth)

Overall not bad but for $20 for one bowl of ramen and a drink ($23 after tip), I expected better.
author: Wilson T.

description:
I can't believe I haven't had a proper Ramen meal that was not from an instant noodle package. 

Thank goodness for friends who like Ramen and that suggested we find one immediately following happy hour. I didn't expect to completely clean the entire bowl. The only downside is that it was a bit salty, so at the next drink spot I couldn't stop drinking water.
author: Moua L.

description: Cozy space. I started with the deviled eggs and strawberry mule cocktail. Really tasty. My crab ramen was delicious and flavorful . I like sitting at counters and was very comfortable there. Shelby was our friendly waitress and was excellent. The service was great and the space was really cozy.
author: Cecilia D.

description: Had to try The Ramen Bar because my sister kept raving about this Ramen Bar. When i tried this bar the experience was very good. Decadent Ramen, Delicious and cold refreshing drink and great service. Specially the Tokyo style  pork ramen. Can not wait to come back.
author: Paige C.

description: If you are in the Financial District, this is the best ramen you will find. It has a flavourful broth, good noodles and ample toppings. Authentic Tokyo style ramen at a decent price. Service is great too and they have an easy online ordering site. Great ambiance. Check it out!
author: Chantee F.

description:
I wanted to try a different ramen place other than Ramen Underground for a change, so we decided to go to the Ramen Bar. There was a long line to get in at the lunch hour.  So far so good!  Seemed like a great place to get ramen. 

I ordered the mushroom and soy ramen with some wakame (as an additional topping). First impression was that the ramen was ok. Nothing spectacular or distinctive, but just ok. The broth was a bit thicker than the broth you get at Ramen Underground, but it was not in the same class though. I added some chilli paste to add some kick to my ramen. 

The service was great and the decor was good (that's why I gave them 3 stars). It was not as cramped as Ramen Underground and you could actually have lunch in a big group. They also give you a punch card, which you can use to get the 10th bowl of ramen for free. 

Would I be back?  Probably. The service was good, so that will get me back. Maybe these guys had an off-day today. So I will be back one more time to see if they stack up to the competition.
author: Gopal R.

description: Finally, a place open past 4 pm in the financial district. I'm a fan of the food here. I've tried the ramen and curry rice here, and both taste delicious. The only thing is the ramen can be super oily.
author: Vivian W.

description:
I actually like the ramen here as it's tasty and you can build your own. The ambiance is nice and they are never too crowded. 

The servers are nice but somewhat out of it. Every time I've been to the Ramen Bar, they insist on delivering me food items I didn't order. I've had to tell them that I didn't order this particular food item at least twice per visit. Overall, nice ambiance, good decent food. I can't complain!
author: Portia G.

description: Hands down. This has been the best Ramen soup experience so far. I thoroughly enjoyed the Shoy Tonkotsu.  With scallion, mizuna, soy cured bamboo shoots, walame and nori. It has the best pork broth ever!!! It comes with shot tare, pork belly, beni shoga, cabbage, and soy-cured egg. I wanted to devour my entire bowl it waa that tasty. I will definitely go back whenever I am in San Francisco. Moreover, the teas here are exceptional. I ordered the lychee oolong and the flavors of the tea are truly amazing.
author: Mary A.

description:
I have been excited to try this place since I love eating ramen and a Michael Minna restaurant. You order food at the cashier and they bring it the table you choose - cafeteria style. The cashier recommended the Tokyo style Kurobata ramen $12 because they are known for the light broth.  The broth was plain, light, but tasty and came with thin slices of pork.  The price is a little steep for a bowl of ramen but there's not many ramen options around the  FiDi area and it's pretty good.  

Line was long but food came quickly, great for work lunch.  I would come back when craving ramen near downtown.
author: Yolanda G.

description:
i skimmed the reviews before being dragged here, and now finally, fully understand the term, "haters gonna hate". 

Ramen Bar is straight-up excellent! There are not many decent bowls of ramen to be had in this city, and while there are a couple recently openened shops I haven't tried, this was the best ramen I've had within city limits. We were probably wise to arrive after the lunch rush, because our order was out in under five minutes, piping hot and picture-perfect. I don't know how they cook the eggs so superbly, but the ovum alone was worth my (boss's) twelve bucks. The pork was sublime, the broth enchanting, and the rest of what lurked in the murky depths of my bowl was a delight. Staff were friendly and helpful, the space is well appointed, and I'm really at a loss for something to critique. 

This could be habit-forming.
author: Quinn S.

description:
I was curious as to what magic Michael Mina was able to do with ramen. Unfortunately my expectations may have been too high ad I felt a bit underwhelmed. 

Gyoza - Nothing too special about this one. 

Crispy miso duck wings - The wings were a bit dry, however the flavor and crispiness made the dish worth ordering. Besides, I think this was the first time I ever saw duck wings on a menu! 

Tokyo style ramen with pork belly -
   the good - the size of the order is good for the price. The chasu was larger then usual and the pork belly was tender. The cured egg was done well (even though it was a bit saltier then I would have liked). 
  the bad - The broth was only ok and the noodles didn't have enough chew/bounce to it. I have had better ramen in the city, and that is saying a lot since there aren't too many around. 

Overall thoughts : It is worth the trip if you are craving a hot bowl of ramen without the crazy lines. Otherwise there are better options around town.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I really want to like Ramen Bar but there's just something off about it.  Noodles are okay, but taste a bit mild.  The shoyu broth is way too sweet for me and lacks depth.  The chashu was quite thin and lean so there wasn't much flavor.  Without stating the obvious, this ramen tastes and looks like a really good chef's interpretation of ramen.  It lacks soul, however and just isn't satisfying.  Too bad, as I really like Michael Mina. 

I recognize that there really aren't any rules with ramen (unlike Soba), but this was a very shallow ramen.  With all the new alternatives in FiDi, it's going to be tough for Ramen Bar.  That said, I like a more blue collar style of ramen.  There may be an audience for this lighter, California-ized fare that's more style over substance.
author: Kenneth N.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend for dinner after work.

We ordered:
- Spicy miso-butter Hokkaido ramen ($14)
- A side of pork belly ($2)
- Spicy chicken ramen (special) ($14)

Taste:
I ordered the spicy miso-butter Hokkaido ramen and it was quite rich in taste. It was pretty good and very different from your typical traditional Japanese ramen. After a couple more bites, it got a little too rich and heavy.

My boyfriend ordered the spicy chicken ramen and thought it was pretty bland. It just didn't taste right.

Waiting time:
It took about half an hour for our food to come out because they were bagging up some Caviar orders. I don't think this should be an excuse for dine-in customers.

Price:
$14 is a bit hefty for a bowl of ramen and, if you order some pork belly on the side, that'll make your bowl of ramen $16. I understand this is one of Michael Mina's restaurants, so I wouldn't expect anything less than that, but it is still on the pricier side.

Verdict:
If you're looking for a non-traditional ramen spot, this is the one. If you are, steer away from this place.
author: Denise K.

description: Great lunch spot, good ramen, line moves fast, nice seating area indoors and out. What's not to love.
author: Lane L.

description: Worst service ever. We placed an order on Caviar. The order was missing some of the items. We called the restaurant and requested a refund of the entire order, since eating only the items we received greatly diminishes the enjoyment of the entire meal. The manager refused. The food we did receive was cold and unenjoyable.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
The Ramen (pork belly) is quite good.  But portions are kind of small compared to the price (kind of large).  I have always enjoyed the food and the outside seating is great for people watching.

Make sure to order the egg with your ramen.  It's a nice addition (worth the buck, buck fifty)

And the HongKong milk tea (ask for boba) is yummy.
author: Edward M.

description: Meh... heavy on the peanut/sesame flavor for NY dish ... however, I would give the boiled egg 5 stars and could have eaten 10 of those.
author: Shanna S.

description:
10% better than the top ramen you can get at safeway, literally 14,000% more expensive.

pros:  sleek decor, fast efficient service, seemingly high quality ingredients

cons: $14 frikkin dollars for Ramen at lunch time with no drink or extras.  Mediocre flavor.
author: james b.

description: The salt broth was flavorful but not overwhelming - the best part of the meal! I also liked the variety of drinks available, and enjoyed the dark asahi. Was not a huge fan of the pork (cut too thick and a bit too fatty) and overall I'd give the food a 3.5 if you're not extremely picky about your ramen. I bumped it up to a four for the convenient location (by Bart and muni), great service, and good environment (not too loud or crowded, clean, with outdoor seating option).
author: Alison S.

description: Tokyo ramen is well made and served with tender pork belly and soft boiled soy egg. It comes with a lot of noodles. Soft shell crab was ok.
author: Tina C.

description: My friend and I had a huge ramen craving, so he took me here. It's a cute little place with indoor and patio seating. I tried one of their most popular dishes, the chasu miso-butter hokkaido ramen ($14) which has perfectly tender meat, a whole egg, some corn, and seaweed. It was actually pretty good -- not too salty and not too skimpy on the ingredients. The spices on the condiment rack are good too, and I needed them to make my ramen spicier. The only downside is that $14 is more than I would like to pay for a good bowl of ramen, but it IS Financial District so I shouldn't be surprised. Overall great place to satisfy your ramen craving if it's conveniently nearby!
author: Stefanie C.

description: The place is unique since you can watch the chefs make Ramen but taste is average. Would i go again probably not.
author: Pooh O.

description:
This is my first bowl of ramen since coming back from Tokyo and this place made me vow to never eat ramen again in the Bay Area. Every ramen place I've tried in the US has been disappointing (except maybe one place in LA). I still don't understand the craze about ramen here--it is the cheapest, most accessible, most casual fast food you can get in Japan and somehow it's become a delicacy here in the US. Mind blown.

ANYHOW, soup was lukewarm and overly salty. Egg was just a simple boiled egg, not the ramen egg with the soft yolk. Noodles were undercooked. They used nori that looked like it was bought from the dollar store. One slice of bland chasu which tasted like it was just boiled with plain water. Small portions. Bad presentation (everything was sloppily thrown together in a bowl and lacked color). Expensive (came out to $15 including tax). 

For the price of 100 bowls of ramen at Ramen Bar, you can save up for an airplane ticket to Japan and experience "real" ramen, for half the price of a bowl. That I will do.
author: Cheri S.

description:
Highlights
- Chasu Miso-Butter Hokkaido: It's all about the broth here. Not your typical Japanese broth, but an Asian fusion version with a little kick, rich bold flavor, and plenty of saltiness to make you thirsty for more and some milk tea to wash it down. Love that it includes corn and a soy-cured egg. 
- Agedashi Tofu Salad: Mixed greens, fall vegetables, kaiware, and
yuzu vinaigrette with crispy tofu, eringi mushrooms, asparagus, radish,
carrots, and cucumbers. I like that they have the option to add chilled noodles or more greens for $2.00 more. Add the noodles it will make it taste better and more hearty. A nice and light alternative if you are not feeling a pipping hot bowl of ramen. 
- Matcha Green Milk Tea: Strong and bold tea flavor. Delicious and thirst quenching after accompanying one of their bowls of ramen. 
- Milk Bread: If this is laying around near the register, get it! It's the cutest and most delicious offering! A mini individual sized loaf of milk bread that you can break into 3 pieces and it is accompanied by cream and two other berry flavored jams. 

Improvements
- There is always a line out the door during lunch time, but luckily it goes by quickly and the seating area looks crowded but clears up by the time you finish paying. 
- Pricey for a bowl of ramen and adding anything additional will set you back $2.00 each, but what do you expect in the Financial District? Probably not something I would go out of my way for unless I'm around the area. 

Tips
- Download their app and order before you head there for pick-up if you are in a rush.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Ehhh, I've had ramen from The Ramen Bar (TRB) twice. Once was when the company I was working for at the time, ordered TRB for our weekly lunches. It was ok, but honestly, everyone's tastebuds were probably off since it was the day right after our holiday party. I decided to give it another shot when I was craving ramen for lunch. Anyway, despite being famished, I did not find TRB's ramen to be particularly good. Is it because I'm Asian and grew up eating various ramen/noodles my whole life? I don't know. But all I know is that what I ordered was not worth $15. The broth wasn't anything special and the texture of the noodles were a bit off. Honestly, there's way better ramen places in SF/the Bay Area. I think the best part of the experience was funny/flirtatious staff. I've never heard someone attempt this "joke" before, but the cashier that day asked if I had an aunt, when I responded yes, he continued by saying "Does your aunt go around saying, 'This is my niece, Denise?' " Haha, good try, thanks for the chuckle. 

Before I forget-- I must add that I did catch a glimpse of something interesting, I think I saw the words "alcoholic boba" at the bar area. If I'm wrong, I must be delusional or I was having such a tough day that my brain was trying to cheer me up with words that I generally like. I've tried alcoholic boba once in my life at an Asian American networking event (go figure), but I'm curious to see if this place made deliveries to that event as well. Alcohol + Boba, the beginning of a not-so-great marriage, I hope I'm wrong on that one! But how great (or gross, depending on personal preferences) would it be to sip alcohol-infused boba nonchalantly down the street, or maybe that's just me.
author: Denise L.

description: Poké bowl minus rice, extra greens = the most delicious salad yum!!! Haven't tried anything else because the poké bowl is so good. Order online for pickup. Food is ready fast!
author: Caitlin G.

description: Three star for food, but deduct one star for the price. This is a hip place to get a bowl of hot noodle, with friends (they have long commute tables) or alone. But ramen taste and quality are not even close to some of the LA ramen bars, let alone those in Japan. Noodle, soup, meat, ingredient, egg... everything is mediocre. Disappointed that any respected Japanese chef would associate his name with this venue. It definitely does not qualify for gourmet ramen, and it is way too expensive for just a bowl of hot noodle soup ($20 for a tonkatsu ramen and three gyoza). Done with Michael Mina's Japanese venues after this and Pabu.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
Ordered via Postmates because I was craving soup and boba and this place hit two birds with one stone. I ended up ordering the Ginger Chicken Ramen and added pork belly (+$3), and the Golden Nectar Milk Tea (hot) w/boba pearls. 

The ramen broth was flavorful, noodles cooked to perfection, and the added pork belly topped it off amazingly - so tasty! I've never ordered boba tea hot before (usually always get iced), and really enjoyed it. The Golden Nectar tea was delicious, and the boba tapioca pearls were just the right chewiness. Would definitely order again!
author: Anna D.

description:
After years of eating it purely for survival, the first thing that comes to mind when someone says ramen is the 48ct Top Ramen variety pack from Costco (Beef flavor FTW!). After unsuccessfully attempting the Ramen Dojo wait challenge I also associate the word with long lines. 

Praise Beyonce The Ramen Bar is neither one of those things. 2 people in line in front of me on a weekday 1pm. Don't let the lack of waiting fool you, The Ramen Bar can hold its own as a solid spot. You shouldn't compare it to other places and appreciate it for what it is, a damn good bowl of ramen. 

Once Michael Mina opens shop closer to home, I'll be a regular and can finally stop eating ramen that looks like Justin Timerblake's hair from the 90's http://i.imgur.com/X031w8b.jpg
author: Jason O.

description: I got the Tokyo Style Kurobuta Pork. The ramen was good...a bit too much butter or etc in general. I like places in japantown a lot more. For a casual place in fidi this place isn't bad though.  I would most likely just end up having dinner at Pabu if I were around this area again.
author: Lily P.

description: Awesome Tokyo style ramen - and really good sides. A decent selection and relatively quick service if there's no line.
author: Oleg H.

description: 2-stars for the ginger chicken ramen. Nothing really special, didn't even really taste the ginger. The restaurant itself is nice and the outdoor seating was great. But I would not come back for the ginger chicken ramen.
author: Tinou B.

description:
Nestled in the midst of cable cars, the ferry building, market street, end of day traffic, rush of people making way to the BART and MUNI stations, Union Square, Chinatown, and towering buildings in the financial district, is The Ramen Bar sitting right next to its larger Japanese counterpart Pabu. 

The Ramen Bar does nothing to remind me of Japan... those perfectly made ramen noodles on the streets of Tsukiji fish market by an old man and his wife over a propane stove and a large pot of soup that's probably been cooking over night.  Locals stand waiting for a nice hot bowl of their ramen early in the morning before heading to work.  There are no seats to a small bar top table but everyone seems comfortable slurping up their ramen while standing on the curbside.  Broth so light yet brings so much depth you can taste the flavors of their ingredients that must've been brewed over fire for many hours.  The Japanese, pride principle and discipline, is intertwined with everything they do and can be felt through their craft.

If I were to compare most of the ramen joints in the bay area to my experiences in Japan, they would all get 2 or less stars.  Only a few good ones come to mind around this part of the world.  Like a glass of wine or scotch, everyone has their own preference.  So in this review I think it would be unfair to rate The Ramen Bar based on experiences from a land where the sun rises.  I won't even compare it with any ramen spots around here either since I feel that The Ramen Bar is something different.  It's kind of like that kid that didn't fit in at school but doesn't make it any less special in its own way.

When it comes to ramen, everyone is an expert... at least that's what it seems.  I'm not claiming to be an expert but there are certain things I personally look for.  I firmly believe that a good ramen to me depends highly on the chemistry between 2 parts, the soup and the noodles.  

The soup can be any flavor... as long as there is depth from its ingredients.  My parents and grandparents always stressed that a good soup base needs to be sitting over the fire throughout the night to get flavors deeply infused into the soup... basically it takes hours.  Growing up in a Chinese family, I've grown accustomed to that method of making soup.  I can tell if a soup has been on low boil for hours or not with a quick taste.  The soup here doesn't remind me of my grandmother, my childhood, or anything I've had in my recent years in Japan.  

I had the Hokkaido ramen.  Although it was quite flavorful, it was rather sharp and strong, lacking that depth and finesse that would have brought tears to my eyes with memories of my grandmother while she was still around.  The butter created a little too much oil for my likes and the chashu was a bit dry and tough.

Different people prefer different textures and types of ramen so it's hard to say if there really is a right or wrong way these days especially if we are not going to compare directly with some I've had in Japan.  At the Ramen Bar, the noodles are gluten free... hmmmm... that makes it real hard to compare to anything for that matter so we won't.  For a gluten free type of ramen it's pretty good.  It has a denser bite and more of a chew than what I'm use to but it totally works!

Most their other ingredients are good including their perfectly cooked egg with a beautiful creamy yolk.  Chashu wasn't so great as I described previously.

The Ramen Bar isn't as bad as what people make it seem though.  It doesn't help that their process of making your order looks something like the Chipotle of Ramen that showcases no special mastery.  Makes it look cheap and lack of attention to fine detail.  At the end of the day a great bowl of ramen is just using simple ingredients and make them work well together like everything else.  This place is above average so far for my first experience.  Service was attentive as well.

If I was nearby on a random night and felt like ramen I'd come here for a quick one.  As for the Japanese experience, I will be constantly reminded by the fancy decor, bustling happy hour crowd, bells of the cable cars, and the ramen I'm slurping that I'm definitely not in Japan.

3.5 stars rounded up to 4
author: Colin M.

description:
I'm gonna have to go with the yelp consensus here-- "Meh. I've experienced better."

It is a spot-on location right off Embarcadero BART. I work very close to The Ramen Bar and constantly pass by it only to see a fat line going out every time. It deterred me from going during lunch, so a friend and I made a dinner date out of it. Tuesday night, no line, very spacious. It was also freezing so our ramen appetite was pretty ferocious. We got our pick of tables and I must say, I enjoyed the ambiance. It's not super cramped like a lot of ramen stores.

Tokyo ramen-- salty salty salty. Very little broth but it's freaking salty, not even flavorful. Noodles were overcooked. It wasn't horrible just mediocre. It's the only ramen in the area so there's not really competition. If you have a severe hankering it will suffice. For better ramen I'd suggest Ramen Underground over by Montgomery, or even better Orenchi's in the Mission.

Dessert: Coffee jelly was pretty good! The bitter jelly and sweet toffee pudding go hand-in-hand. I'd recommend it.
author: Emily C.

description: Adequate for a lunch north of $10, but a bit disappointing considering that it has Michael Mina's name associated with this and you're really paying much much more than what you get.  Overall, worth a try once
author: Angel S.

description: This place is ok.  Wouldn't mind coming back.  Ramen could be better tho.
author: Joane B.

description:
This place deserves better reviews than it's getting.  First of all, they've updated the menu and added the heartier traditional options.  There's also a spicy native option now.

Overall the food tries very much to be balanced in the context of ramen, etc.  I never eat here and leave feeling overwhelmed.  The ingredients are high quality and carefully moderated.

I like coming back here.  It's good ramen.
author: Richard K.

description:
This place was not good. I ate here today for the first time, and I ordered the shrimp and crab ramen bowl. I would be disappointed by this dish if it were from some hole-in-the-wall - from a Michael Mina restaurant it's just wrong.The broth was extremely oily and lacked flavor/complexity. Additionally, each ingredient was quite bland and lacking flavor. This was not a "back to the elements" kind of dish. It was poorly constructed and either was prepared in a rush or needs to be reworked. 

I work on the same block as Ramen Bar, and I always see a line out the door around lunch time. Maybe I got a sub par dish, but my experience doesn't justify the line. 

Two stars because, although a poor food experience, there were no issues with cleanliness or service.
author: Lauren M.

description: The ramen is good, the noodles are fine, the brooth is ok, the service is terrible, I had to wait 15mins to get change for my bill.
author: Erik V.

description:
Michael Mina Group, I'm sorry to say this, but this is my true and honest review of my recent experience. Just had my BDAY dinner here. Had super high hopes. This is how it shook out:

1. Over salted broth
2. Over cooked noodles or clumpy noodles
3. Sold out of sake
4. Sold out of royal milk tea
5. One order of noodles came 15min late and without corn so it had to get sent back and I felt so bad for my friend who was watching us eat for 15++ minutes now. 
6. Suuuuuper small ass portions for $12-$16++ a pop. 
7. 2 mini bites of pork for the protein. My guest politely asked if 2 bites was the standard issue per bowl. 
8. No heat lamps for the freezing ass cold outdoor seating

I honestly was embarrassed and ashamed I chose this venue for my day dinner. Sorry but this was my honest and true experience.
author: Teresa H.

description:
I don't consider this a "foodie" destination. If you want real good ramen, this is not the place.

The noodles are not chewy and can't seem to "carry" the broth. Basically, the noodles have no flavor. The soup base had a slight seafood taste and this was confirmed when I saw one of the workers pour water from a defrosted bag of mini scallops. Hm.

Th broth was thin and light although marketed as "full of flavor". I could taste a hint of butter but it didn't add any richness.

The egg had a slight sake/alcohol flavor to it as well. Not my thing.

To top it all off, I was charged almost $14!

Also, I don't really care for the Japanese "decor" -- bottles of Kewpie and other Japanese ingredients along the walls. Just because you sell Ramune (for almost $3 a bottle!) doesn't make you authentic or good.

Skip... unless you're desperate (I get it).
author: T L.

description:
I recently started working in the area and have now visited Ramen Bar twice. It definitely deserves 4 stars. One knock on the restaurant is it's popularity. Prepare for lunch lines any time after noon on weekdays.

I've tried the SPICY MISO-BUTTER HOKKAIDO, great ramen. Hearty and full of flavor. And also the GYUDON Donburi. Nice blend of textures and flavor. Will definitely be back!
author: Matthew H.

description:
I walk past this place every day on my way to work and the line has been out the door EVERY TIME!  I have been to several of Michael Mina's other restaurants and had a great experience every time. Took my chances and waited in line for lunch today, I was NOT disappointed!!!

Had the Tokyo Roast Chicken ramen and opted to add the braised pork belly & soy cured hen egg. #fatkidproblems #foodgasm

Definitely going to be a new regular spot for lunch in the future. The line went quickly & staff was professional and friendly. This place is just what the financial district needed!
author: Hope R.

description:
I went in with absolutely zero expectations. I thought the Tokyo Style Kurobuta Ramen tasted like Japanese food. 

It might be possible that the portions, sizes of each toppings, and broth fluctuate in time. When I went in about a moth ago with two of my Ramen peeps. the portion was not as small as other people described in their reviews. Maybe they increased the portion size after hearing people complained? 

And pork was very thick, and big, and drippy oily as pork should be, but not like other reviews say "small." The pork in my bowl was big and thick. Egg was nice but a bit too sweet for me; perhaps accommodating to sweet pellets of Americans? Noodle was good, not overcooked and just right. Broth was okay but not great. With that price, broth could have been better. Not enough "Dashi" (the essence of taste extracted from stuff being cooked long hours). Now I know why Japanese (in Japan) ramen shops are small because one can cook only so much broth to serve to so many people. 

I also tried curry over rice. I would go to Curry House (San Francisco does not have Curry House yet) or Indian restaurant for curry. - Just not hot enough for me, and overpriced for that little bowl of rice and curry.

Over-pricing: Is it because of the "location"? or in the name of "Michael Mina"? I don't know. I take one star off because of the over-pricing of food and drink. I guess only powerful restaurant group can set up the large restaurant like that in the prime location like that, and prices go up by necessity, I guess? A small cup of sweetened milk tea for $4.25 and extra 50 cents for adding boba to iced tea sound crazy to me. I suppose it's sorta typical of "trendy" FiDi place, but it may not fit to my wallet. 

I enjoyed the dining there with friends, and my Ramen peeps approve the raman in this place. It was a special outing as one of them was visiting from the other side of the continent, but if I go to the area alone for shopping or other errands, I don't know if I want to spend $30 + just for raman, appetizer, drink, and tip and spend extra time on the long line. I would rather go for more convenient and filling food that costs me less than half of this place. But I am glad I got to try this place.
author: Momoko S.

description: I'm not a fan of their ramen. Sometimes it has been decent, once the broth was inedible. Their other items are tasty. Rice bowls are decent. Wagyu burger is pretty solid. The flavored ice teas are super yummy. Go here for anything but the ramen. There is better ramen a block away at Kirimachi in Embarcadero 3.
author: Elsie M.

description: Delicious food! But a little pricey! Great customer service and beautiful ambiance when it's not crazy busy!
author: Lauren O.

description: The Ramen Bar is a step above fast food. The food is expensive and mediocre. To give you an idea, edamame is provided in a small take out box from the frig. It's cold, not seasoned and you don't know how long it's been sitting there. The ramen bowl was good, but the take out California Roll for $10 is just okay. The restaurant has a soothing atmosphere and the bus service is great. The whole experience could be so much more.
author: Elea T.

description:
I had been wanting to try them out since it was announced that they were opening blocks away from work. Finally, I convinced Boyfriend to come with me for lunch.

Ordering ahead and picking up might be the smartest option in order to avoid the lines, but the lines do move rather quickly. However, I don't like that they don't seem to really look around to determine if they have any seating available before agreeing to a diner choosing the "for here" option when buying food (though I guess that's kind of on the customer as well).

Boyfriend and I both ordered the "Hokkaido" Miso-Butter Chashu ramen. However, I didn't expect that the ramen was going to be so spicy! In the menu description  of the item -- "braised pork, garlic, sweet corn, soy-cured egg (richer, bolder flavor)" -- nothing is said about spice! It wasn't so bad that I couldn't finish eating, but it caught me off guard and was definitely more than just a hint of heat. I'm sensitive to spice, so I wish I had known, but maybe that's what they meant by "richer, bolder flavor"? Or maybe I'm just sensitive. Boyfriend noticed the spice in his ramen, too, and it made his nose run and he's not quite as sensitive as me. So who knows.

Overall, I felt that they were pretty decent. Better than Ramen Underground on Kearny plus less of a trek to get to. They're a touch overpriced in my opinion, but if ramen is what you're in the mood for and you're stuck working in the FiDi, then I recommend coming here and trying them out.
author: Anna W.

description: Came on opening day.  Already had a line or the door at 11:00am.  About a 20 minute wait to order,  but the food came right after.  I enjoyed the shrimp and crab dumplings ramen.  The broth wad very tasty.  Next time I'll get the extra noodles.  Mina was watching over the first day.
author: Heinz G.

description:
Farm Chicken Donburi bowl - one word - YUM!  4, not 3 different preparations of chicken in this not-so-simple dish.  Chicken balls, braised chicken, roasted chicken, and chicken katsu over sticky rice.  The textures, flavors, and volume were pleasing.  The sauce and nori was a great accompaniment to the dish as well.  Was tempted to try one of the desserts, but didn't order.

I ordered togo and working in SF, you know if you are going to order togo, bring a bag (or get charged).  So I brought a bag.  Upon ordering, I noticed that after the cashier totaled me out, I was charged for the bag anyway.  So I advised her an the manager came and honored me with desserts!  Much love!

The sesame brittle and green tea madelines were wonderful - thank you!  I will be returning - often.
author: H A.

description:
The Ramen bar is the newest restaurant to be added to San Francisco's financial district opening on 06/30/2014, adjacent to it's new sister site Pabu.

Above is the Tokyo style pork belly ramen. Shouyu style base ramen that will run you $13 off the bat. You will get a smedium (small to medium) sized bowl filled with nori (dried seaweed),  wakame (seaweed), menma (bamboo shoots), chashu (pork shoulder), and buta no kakuni (braised pork belly) sprinkled with green onions. To my surprise a beautifully cooked seasoned and soft boiled egg accompanied my dish.

Aesthetically it was a great looking dish. First taste of the broth was a light shouyu taste that was filled with pork flavor. The soft boiled egg was seasoned well and balances the sweetness outside with the umami flavor seasoning and the creamy golden center. This is quite the rarity.

The meat was nice and tender, but the portions were rather small. Imagine half dollar sized pork belly and (3) 2" discs of pork shoulder. Unfortunately, the noodles in my bowl were also very overcooked. For a place that specializes in ramen, this is a big no-no unless specifically asked for a softer batch.

My experience had about the same amount of highs and lows. Overall the dish was still enjoyable. For $13 dollars you will be leaving the place feeling content with your serving, but will probably be feeling hungry within the next couple hours.
author: Kyle P.

description: Ordered the Shiro roll through Caviar - it's slammin.
author: Stacey R.

description: I totally agreed with some of yelpers' comments relating to serving lukewarm ramen.  To enjoy a good bowl of ramen, the broth has to be hot. Despite informing the staff that it was lukewarm, nobody seemed to care.  I won't go back again.
author: Fong K.

description: The ramen bar is the opposite of what I would call "value."  The shrimp and crab ramen was fine, but not worth $16.  The deviled eggs were overly salty and unappetizing, which is shocking because, um, how can you mess up deviled eggs?  The milk tea was refreshing and delicious, but paying $24 in total for a mediocre lunch, just seems absurd, even in the expensive FIDI.
author: Candice B.

description: I haven't had a bad experience here yet. The ramen is amazing, same with the rice bowls. And the teas are splendid.
author: Veronica S.

description:
I liked it!  I'm no ramen expert, but when RB opened up in my office building, how could I not check it out?  My initial encounter wasn't the best - I had ordered online using their web app, received a confirmation, and when I went down to pick it up, they had no record of my order.  However, the manager was super-nice and they had my order ready to go very quickly, especially given the number of tables that were occupied and all the people waiting.

The seaweed salad was delicious with an amazing dressing. I went with the ginger-braised chicken ramen, and loved the flavor of the soup, which was a fairly light choice given the complexity of some of the other offerings.  I have to say that the soy cured egg kind of creeped me out.  The flavor and texture was kind of odd.  And the chicken was plentiful, but I could've done without the chicken knuckle that was included.  Gah.

Big portion, great ingredients, pleasant and speedy service.  I'd definitely hit it again.
author: .Hon H.

description: I was not a fan. I think it's a decent bowl of ramen if you're paying the adequate amount. I think my bowl was worth maybe $7-8. Definitely not $16. The broth was also not hot enough for an Asian soup of any kind. It seems like they boiled the broth and threw the noodles in for a second and dumped it into a bowl. Not much cooked vegetation going on, either. They had thrown some kind of salad greens on top, which I guess I appreciated--but wasn't really sufficient. I wish I at least had some cooked cabbage in there instead of noodles and 3 pieces of shrimp. For $16 + tax? Ugh.
author: JoyAh B.

description: The food at Ramen Bar is decent, but can't compare to true Japanese ramen bar restaurants, especially those I've tried in LA. The atmosphere is nice and it's a good go-to spot for the FiDI professionals for lunch or happy hour. Due to it being a Michael Mina owned restaurant in FiDi, the prices for ramen are a bit steep compared to what I'm used to paying. I do go back though because the location is great, although the lines can be a bit long during lunch. It's a decent spot to fill my noodle craving when I don't want to go anywhere farther.
author: Becky C.

description:
Went with Sqky. Ordered Tokyo with added side of noodles and pork belly, $12 + $2 for each side. it was a very decent bowl of ramen. nothing to complain about except the Chasu was just a little tough. not a big deal if i didn't have braces on. shoyu egg was perfect. pork belly was perfect. noodles' perfect. Dao Pan Jan (fermented spicy bean paste) was pretty tasty and spicy. Everything was fine. not the best but way better than average.

Manager checked on us no less than 2 times. He also went around and made sure every table is happy. i am not sure why Cordelia C. did not tell the manager or one of the always present staff members about her noodles.

I always let the restaurant have a chance to correct something before complaining about it. I learned to be nicer and reasonable after seeing so many unfair reviews on Yelp.

I will go back to The Ramen Bar. My fav so far in SF is Katana-Ya and Suzu =) and St Regis lobby lounge of course (they are prepared in the Ame kitchen).
author: DANIEL T.

description:
After reading a lot of the negative reviews I thought I was walking into a sh*t show. But I went to two Michael Mina restaurants and they were both good. This place is a lot better than I expected.

The Ramen Bar is located in the corner of a plaza. There's indoor and outdoor seating for about 60 or more. I even saw Michael Mina sitting and talking with another chef outside. The interior mostly succeeds as a high end fast food restaurant posing as faux low-end Japanese ramen shop. They have folding chairs, disposable chopsticks, and stock shelving; however, take a look at the kitchen, bathroom, and staff and you'll know what kind of place this is.

The menu is straightforward: Tokyo-style ramen, donburi, salads, and drinks. I think they have takeout items to go as well, including desserts. I ordered the shrimp and crab dumpling ramen. The wait is typical for ramen, about 6-8 minutes. I really enjoyed the ginger-clam broth even though I couldn't really taste the ginger. The noodles are good, the shrimp is good, the dumplings are good. The flavors are super clean and tasty. No faults here. I tried some of their homemade hot paste. I wished I hadn't used so much because it's quite potent.

The only thing I had a problem with is the portion size. For $16 w/o tax this is a little cray. The bowl consists of two shrimp, two dumplings, mizuna (like arugula), roasted seaweed, and sweet corn. To be honest when I eat ramen I want to be really really full. If you want additional items like extra noodles or egg, it'll cost you $2 more. Really? $2 for more noodles?? After half an hour I was hungry again. But I cannot fault the quality of the ramen. Just more please or at least more affordable additions. I assume they're aiming at the local wealthy patrons' pocketbooks.

Service is very nice. The women always had really big disturbing smiles on their faces and the guys were friendly enough. No problems with the staff.

____

I recommend this place but I would say it's a little pricey for what you get. Keep in mind this is Tokyo-style ramen so it might not be what you're used to.
author: Michael H.

description: This place was interesting they only had about 5 different types of ramen, the descriptions for each ramen were very vague. So I didn't really have an idea of what to get. Anyways, it's not the greatest ramen, very water down broth. Pork belly was good, noddles were fresh. The facility is very clean and nice, pricing is pretty high for a bowl of ramen that was terrible.
author: Cassandra G.

description: This is the 2nd time in 2 weeks they have sent me home with the wrong take out order! I only ordered ONE item!!! The last time I was here the manager had to comp us desert because they FORGOT to make our order! The food here is good but for $17 noodles I would expect a restaurant to at least give you the right food! What a disgrace for Michael Minna.
author: Little P.

description:
TOO SALTY.

If they stopped dumping tubs of salt in the broth, then I'd give them 3 stars. Nothing really special about this place except that it bears the "Michael Mina" name. I would rather go to Kirimachi, second saltiest destination around, where prices are slightly lower and flavors comparable.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Our office loves this place!

The seafood ramen is the winner here, the broth is amazing. The tokyo style pork ramen is delicious and won't leave you groggy after you get back from lunch break. Salads are refreshing and fun too.

The lines might get long but goes reeeally fast compared to other places.
author: Ana P.

description:
Oh, shocking.  One of Michael Mina's restaurants is totally overpriced and completely overrated!  
If you feel like wasting $15 at lunch (minimum) for formulaic, wanna be, not much to write home about, seize-the-hype-moment ramen, then this place is for you!  Plan to spend no less than $15 for a bowl of salty noodle water with a couple of barely there pieces of protein and previously frozen kernels of corn and when you're done you have to go get a sandwich two hours later because you're still hungry.  The FiDi ding dongs form a line out the door every day but don't be fooled.  Do yourself a favor and walk a stones throw of blocks down to Kearny and visit Ramen Underground instead.
author: e w.

description: Gluten-free noodles available upon request. Very accommodating chefs and staff. A great ramen spot for cautious diners.
author: Parker M.

description:
Don't come here if you want the rich tonkotsu style ramen, Chef Ken's goal was to serve you a different take on ramen, the kind the people in Tokyo slurp from street vendors. 

I had the seafood ramen at Ramen Bar and it was very good, like I said different than ramen I was use to but so clean and simple and not heavy that I could comfortably eat my whole bowl with out the bloating after effects. I liked the crab dumplings too. The portion is big so I don't know how you're expected to order other food but if I were to recommend other foods I would go for the following:

- Salmon donburi, lightly cooked salmon that melted in my mouth goodness
- Crispy duck wings - heavy in flavor but the meat is sparing, not sure if it's just the way duck wings are, either way I liked it
- Skip the pork belly baos, Chairman Bao still rules in this department
- Salads were good too
- Green tea parfait - I could eat a pint of this stuff, delicious

Side notes: they offer vegetarian broth and gluten free noodles here, such a rarity.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Unimpressive. I love me some ramen and was excited to try this new shop by Michael Mina, but didn't leave with a desire to hurry back. Small selection, noodles were not that could and the broth was lukewarm. It wasn't terrible, but completely forgettable. 

The best thing there was the edamame with the amazing sea salt. That salt was the highlight of the meal. 

I'll give it another try sometime but meanwhile there are much better places for ramen in the surrounding area.
author: Courtney A.

description:
What's the point of offering gluten free noodles for all of the ramen options if only one of the ramen options can actually be made completely gluten free?  And why is this not clearly explained on the menu? 

Thankfully the waiter knew enough to inform me that the vegetarian ramen was not gluten free even with gluten free noodles.  There is no vegetarian gluten free ramen option at The Ramen Bar, which really disappointed me.  

The waiter did bring me a salad that was supposed to be made with gluten free noodles.  Turns out the noodles were not gluten free, which I realized AFTER eating the dish once I felt awful.

The only reason I gave this place two stars instead of one is because the waiter was willing to check what ingredients in the ramen had gluten.  He tried to accommodate the best he could, which I appreciated...despite the kitchen's mistake of using regular noodles for the salad.

I don't plan on going back unless they start carrying a gluten free vegetarian ramen.
author: Lexi B.

description: I visited "The Ramen Bar" with my girlfriend and found it lacking. I got the Tokyo Style Kurobuta Pork ramen and a salmon roll. The roll wasn't very good and the Tokyo Style ramen was just ok found the taste bland (could have made better at home). In all I'll just go somewhere else next time and save my money.
author: Rolando G.

description: Got the Ginger Chicken ramen and a glass of Kirin on a cold rainy day in SF. The food tasted great, not too salty or rich like some ramen places. Portions were slightly on the leaner side, but decent enough for lunch.
author: Tim H.

description:
So the stars remain the same.  Apart from my last visit there were some improvements!  1)The "manager" I assume is not bad looking.  Would totally holla ;)
He provided great customer service 2) the texture of the noodles tasted better than last (not too overcooked)  3) the soup base tasted better (however it was too oily) 
Anyways, would I come back?  possibly for their happy hour from 3-6pm, green tea parfait, and for some good eye candy :D 

P.S. the food did take forever to come out (but to be fair they do a lot of take out and delivery)  Good thing the eye candy made up for the wait...
author: Ann L.

description:
Some ramen are interresting in term of flavor but it doesn't have the addictive super Yummy taste that you can find in other places. I would go for 3,5 stars but I can't give 4: sorry !!!

+ It is convenient if you are in downtown near Embarcadero.
author: Mathieu F.

description:
I heard about the Ramen Bar thru SF WEEKLY, I will never trust the SF WEEKLY again.

I tried the Hokkaido Ramen which was okay - 14$
After finishing the noodles, the broth was too thick and really soupy.  A big plus was the sheet of seaweed they throw in which shrunk down to a leaf.

I also ordered the Crispy Duck Wings - 7$
No meat on the bone and they were really really dry.

To top it off, I pulled a bottled juice from the refrigerator in the front only to find it was 8$$  That literally rocked my world, I told the my waitress, "really, you guys know theres no alcohol in here right ..." ??  She did offer me free dessert which I thought was a little condescending.  I wasn't asking to be compensated, I was just freaking out because I've never paid that much for something that I can get CVS pharmacy for 3$.

My total bill came up 37$ for one person, tip included.

Speaking of the waitresses, they were really weird.  Attentive yes but really personal.  I honestly just came in for a quiet bowl of ramen and not be interrogated because I didn't appear to be in a good mood. 

Save your money folks, you can get the same great ramen flavors and crappy service in other Ramen shops around SF for half as much.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Alright.  Changed my mind a bit with their Chicken Miso Hokkaido.  That is a very good chicken ramen, as the chicken is perfectly cooked and still very juicy.  Do this over the pork and soy - add on some of the chili paste.  

Definitely the best bowl of chicken ramen in downtown.
author: Mark M.

description: This bilious ramen is not work even 1 star. Atmosphere is overly commercial, the broth is dishwater, the pork is impure, the seaweed reeks of 5 day old fish.
author: Adam B.

description:
The worst customer service experience I, sadly, have ever received.   So my co-worker and I had a craving for ramen and, through PostMates (great delivery service for all things) ordered some ramen for The Ramen Bar.  Big mistake. 

Here's what we ordered:  

FIRST ITEM: Item description: Ramen: Mushroom & Soy: Extra Noodles, Braised Pork Belly, Buttered Corn, Make it with Gluten Free Noodles, Notes: no egg, 

SECOND ITEM: Ramen: Mushroom & Soy:Extra Noodles, Agedashi Tofu, Notes: No Egg.)

What we got:  2 Veggie ramen orders, period.   There was NO label re: what, if any was gluten free, no braised pork belly or tofu for my co-worker... nada.    So literally $40.00 plus dollars later it looks like Shirley, the woman who processed/ filled our order at The Ramen Bar grabbed two vegetable ramens, didn't bother to read ANYTHING else on the order, threw it in a bag and called it a day.   OH, but she did somehow manage to NOT put an egg on either of our ramens... so she read something....

So I call the restaurant and Shirley answers, I tell her the entire order is utterly wrong.   Did she even bother to read the order?  She does apologize, has no real excuse, then puts me on hold.   I'm guessing she's trying to find a manager.   Then a guy gets on the phone, I hear rumbling in the background, he tells me that "they" are extremely busy right now and cannot help me, that I need to call back, the he, LITERALLY, hangs up on me.... nice, thanks.

So to sum it up, if you don't want anything you ordered, want it late, want to deal with a RUDE counter staff and receive luke warm, not so great ramen, then by ALL means... definitely check this place out, you won't be disappointed... 

Way to go The Ramen Bar.
author: Cindi C.

description:
Two stars cos
1) Ben's ramen came out late
2) The fruit jellies tasted too much like jam
3) Pretentious/stupid haiku ("miso happy" ?)
4) Noodles were so-so 

In conclusion, this place could be better
author: Amar P.

description: Actually pretty good!  Quick in and out to buy for take out, and it was actually pretty good.  Got the chicken hokkaido ramen bowl.  Probably a bit overpriced for what it is, but happy to pay for it given the location.
author: Vivian W.

description:
I probably should have read the reviews before going.  I get ramen a couple of times a month and was excited for there to be a shop close now, but it was disappointing.

As most other people have said, the food was very bland; so bland that after 3 packets of siracha and a healthy sprinkling of pepper flakes the dish still did nothing for me. 

I'm usually a cheap person but for some reason today I felt like splurging. $17 for a Michael Mina shrimp and lobster ramen, I expected this to be amazing. 2 pieces of shrimp and 2 mashed up lobster balls later, I realized I had been dooped .

If you're looking for good ramen that's $7 cheaper than what I spent, walk over to Ramen Underground.
author: Jelly J.

description:
Lukewarm soup broth, cold shrimp "dumplings", bad service.

Had the crab and shrimp dumpling ramen for $16. For that price, you'd think they could make it hot.

When I got up to order something to go, and mentioned that my shrimp dumplings were cold, they acted like it was my fault.

Me: "My soup dumplings were cold, like they just came out of the fridge. I tried dunking them in the broth, but it was gross because I bit into cold fish."
Them: "Oh, why didn't you say anything earlier?"
Me: "Well I would have, except no one came by to check on us!" 

Seriously? They tried to recoup a little bit by giving me a bit of a discount off of my to go order and a free coupon for ramen next time, but I don't know if I am going to bother. (This gets them the 2 stars, instead of the 1 I was originally considering). 

Poor execution. Michael Mina was actually walking around when we first got in, and if he was still there I'd ask him why they don't seem to care that their ramenl is getting served cold and their service tries to blame the customers. 

ALL of our soup broth was lukewarm, and if that was it I would have given them a pass and not bothered to mention it to them, but all together this was too much. 

I've been here before, work near here, but now I'm questioning whether I ever want to go back.
author: Annie M.

description: celebrity chefs in name only but without the delivery and meticulous execution day in and out, but definitely the high price tag.  even the poke bowl, not so stand out or meeting high chef level expectations.
author: Rob C.

description:
Something something Michael Mina, world renown chef opens up a ramen bar in the middle of the financial district.

I've had both the Hokkaido ramens and the Gyudo, which I've crushed after an 800-calorie workout. But my hunger didn't disguise the noticeable sharpness of the ginger or the weak, complicated, herby flavor of the broth.

Basically, this tastes exactly what it sounds like: an American adaptation of ramen. Which is not in itself a bad thing. But it just doesn't cut it for me in a city with some pretty decent ramen shops.

So you're wondering why I've been here a few times if I think there are better places to rustle up grub. Well, my buddy really likes it, it's really conveniently located, and we've never had to wait for seats (though it's pretty lively even during the off hours we go). Sort of a nice hangout spot.
author: Christophe C.

description:
Michael Minna's Ramen Bar is good in the way that The Ramen Shop in Rockridge is good. The flavors are clearly balanced and the variety of the menu is thoroughly thought-out, but authentic, good ramen comes down to the broth and both of these celebrity-chef-associated places have not tackled this front, in my humbly pedestrian opinion. I'm more forgiving towards Ramen Shop because their rotating menu is truly experimental and interesting, which I can't say for Ramen Bar.

There is some strange take-out and order ahead scheme going on here, but I've never quite figured it out. I've been to Ramen Bar twice for dinner, and there was no wait either time. There is indoor and outdoor seating, both of which are pretty spacious and designed well.

This time, I got the Mushroom & Soy ramen ($11). I like how most of the bowls come with corn (although you can always add it on the side). The mushrooms were well-cooked and the broth was good enough that I was able to drink the entire bowl. My friend gave me part of his egg, which was nicely cured and soft boiled. There is nothing bad about the ramen itself; it's just not impressive either.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Our expectations were too high (from the anticipation that grew from passing it everyday) and I mistakenly associated "ramen" with tonkotsu broth. 
 
That said, the place is brand new so I expect them to work out some kinks and will be back to try some of their teas and rice dishes.  But I expected the ramen at a place called "the RAMEN bar" to be spectacular.  It wasn't.  

The soup was not piping hot which can be a pro or con depending on who you ask. For me it's a con, I want my soup hot, not lukewarm. 

The pork and clam broths contain chicken.  I can't have chicken so they let me swap the vegetarian broth into the pork belly ramen.  It's soy based/miso so it had a bitter undertone that I didn't care for and was a tad on the salty side.  There was also spinach which I guess is their attempt to SF-y it but it was awkward mixed in with the seaweed.  

My lunch companion said the pork broth had a sweet undertone which matched what I tasted in the little pieces of pork.  

Like I said, I'm willing to try their other offerings so for now they are just OK but ...

-1 star specifically for waiters carrying the bowls by gripping the side with their thumbs INSIDE the bowl.
author: Ruthe R.

description:
Ok, I've come here twice since they have opened and yes, I came because of the Michael Mina name. I was aware that Ken, the chef, does not like tonkatsu broth and the noodles are Chinese-style wheat and egg noodles. I had an open mind coming here to try something different. 

The first experience I had was pretty good. I ordered the braised pork belly. The service was great... yet semi uncomfortable. There was a waiter who kept coming by to chat, he was just overly-friendly. The broth was light, like I had expected. The eggs were freaking awesome. The noodles were different, but I had that expectation. It was overall a good bowl of ramen, not exactly what I expected, but decent and dare I say, delicious. 

Today, I returned to try something different on the menu to give it another shot. They already added a new Hokkaido (sp?) ramen to the menu, which includes corn, chashu, garlic. It was not garlicky at all... I didn't even remember tasting it in the broth. The noodles were the same, and the toppings were whatever. But isn't it the broth that makes the ramen? I don't understand. It was light as I was previously warned about... but it was just not great. 

I have decided this style of ramen isn't for me. The bowls come lukewarm to the table and I find myself adding a ridiculous amount of pepper and togarashi into my broth, isn't that a clue there's a problem. Thinking back to my first bowl, I did the same. Maybe my low expectations just made my first bowl "good".  

Many might be yelling "it's a light broth!" but I never agreed to a bland one. Maybe it's the lack of MSG, maybe it's the fact that other ramens are just more flavorful, maybe this just falls flat... maybe it's this, maybe it's that... but the one definite I have, is that I don't plan on coming back. After having tonkatsu broth ramen, this isn't for me.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
This place has delicious ramen. I got the standard pork ramen, which was delicious. When I went during lunch at 12:30 on Monday, there were only 3 people ahead of us, and we were served quickly.
I spent $12 for my ramen (I think), which is the same price as the ramen that I ordered last week at the farmer's market at the ferry building (and I didn't have to pay an extra $1 for an egg in my ramen here, as I did for the ferry building place). Considering that this is a Michael Minna restaurant, and they use top notch ingredients, I think the price was what was to be expected.
Location is also great - especially on really nice days when you can eat outside on the steps. 
I'm happy to have this place across the street from me!
author: Dana O.

description: I did come back here but tried the rice bowl. The Ramen, however bad it is for my stomach is at least flavorful and filling. The rice bowls, and I have tried two - chicken/avocado and salmon - are mostly rice with little protein, dry and just no good, overall. $$$ for a bowl of rice, few pieces of chicken/fish and some garnishing - no, thank you.
author: TwinPeaker J.

description:
Went here for an office lunch and loved it! I have been wanting to go here for weeks since I walked past it one day, and so happy that I finally tried it. The line is typically super long during the lunch rush.

It is a Michael Minna restaurant, so very popular. Ramen was cooked to perfect al dente (I always like it a little chewier). I ordered the Spicy Miso Chicken, and the broth was not really spicy at all, but it was still tasty. I like the spinach and corn added into the soup.

It doesn't look like they have dealt with substituting ingredients yet, so just be aware of that if you want to switch things around.
author: Elisha Y.

description:
Small portions, food - just ok, and super slow service.

When you go to a Michael Mina establishment, you expect a certain level of quality, service, ambiance, etc.  Granted, this is considered their "casual" restaurant... this place definitely still fell short of my expectations.  Ambiance and location are great!  As for the other stuff...

I went with a group of 8 people to celebrate a friend's birthday during their second week of opening.  I read a few reviews before going and was looking forward to trying their ramen and milk tea. When ordering, it was apparent that the server lacked knowledge of their menu.  Not only was she not knowledgable, she didn't know what items the kitchen was "out" of.  So, I wasn't able to order what I originally wanted.  

I ended up ordering their shrimp & crab dumpling ramen and my girlfriend ordered the braised pork belly ramen... also ordered their grilled salmon salad to start.  The grilled salmon salad was tasty but was drenched in dressing.  It was supposed to be garnished with salmon skin furikake (sounds delicious, right?) but that was no where to be found on the plate.  The ramen portions were unusually small, especially considering their pricing.  My shrimp & crab dumpling ramen came with 2 pieces of the dumpling, which was tasty, and 2 peeled shrimp.  The light ginger clam broth was flavorful... Overall, not bad.  My girlfriend's braised pork belly ramen came with 2 itty bitty pieces of pork belly.  Broth was ok.  Again, the portions leave much to be desired.  

Would I go back?  Probably not.  In my opinion, there are several other ramen restaurants in the city that serve better ramen, have a more specialized menu, and provide better service.
author: Jackie C.

description:
Incredibly disappointing. Yes I knew it already was at 3/5 stars before I got there but I had to try it to make sure. I got the "SPICY MISO CHICKEN $14.00 garlic, sweet corn, bamboo, soy-cured egg (richer, bolder flavor)*" with a pork belly addition ($2).

The breakdown:
Noodles - Ok. Probably Sun factory noodles. I prefer firmer.
Broth - Tasted like Swanson chicken broth. Nothing rich or bold about this at all.
Toppings - Pork belly was well, boiled pork belly. Could have marinated it or used a torch on it or something. Chicken was just shredded chicken. The green stuff, (spinach and arugula?) it was, tasted just like boiled greens. The egg was notable only for the fact that it tasted like sake (our teenage neighbor agreed). I complained and they brought a different egg out that just tasted like soy. Not sure what happened there.

Overall it tasted like what happens when I have leftover food in the fridge and just toss it all in a pot. Obviously not worth the $16.00 for the bowl.
author: Greg M.

description:
Ok so I love Ramen noodle my entire life. 
When you eat a bowl of real ramen, it is a fight between you and ramen noodle.
If you can eat 'em all while its at the best state, you win. If the noodle gets soggy, then Ramen wins
But anyway, this fight did not happen here as the noodle was way way waaaaaaaay overcooked

I got a bowl of "Tokyo style Kurobuta Pork" which looked ok:
-Noodle: way way overcooked. very soggy and no texture. And some noodles were sticked together, nasty!
-soup: not too bad compared to how the noodles are, but still have a lot of oil considering it is Tokyo style Shoyu based soup.
-egg: It looks right, but too sweet. Trying half of the egg was enough to me
-Chashu: Doesnt have much taste other than salt, and very dry

I was very disappointed to find out another imitated ramen store.

I wasnt gonna complain about price as long as it taste all right, but this is way over priced for the imitated Ramen noodle.
My review might seem harsh for some people, but for those of you who know what's REAM RAMEN taste like, then you would strongly agree with me.
author: K H.

description:
I enjoy Ramen and decided to try The Ramen Bar for lunch.

Not alot of options, but what they serve are top notch.

Service and prompt and the Ramen came out hot and delicious.

A good value for a quick lunch.
author: Daniel P.

description:
I was excited to check out a new place for ramen in the FiDi with my coworkers since it was a short walk from our office. 

Thoughts on the restaurant overall:

Pros:
Excellent interior design
Outdoor seating (tables are for 4 people but can fit 5 or 6 if you grab extra chairs)
Excellent customer service & waitstaff
Quick ordering process
Easy to read menu

Cons:
Not enough seating inside or outside for lunch rush.

Thoughts on Ramen & Beverages:

$4.25 for a half full cup of milk tea that they fill up the remainder with ice, .50 extra for boba = $4.75?!

Miso Butter Chasu Ramen - $14
- Broth was average, chasu pork and eggs were excellent, ramen noodles did not taste fresh and clumped together. The portion size was smaller than I'm used to also. For this price I was expecting a more gourmet bowl of ramen so we were disappointed.

I understand this is a Michael Mina restaurant and the location probably comes with an expensive monthly lease so the menu price reflects that.

Conclusion: Myself and coworkers will probably not be back as ramen Underground produces a better quality ramen for a few dollars less. Ramen Bar seems like a decent late night option if you absolutely have to have ramen in the FiDi and are too lazy to walk to to other places for ramen.
author: David W.

description:
My coworkers and I go to the Hapa Ramen food cart at the Ferry Building religiously every Tues & Thurs, so, we were elated to discover that The Ramen Bar was opening just 1 block from our office (everday access to ramen!).

We arrived at 11:30 AM, to beat the crowd, but there was already a line out the door. I purchased the Braised Pork Belly ramen, which is prepared with a soy-based broth. The broth was rich and not too salty. The menu stated that the broth is prepared sans MSG (always, a good thing). While The Ramen Bar's broth was tasty, it wasn't rare or spectacular, in fact, the broth lacked the complex flavors found in the broth at Hapa Ramen. I would say the same is also true when compared to Waraku's broth (Must try Waraku's tonkotsu ramen!).  In my opinion, broth is the #1 disguishing factor when comparing ramen soup. A rich-bold flavored broth will keep customers coming back for more and more ramen soup! However, in all fairness, I'd like to try The Ramen Bar's miso based soup before I come to any final conclusions. With respect to the pork belly, it was not as tender or as sweet as the pork belly at the Ramen Underground but it was still pretty tasty and I would say it rivals the pork belly at Waraku. However, the soy-marinated egg, used by the Ramen Bar, does not compare to the smoked soft boiled egg at Waraku (Yum! Deep sigh :)!  

My overall experience was good, however, the most disappointing part of my experience is that I left a little hungry! At about $13/bowl a customer should not leave hungry!

I will definitely return to The Ramen Bar for future meals, however, the juries still out on whether or not its ramen can rival some of the more well-established ramen restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Tasha T.

description:
Ramen is decent if you need to satisfy a craving however yes it is overpriced for what you get. ($12-$14)

Do not get the ginger braised chicken over rice. Extremely small portions and the flavor is below average. ($12)

I tried the "Hong Kong Style" milk tea - they basically brew a bag of Bigelow's Constant Comment and use that as the foundation of the tea. Never again. :(
author: Minh N.

description: I ordered the Kale Salad with crispy quinoa and tofu.  Everything was pretty decent except for the MOUNDS of bonito flakes piled on top of my salad - so gross and so salty!  Ruined the entire lunch for me.  My cats might like Bonito and I think they should stay as a treat for them, not as a topping for my salad.  Blech!
author: Taress H.

description:
Meh.

Maybe my expectations were high because Michael Mina. Maybe I just really wanted some yummy ramen. But... meh.

I had takeout of the ginger braised chicken ramen. The broth wasn't bad, but there were probably only 4 slices of chicken about 1" wide by 2" long and about .1875" thick. Very little veg & the bowl had obviously been made up before, as the noodles were stuck together. Once I added the broth to the noodles, meat & veg they loosened a little, but overall, it was a meh meal at best. Not impressed.
author: L R.

description: I got the Hokkaido ramen with pork belly and a slow cooked egg. Overall, the broth was much sweeter than I expected and than any miso ramen I've had before. It was a bit too much for me and. The noodles were decent, but not the best in terms of chewiness. The pork belly was very good: tender and flavorful bu with not too much fat. I was hoping the slow cooked egg would be the typical ramen egg with a runny yolk, but it is actually more of a poached egg. I would have much preferred the typical kind of egg. The ramen was ok overall, but given the price (~$15) and small portion, I wasn't impressed.
author: Kevin T.

description:
first of all, the hong kong flavor milk tea was horrible. it tasted watered down, not strong brewed at all, and the boba and milk are optional and cost extra!!!! that is a disgrace calling it hong kong flavored and tasting so bad. very very disappointing.

a place with good ramen and good milk tea is like a dream lunch spot for me. unfortunately i will not bother trying any of the other milk teas or ever getting it again from here. the ramen however, was actually decent.
