i didnt have high expectations coming here and it was as expected but slightly better. i was expecting a very commercial bulk production of ramen and that was exactly what it was. it had a long line but i like that you wait in line to order and then find a place to sit. it was moving at a decent pace and after ordering, the food was ready pretty fast. the shredded cabbage on top didnt sound very good but it blended in to the ramen fine. the pork belly was pretty good as was the egg. i had the tonkotsu and it had a pretty decent flavor. since theres not that many options in the soma/fidi area, i would go back here if i was craving ramen as opposed to the other random cafeteria places in the area that have ramen.
author: Alex H.

description: I love the Tonkotsu ramen here.  Yes, a bit on the expensive side but I'm willing to pay extra for it.
author: Lev E.

description:
I almost want to give this place 2 stars because after I ate it, I was honestly thinking 'Meh, I have had better' but I don't think they really deserve that so 3 it is. My friend and I came here for dinner and there was no wait. YAY.

Both of us knew of the mediocre reviews but we were still curious so we figured why the hell not and came with low to no expectations. We ordered the appetizer platter and then each a ramen, I got the kurobata pork and she got the other pork flavor. The appetizer was OK at best. Edomame was warm and salted, but nothing special. We only got ONE pork bun which is odd because if people are sharing this... who gets the one? Also, the slice of pork was WAY too small and bun itself was a bit too dense. The duck wings had good flavor but only came with one drumstick and a wing. The crab rangoons were tasty. I actually really liked these. Lastly, the pickled daikon was good but you don't get a lot of it. All for $12 was a bit much if you ask me.

Anyways on to the ramen. The kurobata pork was a bit underwhelming. The broth was under seasoned and the noodles were no al-dente. While the broth flavor wasn't bad, there was something about it that reminded me of a Chinese soup base Chinese restaurants serve as soups of the day (real chinese soups, not hot and sour soup). Everything else in the ramen was not bad. The porkbelly was melt in your mouth good and the pork shoulder was tender. The soft boiled eggs were surprisingly good as well.

At the end of the night, we ended up paying $60total including dessert. All in all, it was OK. Nothing to rave about but I didn't hate it either.
author: edward k.

description: Ramen Love to the next level and It's Michael Mina so the ingredient quality is high.
author: Garrett G.

description:
So..I did it guys. I became that girl who ordered the salad at a ramen restaurant. Turns out that it was DELICIOUS. 

My minus two stars came from this horrendous hot mess of a drink that they named "boozy Thai tea". It was that bad that I needed to knock a couple stars off. Tasted like a massive TEN DOLLAR cup of suck.
author: Katie M.

description:
- Salmon was not fresh, and cold.
- Over dressed the salmon rice bowl with kewpie mayo. 
- Rice was old and had dried bits in it.
- Ramen broth was over salted, others seem to feel the same way.
- Communal spices at tables is unsanitary. How is this not a health code violation since folks can double dip!?!?!
- Overpriced for the quality and flavor.
author: M C.

description:
After reading the 78 reviews and seeing the 3 star rating (and hearing reactions from my coworkers), my expectations were set pretty low. But I wanted to give it a shot, since it's just across the street from work. 

My expectations were met. My conclusions:
-  it's a very basic approach to ramen--no frills and not a lot of flavor
- the broth is clean tasting 
- the broth is not fatty/heavy... so after the meal, you can still be productive at work 
- ramen aficionados will likely be disappointed
- not a lot of flavor (did I say that already?)

Gluten Free note: I was able to sub my noodles for gluten-free noodles made from yams, at no extra charge. This is why I have them 3 stars (vs 2 stars).

I'm hoping that after Ramen Bar sees these lackluster reviews, they will add more flavor to the broth. I'll go back if the reviews get better.
author: Miyuki I.

description:
I'd give 'em 4 stars, but $12-$14 for a bowl of ramen is a bit much, even by SF standards. 

As far as ramen shops in SF go, this one is above average. Keep in mind I've only been once and tried one of their ramen offerings, the Tokyo Kurobata. The pork was very good but lacked the intense flavor I've come to associate with Kurobata. The noodles were cooked to al dente near-perfection. The egg was just about perfect too. The broth, while rich and possessed of the elusive ramen "spirit," was a bit heavy on the soy sauce. 

Service was great and it was nice to sit-'n'-slurp outside on a warm summer's day. 

I'll go back to try their miso broth, which I was told is their most popular. 

Oh, and they don't have karaage.
author: Brett W.

description: So, it wasn't the worst ramen I've ever had, but I probably wouldn't go back, even if I lived in the area. Biggest complaint, the Sapporo wasn't cold and the cold sake wasn't cold either. We had the edamame, pork gyoza, the Tokyo ramen and the Hokkaido. My boyfriend got the Tokyo and was quite pleased with his. I liked his better than my Hokkaido as well. The Tokyo broth was light and flavorful, noodles were generous and firm and the pork belly was tasty and tender. My Hokkaido broth was kind of muddy and, frankly, not very hot at all. In a pinch it will do, but I would definitely want to try other places next time.
author: Amy G.

description:
Its a solid 3 stars. Its not good and not bad for the Fi-Di. 
This obviously isn't going to be super authentic ramen. 
Just keep your hopes low and you will be fine. Its better than no ramen on this side of town. 

Definitely catered to the work crowd. 
Why would you come here if you had actual time to go wait in line for ramen elsewhere??

It will probably be the cleanest and expensive ramen joint you will ever go to so you can at least appreciate that. $15 average bowl of ramen. 
Its kind of the same concept as spending $8+ for an "OK" Banh mi sandwich.... which makes me shiver but desperate times call for desperate measures!
author: Dee N.

description:
UPDATE: much improved in September.  Broth flavor is fixed. Temperature, I would prefer hotter but it may be the downtown need for speed that makes them serve it this way. Food comes out fast. 

Service still hit and miss, cashier tried to give me $6 in change with singles, gave me five and disappeared to the back. So that was the tip. I will go here now but it's not perfect. 



I waited so long for the Ramen Bar to open, then even longer to find a day I could get in. Now I'm a little disappointed. 

It's fast, friendly, decent price for FiDi food. Great decor, acoustics, service was on point (kitchen forgot the egg that comes with Tokyo ramen, but server brought it quickly). The menu is well thought out. 

But ramen to me is about the broth. And the broth was not good. It was tonkotsu, which is the gold standard. It was shimmery with the right amount of fat, glistening but not greasy. Overall, however the broth did not have much flavor and it came out lukewarm. Like a steak house with bad steak. 

 I might try it again but I wanted a place to make me stop hiking up to Katana-Ya (who doesn't even try tonkotsu). I don't think this is the place. At least not yet.
author: jim b.

description:
So I came here after seeing some friends post some pics of it via the usual social channels. The first thing I see was a long line out to the huge sign outside. Ok, I didn't have any meetings, so I didn't have to worry about that. Stand in line, grab the menu, second thing that jumps out at me. Ohh, Michael Mina, nice. Wait, what does he know about ramen? Then, I see that it looks like he hired some Japanese guy to craft the meals. That sounds a bit better, but at this point I'm still skeptical. As I scan the menu, the next thing that catches me off guard are the prices. I know it's FiDi, but come on, this better be some damn good ramen to cost 12-16 dollars a bowl. I only know of 1 or 2 places with 20 dollar bowls, but they only make like 20 servings a day. Even the places in Japan, LA or SF bay area that I've been do not charge that much unless you add a ton of extras. It's ramen for crying out loud.

The Place:
Nice place, modern. I guess you would have to expect that much if Mina is involved. Free for all seating.

Food:
While in line, I grabbed the Yuzu Bars. These were good. You can't go wrong with some lemon bars made with yuzu instead. For the ramen, I ordered the Tokyo style kurobuta pork ramen, which was shoyu based broth with the typical fixings of marinated soft boiled egg, bamboo shoots, fresh seaweed, a piece of nori, and some pork belly/chasu. Let's just say my rating is mainly based on the ramen itself. Full disclosure: I admit that I usually don't get the soy sauce based broth, since that's the most boring ramen broth imo. I'm a richer broth kinda guy, so shio/miso/tonkatsu are my usual broths. But this shoyu broth is blaaaannnnd. It might as well have been water. I can't remember that last time I've tried a shoyu broth that was this flavorless. The ramen noodles themselves are also not interesting either. Egg, although marinated, tastes like the pure white soft boiled eggs I make at home, bland. So that brings me to the chasu, which you can guess by now, is also a flavorless chunk of meat. That was one thing I would have expected to have been properly spiced and cooked. All these key elements of a bowl of ramen are really boring. Just "plain" bleh.

As a side note, I did try my friend's miso broth 

Drink:
Ordered a Royal Milk Tea. 4.25?! that was the worse milk tea I've had in a while. Maybe I'm just not into the overly floral flavor of it. But still, 4.25?!

Maybe I will give the donburi a try if I ever go back. Perhaps they got those right.

Bottom line. This is just another place opened up by a famous name and trying to ride the wave of ramen joints. There are way better ramen around the area for much more reasonable prices.
author: Will Y.

description: Good spot for lunch in fidi on a cold day, though getting a table might suck. I had the shoyu ramen which was decent. The portion was pretty big. I couldn't finish it. There's a good amount of chashu and noodles. Should try the honey green tea. The sweetness is very subtle.
author: Kim P.

description: Not mind blowing or even as good as ramen spots I've been to in Japantown. Good but, for the lore and comparative price point, should've been great. Had crab/shrimp dumpling and the chicken ramen.
author: John A.

description: I think it's good. The location is really closed to my office. The price is reasonable in financial district. I tried the spicy ramen and a kind of beef rib blabla... sorry I forget the name. They are good.
author: Qing Y.

description: Meh, A bowl of ramen was $14 and mediocre: the bamboo shoots tasted like they were from a can - the same went for the corn (wet and mushy). The "rich" miso soup tasted watered down or something I couldn't quite figure out.
author: Thomas C.

description: Decent enough ramen place and conveniently in the financial district when needed. Tried hokkaido which was well seasoned but sauce was too thick. The Shoryu ramen was better and was a good mix of taste. Ramen both times were done well, not over and still tangy.
author: Grapes T.

description:
The servers and staff were very friendly and accommodating. Our host/waitress told us that the ramen broths were very light. She suggested getting the mushroom and tofu ramen and adding chasu and eggs if we were used to more heavier broths.

I decided to get the shrimp and crab dumpling ramen with regular ramen noodles. My date decided to get the gluten free noodles with her pork belly ramen. 

The shrimp and crab dumpling was light and very plain. The broth is better described as watered down than light. It lacked flavor. The gluten free noodles were more like spaghetti noodles than your traditional ramen noodles. I should've listened to our waitress' advice about the broth. I would not recommend eating here. There are just too many better alternatives nearby.
author: Hung N.

description: Frankly, a successful kitchen/restaurant should have most aspects aligned even in its first week. Ramen Bar failed this. Thank god I just ordered a simple basic generic pork belly ramen with soy-based broth. I am so turned off by the salty broth & undercooked ramen. Pork belly & the soft boiled egg were fine. Hope it can turn around, yet I m not interested to go back.
author: SW Y.

description:
- The ramen is pretty tasty but it is expensive - the ramen place in the international market is just as good for a lower price 

- The salmon rice bowl is basically a small piece of cooked salmon, white rice and teriyaki sauce. Save the $13.57 and make this at home!

- Overall Ramen Bar is overpriced but the food is pretty good. I would definitely go with the ramen.
author: Laurence S.

description: The Ramen toppings were super good and I liked the food overall, but found the ramen broth to be way to salty for my taste.
author: Brian C.

description:
No Bueno
Overpriced and just not that great. But what else would you expect from Michael Mina at this stage in life?
author: Jon C.

description:
Still a mixed bag -- maybe a work in progress.  Needs Improvement. 

There have been a few changes since the Ramen Bar opened a few months ago; some additional soups on the menu. It also seems that they are tinkering with the flavors. I'd have to say that the jury is still out as I continue to have mixed experiences. The Ramen Bar is located close to my office, so I will likely keep tabs on it.

It's a tough act to enter at the high end price point of the market; Ramen Bar is the priciest ramen joint in town (but perhaps falling a bit short of Rockridge's Ramen Shop). At the high end, you better have a good product. Luckily for the Ramen Bar, the competition in SF is mostly not too strong (unlike further down the Peninsula). 

On some early lunch visits, I found the ramen to be interesting. The broth was unique and unexpected. However, it was a bit too sweet for my taste. The noodles and contents were respectable. Portion size was small and looked funny in the bowl; which seemed too empty.  I tried a donburi once; maybe unique but pretty bad ... I can't recommend a dry donburi. Stick to the ramen.  Lunch is usually crowded and counter order; but the wait is not too long and they started opening room in Pabu next door for the overflow.  Deserts are a high point.  I keep meaning to try breakfast pastries; they coffee is good (if you ask for the expert who can make a proper cappuccino). 

Dinner is table service; the menu is similar with a few additions. The Ramen Bar is not crowded in the evenings. The table service does not do anything to add to the ambiance and is therefor unnecessary. The decor is nice enough for a counter order place. A big sin is lack of a real ramen bar (given the name). Don't go expecting the feel of a Japanese place.

Service is also mixed. Some of the staff is earnest and friendly. The staff can also be poorly trained which degrades the experience. On a recent dinner visit, I found the ramen to be changed; more typical and still tasty (so that's an improvement). However, there were a series of unfortunate events; staff was slow to bring menus, the newly hired waitress was not able to answer questions about the items on the menu, the food server spilled soup on our belongings and placed the wrong orders in front of the diners, the restaurant ran out of the beer on tap that we ordered so after a delay could only bring a partial glass.  Each a little thing (the stained items being the most annoying), but adds up to a, "needs improvement".

The way the staff dealt with mishaps was friendly enough, but also a bit odd. In particular, they charged me full price for a partially full $6 beer and then offered a no-charge glass of the $4 draft in addition. Seems like the thing to do would have been to comp the partially full first beer and then let me order my choice if/when I want more.  

A generous 3 stars at this point.

Ken Ken is probably still the best ramen in SF, if you can put up with the long wait and loud bar-like atmosphere. Or, head over to Ramen Shop for the high priced, not quite Japanese experience.
author: Jice E.

description: I ordered the Avocado Chicken rice bowl. However, the dish did not have avocado on it and did have a couple ingredients not listed on the menu. The waiter confirmed that I did indeed receive the avocado chicken but that they forgot the avocado. Hmm I think it's pretty important if it's in the name... Otherwise, the food was mediocre, especially with the price.
author: Yacoub O.

description:
Note: the 5 star review only applies to the Miso butter ramen with Chasu. I also tried the ginger chicken, which was 'meh'.

The cured egg will change your life.
author: Hans I.

description:
The Ramen Bar is a pretty hip looking place rather than a Japanese restaurant. They have TVs that show off various dishes they make. There's a large dining area in the middle of the restaurant, some bar stools, and an outdoor seating. Even during a busy lunch rush, you should be able to find a table.

== Food ==

Chasu Miso butter hokkadio ramen had a buttery ramen broth, but it tasted pretty good. Let's see... there's braised pork, garlic, sweet corn, and soy-cured egg. The egg tasted great! They made it perfectly. The braised pork was soft and good. Overall, it was a good bowl of ramen.

== Service ==

Order at the counter, receive a number, and they'll bring your ramen to you. Lines may be long, but they move pretty quickly. The wait time for a ramen bowl is around 10 minutes during the lunch hour.

== Overall ==

It's good, but very overpriced. $2 to add a topping is very harsh. If this place was like cheaper, it would definitely have been better. This place doesn't have the wow factor needed to match its premium price.
author: Steven B.

description:
I was finally so excited about a ramen place opening up in FiDi. So close to work! But alas, I probably will not go back.

First, the line gets crazy long at 11:30, so if you want to beat the rush, go early - hopefully this will change once the hype does down.

I ordered the Tokyo Style Pork Ramen. The presentation was nice. However, the first sip of the broth was disappointing. Not very flavorful,and if you're expecting a hearty, thick-ish tonkatsu broth that you're used to, you will not get that. In fact, it tasted pretty bland. The broth is also extra oily. By the end of my meal, I felt like I had smothered pork grease all over my lips. 

The noodles were okay. It was the thin, stringy kind. I much rather prefer the thick noodles they offer at Ramen Yamadaya in japantown. 

The pork itself was okay. It was decently fatty so there was some flavor from that, but again, nothing memorable.

In my opinion, not worth the $12. The only good experience about my meal was the staff. Every single one of them that I interacted with were super friendly and all had smiles on their face.
author: Stephanie L.

description: 4 stars. Superior to ramen bar. Yes it's fusion - get over yourself. Go to LA if you want authentic ramen.
author: Chris C.

description:
Great to sit out at the patio to enjoy your ramen on a warm day. 
BUT how often is it warm in SF?! 
BUT where else can you slurp ramen outdoors?! 

YES on the Happy hour cocktails 
YES on the kind service
OK on the ramen

Taste was not bad, but not out of the world. I appreciate the restaurant for what it is, especially location. 
Ramen and cocktail. Surprising mix [we dont normally do that anywhere else] but I had a fun time.
author: Veranna N.

description: I am giving this place a solid 4 stars. The place it self has a beautiful decoration. The food are good. The inly problem is that the food comes in a not so big portio. Compare to the price you are paying for. And that is why i am giving this place 4 stars.
author: Bryan M.

description: 3 Stars for the yummy noodles, and minus 2 stars for twice in a row not  giving the egg that suppose to come with the ramen when ordered to go!  I would complain but it's too far to walk back during short lunch break.
author: Lola C.

description: Had the Kurabuta Pork Ramen and it was just ok.  Love my noodles but these were just ok.  I did eat at Pabu next door and the food quality was great so I did have high hopes for this place.
author: Spencer Q.

description: Got tokyo shoyu to go and skipped most of the line.   Good stuff.  Excellent broth, not overly salted, maybe a little fat heavy, but tasty.   Good noodles.   Quail eggs were a very nice touch, yolks were the perfect softness.
author: S H.

description:
went there during lunch two weeks ago with couple friends, very busy place, my Tokyo style ramen was super salty, maybe the soy sauce was free that day ? lol . the pork and noodle was all right.

one of my friend ordered some burger (what, in a ramen place?), but he likes it, and looks like it's the right thing to do. I might try that next time, if there is a next time.

STAY AWAY FROM THEIR RAMEN !!!
author: Lindersy F.

description: Great ramen! I came at lunch so they were super busy, was told the wait was about 7 min but after ordering I realized it would take much longer & I had to go to an interview. Asked a kind gentleman in blue shirt who was in charge of to-do order to change it to take out, he promptly accommodated me without any questions. Food was great but I'm writing this mainly for the great service, thank you!
author: T L.

description:
Way better than Ramen Underground and Katana-Ya. 

I got the Tokyo-style Kurobata Ramen. The broth was a little salty, the pork belly wasn't tender enough, and the ramen was decent but needed to be more chewy. All in all pretty good except the price.
author: David H.

description:
I love the idea of a ramen bar. Rob L chose this destination for our Thursday Thursday dinner, so I was really excited to try it out. Who doesn't love a good bowl of ramen on a chilly San Francisco evening? 

As I walked in I noticed the dark grey metal chairs that remind me of my chemistry laboratory. There is also a glass so you can sort of see into the cooking area. I couldn't really get a good look of what was happening from where I sat. Just people cooks shuffling around. I was expecting that a Ramen Bar would have a noodle making station but I didn't see one. 

I really like our waitress. She was really helpful and checked in on us every so often and we never felt rushed. She was quick to help us with drinks. The Ramen Bar has soju on tap! Interesting, no?

Between my crew and I, we immediately noticed that the noodles are not fresh hand made noodles. I'm not sure why I assumed that the noodles here would be home made but it was a disappointment to me that they were supermarket noodles. I liked the soup and I wish it were warmer. It was a cold evening! I ordered the Chicken Ramen and I have to say that the meat wasn't very good. It wasn't terrible but I was hoping for better. The egg, veggies, bamboo, etc. were really good. 

So, basically this place has three stars in my book because I think this place is cute, the service is good, they have soju on tap and I like the soup and veggies in the ramen. However, I have no intentions of coming back to The Ramen Bar unless they make fresh noodles and they step up their game with the meat.
author: Kelly H.

description:
I missed out on new Ramen at the Ramen Yokocho festival in JTown (was super nuts, too many ppl) so wanted to try out the newish place in fidi area for Ramen...  

Sat outside, good wooden tables and chairs with patio umbrellas. 
Had the Hokkaido Miso-Butter Chashu for $14 and beer and saki shots. 
I don't believe there's anything spectacular about the ramen... it's just regular / average / typical.  $2 for extra noodles as there weren't a lot that came with it.

Overall good - but expected more for the cost and the Chef Mina name.
author: Chuck R.

description: Tonight was my third visit and my rating still stands. My boyfriend had the chasu miso butter Hokkaido ramen and the broth was way too salty and thick. I think they put too much miso in or something. I had the ginger braised chicken ramen and it was pretty good. Still seasoning issues going on here and inconstancies, which is why I'm giving it 3 stars.
author: Jessie L.

description:
So I did return because I had friends who really wanted to go. The second time I would give it 2 stars because (a) I found a hair in my ramen, (b) I'm pretty sure they didn't put in the extra noodles I had ordered in my replacement bowl and (c) they didn't reduce the bill at all for the hair.  This time I had the mushroom and soy ramen, which was better than the Hokkaido but not stellar.

Then, believe it or not after the hair incident, I came back a third time (also with a friend - very little wait at lunch).  This was probably the best of the three - but still worth only 3 stars.  This time I had the kurobata pork ramen, which was probably the best of the three I tried but still not good enough to drink alone after finishing the ramen.  No hair this time, though!
author: B. Y.

description:
I used to live in Tokyo. I was expecting much better after all the press this place has received.
Also it took us to notice that our ramens were missing some of the ingredients. We had to alert the waitress, and by the time she came to say that she could bring them now, we had practically finished our ramen. Evidently they had run out and needed to fetch them from the back. Shouldn't they have done that before serving us, and also alerted the waitress? Rookie kind of move. 
The namelaka was boring, just plain old chocolate mousse.
author: Naomi G.

description: I'm from LA so Ramen is everywhere over there. Decided to stop by this Ramen spot after finally finding parking in this beautifully crowded city. Probably one of the best Ramen I've tried. Tonkotsu was so rich and tasty, I actually finished ALLLL my broth which I hardly ever do. Definitely coming back here next time I'm in town. Oh, and the teas are a MUST try. You will not find these anywhere else. ;)
author: Adriana R.

description:
A quality ramen, for certain, stuffed with noodles, thick slices of pork, green onions, greens, bamboo shoots and two halves of a boiled egg.  It's aesthetically pleasing in addition to being tasty.  Unfortunately, their house hot paste is timid at best.  Additionally, getting a seat is a frenetic experience and a number of their staff don't appear to want to be there based on their expressions.

Ramen Bar is good, but given the association with Michael Mina, I expected more.
author: Mark B.

description: The noodles tasted really tough, more like Hong Kong egg noodles. The noodles did not absorb any of the broth flavor. The broth itself was soso. It did not taste complex and rich, more just like salty with soy sauce and miso. The soft boiled eggs were cooked perfectly but it tasted really sweet. $16 excluding tip is pretty expensive. Service was quick and ambiance was good.
author: Sylvia C.

description: So I just drove all the way from LA and I enjoyed my visit. The waitress was polite, and gave my girlfriend and I good suggestions to eat. Polite staff, good food, and nice ambience.
author: Kevin F.

description: Try the vegetarian mushroom ramen. Can't believe it's vegetarian. So creamy. Fried chicken sandwich and burger are good too but you are here for the ramen.
author: Michael R.

description: Thank you super nice guy that rushed my order tonight! You ran me out the back exit and with out a minute to spare, I caught my bus!  I thought the tuna was raw and it would be the quickest choice.  I see now that it's hot!  Thanks for helping even though it was my fault.  All of the workers could see that I was having a slight meltdown. It was the low blood sugar!  I can't wait to get home to eat it.
author: Kelly D.

description: I tried the spicy miso chicken ramen. The portion was good and the flavors were on point...but for $15 (including tax), I don't know if it's worth it. There aren't many ramen options in fidi, so I'd say I would come back if I had a serious craving or if someone else suggested it. There was hardly a wait at exactly 11:30.
author: Musetta S.

description:
What I didn't like was the price. 2 bowls of ramen and 2 beers=43.40. Not including tip. VERY PRICEY for a bowl of ramen (the rent must be super high though).
What I did like was that they have a lot of healthy choices (the yam noodles are wonderful). I also loved the service (Coleman). The location and atmosphere was really nice too. If the price was lower, I'd bump it up a star.
author: S. G.

description:
Really not worth the money. Very little taste at all and the portions of meat ( for a $15 plus bowl) are way short from filling.

I would not go back.
author: thekidd b.

description:
Ordered the pork ramen to go & since it's Michael Mina's ramen bar I had pretty high expectations.

The price point seemed a little higher than other ramen places but I thought that was ok until I opened up the food & saw three tiny little pieces of pork floating around. The most disappointing thing was that the stock was quite bland. It feels like MM/the chef made it so non descript as to meet everyone's flavour profiles instead of making a kick ass stock with some tasty oomph. The servers happily gave us spice additions which were great & made it delicious but I kind of feel those flavours should have been in the stock not DIY. Sadly it's no katanaya.
author: Nicole E.

description: The Hokkaido style ramen! A bit oily but really good!
author: Nikhil B.

description: Seated in the heart of downtown financial district, you are immediately surrounded by the concrete jungle that is fast becoming very Manhattan-esque!  During the daytime it's a wonderful outside to people watch.  By sunset though it can start to get a lil' chilly depending on the time of the year.  The food is just okay and I was not impressed.  It's not bad but not my favorite place.  If I worked downtown, I suppose I would go more often.  But I still head to J-town for my ramen eats...
author: Cary L.

description:
Much hype for this place but not sure if I will go back after my 2nd visit today.

First visit had the pork belly shoyu ramen.

Broth was on the sweet side, so those who like a milky oily tonkatsu broth like me, this may not be it for you. Good fresh ingrediants inside though, egg, seaweed, toppings, the noodles itself are OK, not too chewy, not too soft. Kind of middle of the way noodles. at $13 a bowl, for those with a hearty appetite may not be enough for you. 

2nd visit I got the salmon kewpie donburi. The taste was good but it was just too much spicy kewpie mixed in with the salmon, it was overkill -the sauce is basically the sauce they put into those "jive ass rolls" according to nobu K- you know what i mean! a little would be good but just too much. The crunchy bits of the salmon skin on top were good but sauce was too overpowering. Won't be getting this again, not to mention so unhealthy. Crap that means I have to work out 2x as hard!! Not worth the calories...

all in all...wIth not many ramen choices in the fidi, this is an OK choice but I wouldnt selectively go here at will again.
author: Petri Y.

description: The broth was terrible. Very dark soy taste. I live in Ramen County aka San Mateo. I'll save my appetite and wallet from the pain next time.
author: T O.

description:
The RAMEN Bar.  I saw the sign while walking back to my office from the Embarcadero Plaza buildings.  I couldn't resist and walked on in to place my TO GO order.  First impressions - Clean interior, friendly, approachable staff, and so many deliciously SOUNDING options to choose from.  I opted for the SHRIMP / LOBSTER RAMEN.  The sound of shrimp and lobster swimming in a sea of broth and ramen made my mouth water.  Yes, true.  

I get back to my desk and uncover the RAMEN, and uncover the separately packaged broth.  The broth BARELY covered the RAMEN.  It was JUST ENOUGH.  I received three shrimp and two balls of lobster.  The SHRIMP were fresh and perfectly cooked.  The lobster balls were JUST OK, nothing to rave about.  The broth on the other hand was PERFECTLY SEASONED, tasty, and again JUST enough to cover the contents in the bowl, but BARELY.

I paid $16 for a bowl of RAMEN!!!  16 SMACKAROOS!  I think for that price that I should have been given MORE broth for my RAMEN to swim in!  I felt as though I had to hurry up and eat my RAMEN before the RAMEN noodles soaked it up.

I would order from here again, ONLY if it was for an office function.  

Definitely a place to TRY, however, note to THE RAMEN BAR, if you want to appeal to the hungry FIDI crowd, please don't SKIMP on the BROTH.  Really.....please??

3 STARS - More broth would take this to 4 STARS, and better tasting lobster balls would make this a perfect 5 STAR BOWL of RAMEN.

First time here, I haven't tried anything else so limited in rating options.
author: Ana W.

description: I came here for lunch for the second time today. I actually used the app to pre-order in an effort to avoid the line and save some time. Unfortunately, after walking one block with our lunch, the bag broke and pork ramen spilled all over my coworker's jacket. Since we were starving and didn't want to wait in another FIDI lunch line, we decided to go back and explain what happened. The GM Natalie handled the situation amazingly. She sincerely apologized for the accident and inconvenience. She immediately offered to remake our entire lunch and while we waited, she made us complimentary Boba Tea-Tails. She even offered to cover the cost of dry-cleaning my co-worker pork ramen saturated jacket. What started off as a frustrating and disappointing situation, ended so well. Natalie truly understands what great customer service is and I would be happy to go back for more delicous ramen again.
author: Michele V.

description:
I had higher hopes for this place, and I have tried two of the Ramen dishes two days in a row. I have tried the "HOKKAIDO" MISO-BUTTER CHASHU and TOKYO-STYLE KUROBUTA PORK, and neither had much flavor or Umami. 

Ramen Underground on Kearny is much better, their broth is much heavier and substational. 

Also the best place I know of is Ramen Shop in Oakland. 

Think this place needs an overhaul of it's dishes. 

The pork was dry and overcooked.

The eggs were cooked perfectly.

I really wanted to love this place since it is closer to my office, and i ma sure if I am really in the mood for Ramen I will go....but it should be sooooo much better.
author: Thomas G.

description: My wife brought me home a poke bowl for dinner and I was really excited. However, the Poke bowl was really boring and the fish did not taste fresh. I told my wife while eating I've had a better Poke bowl in Fresno than this place. Complete disappointment.
author: Skyler R.

description: I'm eating my words. Gave Ramen Bar another shot, had the chichken ramen and they nailed it. I've been thinking about my original review and felt the need to adjust the rating. I will admit when I'm wrong. So I'm happy to give this place another star and will continues to check in from time to time and hopefully increase my rating. And I must say they nailed the chicken. It was really good!
author: Olivia W.

description:
This place is just "meh." I go because the location is convenient and the wait isn't too bad. I always leave feeling a bit disappointed, like I overpaid for very average ramen. The ginger chicken ramen isn't gingery enough and the chicken was cold today. The soy-steeped egg that comes in most of the Ramen Bowls is amazing though. I usual add and extra one to my order. 

If you can afford to wait in line, go to Ramen Underground instead.
author: MorePeas S.

description: I have tasted better ramen. I ordered the Hokkaido no onion. It came out cold. I asked them to make it warm. It came out warm with onion. The broth is salty, chicken has no flavor!! It is steam chicken. I came here because pabu wasn't open until 11:30.
author: Linda L.

description: With the ramen hype going cray, competition for top ramen is fierce throughout the Bay Area from Orenchi to Dojo and the newcomers. The Ramen Bar is a more casual restaurant than you would consider when it comes to the Michael Mina name. You order at the counter and wait for food to be brought to you in a semi self-serve format. The ramen is not bad but lacks the touch you get at some of the smaller family spots. There are some creative options on the menu but seems overly sophisticated without the best execution. Calling this a Michael Mina restaurant would be putting lipstick on a pig. On the plus side, they have a great selection of desserts made next door which are Japanese fusion inspired.
author: Ed L.

description:
I wanted to like this place since it's associated with Michael Mina, but it didn't live up to its hype at all. There was nothing special about their broth, which is really a distinguishing factor for ramen bars. The chicken in my ginger-braised chicken was dry at best.

When I came here with some coworkers, the waitress wasn't even wearing anything that distinguished her as having worked there, so it was very confusing when she just came up to our table while we waited for our food and handed us napkins & chopsticks and didn't say anything! My coworkers and I all literally thought she was some rando stranger! At least have the courtesy to greet us if you're going to serve our table?!

As many others have mentioned, the $14 price tag was a huge rip-off. If this place is going to charge that much, they should learn a thing or two from Dojo Ramen in San Mateo or Ippudo & Totto Ramen in NY.
author: Connie Y.

description: My last two experiences with The Ramen Bar have been underwhelming.  Which really sucks since they are on the ground floor of my office building and really convenient.  I'm about halfway through my grilled chicken ramen right now and I am just bored.  It's kind of tasteless.  Supposedly there is ginger in the broth but I can't tell.  I've ordered this particular ramen in the past and really liked it.  Something has changed.  And, about a month ago, I ordered the ramen with pork belly but the pork tasted "off" so I did not finish it.  Really too bad.  In the future I'll walk a little further when I want Ramen.  Lee's is right around the corner and their ramen is decent and a lot cheaper.
author: Susan H.

description: Ordered take out for team dinner. Ordered a rice and 3 Ramen and a soft shell crab. Got to office to unpack and found out there was no soft shell crab. So I highly recommend you check your items before leaving. First time a restaurant messed up a takeout order by skipping an item for me so I learned my lesson.
author: Kevin W.

description: The ramen soup was excellent, really fresh and tasty! The spices at the table made the bouillon extra delicious.
author: Åsa G.

description:
i came here on a friday night with a girl friend. we met up to do christmas shopping, but of course ended up craving ramen instead. we meandered over to the restaurant from union square. it was a bit of a walk, but still not too shabs.

the restaurant is located in a plaza at the ground floor of the 101 california building. there's a pretty good amount of 2-4 person tables, as well as seating along the counter. my friend and i chose the counter seating, so we had a first hand view of the assembly-line preparation of the ramen. the broth is prepared in the kitchen, and the bowl is handed to worker #1 outside the kitchen. he adds the noodles, then passes the bowl to workers #2 and #3, who adds the individual ingredients (meat, spinach, corn, etc). workers #3 and #4 were there for extra hands. it almost looked like a chipotle/subway-esque of ramen preparation. not sure i was very fond of it, since i feel like there were 5 people doing the job required of only 1 person, but i can understand that it's an efficient meal prep method for if/when the place gets busy. when i was there though, it seemed like 4 of them were standing around for a majority of the time trying to look busy.

i ordered the tokyo style ramen ($12) and my friend ordered the chasu miso-butter hokkaido ($14). the broth in the tokyo style was lighter and more appealing to my taste buds. i tried my friend's chasu miso-butter hokkaido broth, which was also delicious, but it was significantly richer and would probably make me feel bloated and really uncomfortable after the meal.

my ramen came with wakame (seaweed), a tender perfect piece of chashu, spinach, corn, and a soy-braised egg (hard boiled with a runny yolk, amaze). the noodles were tender but nothing extremely out of the ordinary. the ramen ingredients were pretty standard and up to par, except for the corn. to be honest, it tasted like the frozen corn you buy bagged in the freezer at the market. meh but the other ingredients mostly made up for it.

overall it was a good bowl of ramen, but i'm not entirely convinced it was worth the price. it's a convenient location, but i think i would only come here if i were in the area.
author: Caitlin C.

description: I have never seen a worse run line in my life. You have empty tables and people who have been waiting to order for 25 minutes and one cashier. Ramen is popular because it is basic get amazing, maybe take a que from than
author: Lea W.

description: Have been here several times due to its proximity to my office. Each time I've come in with high hopes considering the name attached to the place and each time I've left pretty disappointed. Celebrity chef restaurants are often hit-or-miss, and this one definitely falls in the latter. Really don't know what else to say besides that it is just not very good.
author: Rob C.

description: Interior was nice. Service was good. Drinks were good. Food was kinda ho-hum. Had to reach for extra spice for my tonkotsu ramen. The Hokkaido ramen had a better broth.
author: Sunny C.

description:
FULL DISCLOSURE: I AM NOT A RAMEN EXPERT! 

In my endless quest for lunch in the Financial District (5 years), I was thrilled when I saw that Ramen Bar had opened up. Something new and different! I don't have much time for lunch usually so I opted to order ahead. You can order ahead through their website or you can download the app and order through your mobile. You can even specify the time you want to pick up your food! I've ordered lunch from here three times and haven't had any issues with the payment system or my order being wrong. It's easy and convenient and you don't have to wait in line with all the other schmucks. 

For my first time I ordered the Tokyo Style Kurobuta Pork ramen ($12). I loved the fixings. The wakame and egg and the pork. That pork was delicious and had a great texture. I think that because I was in a hurry, the noodles didn't get enough time in the broth before I tried eating them and I wasn't a fan. They were sort of chewy and the broth didn't really get soaked up in them. Personally, this broth was too light for me. It had a good umami flavor but it was sort of one dimensional. It could have used a dash or salt or something. 

My second visit I had the Beef Kare don buri (rice plate, $12) and I added an egg ($2). This is a curry dish and it's great. It's spicy and savory and filling. I was completely satisfied with that lunch. 

My latest order was the Shrimp & Crab Dumpling ramen ($16). Man, that is a winner lunch right there. I felt that the broth was a little more flavorful than the Tokyo ramen one. The lady that gave me my order also recommended the chef's special spicy sauce so I tried it. It was perfect. The ramen dish had a southern feel to it with the shrimp and corn and spicy sauce. I love those flavors. This time I also ate the fixings first and let the ramen soak longer in the broth. I must also add that the takeout spoon provided has an excellent design. The edge is squared off but at an angle and it's perfect for cutting the noodles a bit. I know it's somewhat taboo to cut your noodles but when you're eating this at your desk, you don't want to be slurping noodles so this utensil is fantastic. Thank you, spoon gods! When I finally got to the noodles, they were nearly perfect. The broth had absorbed some extra flavor from the spicy sauce and it was quite wonderful. 

I must say that I'm a little more of a pho person and I'm partial to the rice noodles. There is just something about these noodles that I am not completely thrilled about. Maybe it's because when I order take out they keep the broth separate and the noodles don't soak up the broth long enough but, I mean how long must they soak before I like them? 

I'll be back and check out some more menu items. If you're coming here for lunch, order ahead. I don't want to hear you complaining if you show up at noon and you have to wait in line. Order ahead or get over it.
author: Daisy S.

description:
Probably won't go back for a long time. My soup was not very hot. Kind of Luke warm. I'm Asian and you can't drink soup like that. Then my soft boiled egg was cold so i had to try to keep it warm in the Luke warm soup. I was too hungry to complain. 

Over rated like pabu for a Michael minna???  I'd expect more.
author: CR L.

description: Ginger Chicken Ramen, is very meh. Wasn't a fan of the flavors, rather the lack of flavors and the price. For the $14 spent, I figured it would be amaze-balls good, but nope. I won't be back and have asked around the office and Underground Ramen seems to be the spot in the FiDi. Save your money and your taste buds.
author: Ezra B.

description: For the 1st day I say they hit it out of the park!  I loved the pork belly ramen! The flavor was really good.  The outside sitting area is really nice, a very nice lunch experience.
author: David G.

description:
This review is for the milk tea!  5 stars for being yummy and fun, but minus one star for being super expensive.

After my disappointment about the online menu being outdated, the wonderful restaurant manager Natalie contacted me to apologize and offer me my mason jar drink.  I ordered the lychee oolong (I absolutely LOVE lychee) with boba, and it had great flavour.  She told me it was her favourite one too.  Now I have my new mason jar and I will definitely bring it back when I eat there again.  To date I've had 5 or 6 different ramens there plus the pork buns, and I'm excited to move on to the rice dishes.

Please do take the outdated milk tea menu offline though, and replace it with the current menu.  Another customer might be upset to have to pay $2 (which represents 40% more) for a mason jar milk tea drink.
author: Michelle L.

description: Had the Farm Chicken Donburi because I craved rice. It was delicious. The soft boiled egg is perfection. The variations of the chicken were equally flavorful. The pudding is smooth, creamy & yummy.
author: mal u.

description: Ramen is legit. It is Shoyu ramen. While I was eating it, I was transported back to ramen joints near train stations. It is not TONKOTSU (pork bone broth, not to be confused with Tonkatsu, which is fried pork "Katsu"=cutlet) and if you are not familiar with it, yes, it maybe salty (Shoyu is salty). Folks, educate yourself and learn the fine art of Ramen before you add your low-star review. I was as skeptical, because on a non-Japanese restaurateur opening another Ramen shop. I'm glad I was not disappointed. It was also good to see both chef Tominaga-San and Michael Mina himself making Ramen.
author: Yasuo S.

description: I had the mushroom ramen and it was fantastic. The broth was creamy and super rich. The portion was huge. I think it was better than Ramen underground. Can't wait to go back! Highly recommended!
author: Yuliya D.

description: I am on a mission to try all of the ramen places in the city! This establishment has been recommended to me by several people. We cam here on a Monday morning, around 11am. The place was completely empty. You order your dish at the counter and then sit down with a number they give you. I got the Tokyo ramen with added corn ($2 for corn is preeety steep and it was AS BUTTERY as I expected). I thought the bowl of my ramen was pretty decent but nothing mind blowing. The shoyu egg was alright, the broth was a bit on the salty side, the chashu was pretty decent. All in all I think Ramen underground is actually much better but I would come here again out of convenience.
author: Katya O.

description: I have no idea what the poor reviewers are talking about. I love Ramen and this place was perfect. The Ginger Braised Chicken Ramen was superb. Just the right amount of all ingredients. I will be returning with friends.
author: Brandon A.

description: Delicious! Super friendly and patient staff. Everything on the menu is delicious, so you can't go wrong. Some items are pricier than others, but overall fair for the area. Will definitely come back on my next trip to SF.
author: Neuftearia S.

description:
Update:
Been going back past few weeks and noticed they're more generous with their chasu now (2 pieces standard).  Also, no missing extras in my to-go orders, although they're still a little skimpy on the soup base.

Anyhow, kudos on the improvements. 3.5 stars
author: Jerry Y.

description:
I am totally perplexed by the lesser recent reviews on Ramen Bar. Went yesterday for lunch and I have not one complaint - it was flawless and so yummy! To address some common themes from recent reviews:

- portion size: I'm sorry, but these portion sizes are not too small. Unless you typically eat a 5-course meal for lunch and that's your benchmark, it's plenty of food. I had the roasted chicken ramen with no extras, and I couldn't even finish the broth I was so full. Also, there was a nice amount of chicken, a whole egg and lots of yummy greens. 

- price: $12 for a huge bowl of delicious ramen. In FiDi. Brought to you by Michael Mina. What's the issue here? 

- taste: other reviews complain about the broth being either bland or too salty. My chicken broth and my husband's pork broth were neither. They were both extremely flavorful yet delicate. We both added some of the spicy paste and it added just the right amount of kick. Yum. 

- service/seating: there was a long line but it went fast. We went at 1pm so it was the height of the lunch rush. But by the time we ordered, there were 3 spots inside to choose from to sit. Food came out about 10 min later. Easy!

Anyhow, really glad I went to see for myself. Not sure why the haters. I love the place and can't wait to go back.
author: Chrissy T.

description: It's a nicely appointed fast casual spot  & the staff was really nice. the noodles are not made in house I believe they are using Sun Noodles as their supplier. I had the Hokkaido Chasu Ramen  & an Imported Asahi Original Dark with the meal for a grand total of $23.47 . I felt it was defenitly on the pricey side for Ramen even though it comes with all the accompaniments which allot of other places up charge you for.the broth was flavorful with just the right amount of fat. Noodles were perfectly Al'dente the accompanying goodies were all delicious. The Chasu was a bit chewy & the cured egg was a bit overcooked also see my photos for clarification. It's a good  place to visit I believe the prices don't justify it as being a weekly stop though. Go ahead & give them a visit who knows you may agree with me or not? But it is worth stopping in & deciding for yourself. I'd give it another star if they had executed the food a bit better.
author: Mr. D.

description: Sadly, this didn't meet expectations. My dining partner had the butter broth, which was nice, but my broth was lacking in flavor and the noodles lacked in texture. She ordered chasu and I ordered the Kurobata pork and they were identical! The egg wasn't cooked well, and it was cold. Disappointingly expensive for what it was. I'll stick to Katana-ya or Ramen Underground for downtown ramen.
author: Mi M.

description: I've been here a few times, mainly because its so convenient located just below my office.  The lines have simmered down since it's grand opening.  The shrimp and crab ramen is meh , gyudon donburi is good, and the coffee jelly dessert is excellent!  Other items I've had over and over again is the HK milk tea & Royal Milk tea, both with boba (cost is around $4.30).  Overall lunch could cost you almost $20 at this place.  I hate the fact that it cost an extra $2 to add an egg to your ramen.  Isn't that a standard ramen ingredient?
author: Erika C.

description: I was trying to remain optimistic despite the negative reviews, but now will have to agree with the other yelpers.  My fiance and I both had the "HOKKAIDO" MISO-BUTTER CHASHU" ramen and the duck special for app.  Ramen was not impressive, the broth was pretty flat.  The outdoor patio was pretty cool, but a longer wait time.  The "MATCHA GREEN MILK TEA" was delish and I loved the little pastries and desserts!  Overall, the desserts and service were more impressive than the food.
author: Esther K.

description: Stopped by here with a friend.  Had gluten free chicken ramen.  Was great.  I hate very hot soup and this was just right!
author: Adam C.

description: Just ordered the Pork Belly Ramen to go. It's way too disappointed. The ramen texture is very floury,mushy and not chewy, AT ALL! The soup base is not delicious and seems like it is straight from some manufactures. The only one star I give is for the staff' friendliness and neat-n-clean location.  Hope they can improve the quality of the ramen in the future.
author: Mike P.

description: This ramen is really good.  I went with the Pork Hokkaido - nice and rich, great cured egg, perfect noodles, and I really liked the sweet corn.  All components were very good, I don't know or care how this all compares to other amazing spots in the bay area, I have not doubt you can rattle off plenty of spots that are better.  I would agree with you.  Those are all going to be exceptional, which would make this place still really good.  I do prefer Underground, but that's because I like the spicier broth.  This place is still a really great lunch option downtown.  I'm dinging them one for the price, I'm not into 15 dollar lunches, at least not too often :)
author: Jon S.

description:
came here for lunch. had the braised pork belly ramen.  meh. the broth lacked depth of flavors.  it just tasted like salt and soy sauce.  the noodles were nicely al dente. the pork belly was very flavorful and delicious, but i wished they had given more than just three tiny slivers. overall, the ramen was disappointingly mediocre.

service was excellent, and ambiance was fun.
author: Peter M.

description: Love this place. Great staff, quick service and not to mention delicious food. The pork ramen is heavenly and I love the soy cured egg. Also recommend the donburi short rib curry when (on that rare occasion) ramen is not doin it for you. Dont miss out on the boba or the soy caramel dessert!
author: Sydnee S.

description: Overpriced for just ehh ramen.  I ordered the "HOKKAIDO" Miso-Butter Chashu (braised pork, garlic, sweet corn, soy-cured egg)  $14  I tried my friend's Spicy Miso Chicken and thought the broth tasted a bit better.  Just a bit. The service was great though.
author: Tammy N.

description: Great ramen! Probably the best I've found in SF so far. Also, I really appreciate that they have more to their menu than just ramen. A lot of great places do ramen well, but that's about it. The Ramen Bar has much more (and sake). Very reasonably priced.
author: Mike W.

description: Another super hyped-up ramen place by a famous chef. I walked in completely sold on the pork ramen because of the staff's enthusiastic recommendation.  A few friends of mine have gone already and were not impressed but I was up for giving it a try. The Tokyo-style kurobuta pork ramen was horrible. The texture of the noodle underwhelming the broth lacks depth. "Awe-inspiring" in the sense that press coverage is so one-directional. This place far from good nor authentic.
author: Eve H.

description:
Given all the less-than-glowing reviews, I was hesitant to come here, but did so anyway. And I'm glad I did.

We sat outside at one of their lovely tables and enjoyed our ramen soup and sweets.  The tofu soup was very flavorful and full of interesting veggies.  Although I've had ramen in Tokyo, I am anything but an expert, so can't speak for its authenticity.  

The various sweets, including French-style jelly candies (in coconut, mango and strawberry) were fantastic and reasonably priced at $2 a bag.

The service was great, prices average and location in the 101 California plaza very nice.

I'll definitely be returning.
author: Jane D.

description:
Work near this place so I've had my eye on it, so so so excited for it to open. Now that it's open and I've had a few interactions with the place (ahem, note I didn't say meal), I can review it.

Before making an official date with someone, I pop in to ask about gluten free ramen. Turns out, they have gluten free noodles available (COOL!!), but I can only order one broth, and I have to ask for the egg to be omitted, because it's cured in soy sauce. Hm. You make a big fuss about having gluten free noodles, but don't label anything else? That tells me this place knows about gluten-free the TREND, but not gluten-free the LIFE NECESSITY. I could go on a real rant about this, but it's too early for that. Strike one.

The cashier that I questioned was nice, so I decided to try their iced green tea. I can't stand the sweetness that's in 80% of prepared drinks, so I was crossing my fingers. I was surprised to find that it WAS SO BITTER! I can't imagine how awful it must have been to someone who likes sweet drinks. I shouldn't have finished it, but I paid way too much to throw it out. Strike two.

I decide to try this place for breakfast. Get there at 8:15am, we're informed that they don't serve ramen until 11, which it says nowhere on their website. STRIKE THREE, aaaaaand I no longer have any interest in you, Ramen Bar!

JK I'll be back when I can't resist ramen any more. If anyone knows of any good gluten free ramen, please message me! 

Three stars because I'm crossing my fingers that this place gets its act together, cause the service, concept, and location are all great.
author: Jackie C.

description: Went there for lunch with coworks. Waited in line for about 20 mins even we arrived around 12:40pm. Service was quick after we ordered our food. I tried the pork belly ramen and a few desserts. Everything was good except the ramen - not chewy at all, which I think it's an essential quality for a good bowl of ramen. Mina needs a stopwatch!
author: Fonda C.

description: Spicy miso butter ramen wasn't bad. Pork was flavorful and the noodles were a good texture. The broth was a bit salty for me. I liked that there was no wait at dinner time. I would come back to try other stuff or to check out happy hour.
author: Melinda C.

description: If you like super salty you may enjoy this. I do enjoy adding pink himalayan sea salt to my meals so I consider myself a fan of salt, however....this place is heavy handed on sodium. My fingers are bloating as I write this.  The egg is tasty and the fact they offer gluten free noodles is a plus. And, all the "grab and go" salads and treats look good.
author: Amy E.

description: Employee in the order line misgendered me, and then misgendered me again after I corrected them. Won't be coming back.
author: Kara Q.

description: I'm a big fan of this place. I love the location and the service is so fast. Great ramen too. The egg is awesome and really flavored. I'm very pleased with all these new ramen places popping up.
author: Tara S.

description:
Let's start off by saying I didn't have high expectations.  Yes it is is Michael Mina restaurant and that's part of the reason why.  His flagship is very good but I don't see him and ramen going together even if he hired an expert.

This area of California st. is not an area I venture to but since it was a meeting and the restaurant was close by we decided to try it out.  We ordered a few things to share; cha shu ramen with an extra side of pork belly, chicken donburi and the salmon salad.  The salmon salad was decently made.  Cold noodles on the bottom with greens that didn't have too much dressing makes for a good summer dish.  The ramen on the other hand was not that great (not saying disappointing because I didn't have much expectations).  I can't pin point what is wrong with the noodles but the texture and the taste just didn't feel right.  The pork flavor soup tasted and looked more like soy sauce flavor.  The pork belly were teeny tiny pieces so if you are looking for meat order the cha shu which is a larger piece of meat but was way too tough.  They did get one thing right in the ramen and that was the egg.  The chicken donburi came with diced up chicken breast meat, fried chicken and chicken meat balls.  They should turn this into a fried chicken bowl because that's really the only piece of meat that was good.  I'm really not interested in paying $12 for diced up chicken meat that was covered in what seemed to be teriyaki sauce.  The fried chicken was good enough for us to ask if we can do a side order which they were kind enough to do.  I could also have done without the chicken meatball which tasted more like a beef meatball.

Service was good, friendly as they allowed us to do a side order of the fried chicken and when we asked questions they were happy to answer.  The manager (I think) also asked for our feedback.  They aren't familiar with their products though as we asked them about the candy they were selling to go (looks like pate de fruits) and they told us the flavors were yuzu, orange and I think raspberry.  I've only had the white one and the orange one and the flavors were coconut and mango.  Just an fyi, the confectioneries are properly priced and are good to eat when you want something sweet so pick up one or two.

It's California street in Financial District so you're bound to be paying a few dollars more for ramen, donburi and other stuff but if I'm paying more I would like to see better quality and a little more quantity as well.
author: Pierre L.

description:
My friend and I met up for lunch at the Ramen Bar. The ramen dishes we ordered were good. 

It's definitely not like the Ramen Shop in Berkeley but for the price and location, I will definitely return.

My friend also ordered the bubble tea, Hong Kong style and it was delicious.

Staffs were exceptional.
author: Sophia L.

description:
I cannot for the life of me understand the hate this place generates. 

The ramen is delicious!! It's downtown, in a great location, and it's relatively fast. Did I mention each proper bowl comes with a marinated, soft boiled egg? 

I don't know what's wrong with people, and I don't care how many goddamn times you've been raised in Japan.
author: Mary C.

description: The crispy tofu salad was amazing.   I added extra greens to my order.  I will probably dream about it.   My friend had the ginger glazed chicken ramen and said it was just ok.  For my salad alone, five stars.
author: Kristen S.

description: Fast lunch spot. Not authentic broth but tasty none the less. The ramen egg is done almost perfectly. Maybe a dollar or two too much for the value. ($12 for ramen bowl). Clean environment with dark wood ambiance. Would come again if near.
author: Griselda Z.

description: Overall I thought the ramen was very tasty; broth tasted great and the ingredients where fresh. Totally recommend getting a cocktail from Pabu and bringing it over. Shared a ramen with my spouse and thought it was a good portion.  I think people have been too critical of this place, solid ramen at a financial district price point.
author: Monette H.

description:
Overpriced japanese food... I got the kurobuta donburi and the matcha milk tea w boba..

The pork was not tender and juicy at all.. The matcha milk tea w boba was just so so..

Nothing spectacular..

Paid $18 in total and was disappointed with the quality of the food... Would not go back again...
author: Diana W.

description:
Had the ginger chicken ramen. Didn't taste bad, but definitely not worth how much it cost. I've had much better for a lower price elsewhere. 

Overall impression was disappointing.
author: Corey D.

description:
we ordered takeout on their app which was super simple! 

then i go to pick it up - around 11:45a - place is packed, line out the door

i walk in straight to the front and tell them my name, he confirms my order and then hands me one bag. which i thought was strange since there were two ramen orders and two donburi bowls. then in a hurry, i go back to my car and look in and see that there are two orders missing. 

a bit pissed, i return and he said he forgot the other bag... okay whatever...

anyways--- 
to-go packaging is really nice, well designed. overall, all the eggs were cooked perfectly. not sold on ramen for take out... they just made it so easy i thought i could trust them. you end up having to reheat the broth and then the noodles get stuck together and you really have to work to get them to separate enough to eat (without causing a mess). they give you a good portion of ramen noodles and all the meat was delicious. the broth could use some work and the chicken rice bowl just was nothing good or bad. just was... 

TOKYO STYLE KUROBUTA PORK - ok.. broth wasn't tasty enough
"HOKKAIDO" MISO-BUTTER CHASU - yummy! would come back for this
FARM CHICKEN donburi - no bueno 
BEEF KARE- very delicious! great flavor in the curry. 

would definitely like to try dine-in next time and see how they do.
author: Shanna N.

description: Inedible.  Ordered the chicken ramen.  The broth was so fishy and off-tasting I couldn't handle it.  Was working late, and hoping for a yummy dinner to make it suck less to be in the financial district at 8 p.m., but instead threw this away and went hungry.
author: Carri M.

description: Seriously? That's ramen? I'd rather eat instant noodle at home that costs much less than this super sweet and super salty ramen. The pork belly is a joke. Super thin with the fat still in solid instead of melting soft. I had bad ramen before but never felt scammed like this. This is the worst.
author: Alice Y.

description: This place rocks.  This area needed some Ramen.  The customer service is always great and the management is professional and attentive.  I usually get the pork belly ramen with the egg and am totally satisfied.  Interesting spin on ramen - Michael Mina style.  Nom nom nom
author: Danielle M.

description: Excited to try this place.   Long line at lunch but the line moved quickly and found a seat fairly fast. Service was quick too! BUT.....yes,  there is a BUT.....ordered the Don buri gyudon and wow. SO MUCH rice.......VERY LITTLE MEAT.  VERY UNBALANCED. For $12? Really? Don't think I'll visit this place again.....Unless u want really expensive rice.
author: Patricia Z.

description:
Went here with some friends. We tried the pork, chicken, and mushroom ramen. All were excellent. The broths, even the "thinner" chicken one, were thick and robust. Great flavors all around. I would gladly eat any of those three soups again and am having difficulty picking a favorite.

I didn't try any of the salads or rice dishes but liked what I saw heading to other tables. Everything on their menu seems at very least worth a try.
author: Josh F.

description: Nice servers, and okay ambiance.  I ordered the ginger chicken, but my ramen was way too salty.  Im surprised it's a Michael Mina restaurant.
author: Keshia H.

description:
I ordered the miso and corn ramen and added the pork belly (it comes with chasu by default) and my bf ordered the tokyo style pork ramen adding chasu (it already has pork belly). He also subbed gluten free noodles. Royal milk tea that we ordered had a cardamom flavor to it, which was good but not expected. Matcha milk tea was also good. Both might have had a little too much ice in them but it was still good tea. 

The actual bowls of ramen were underwhelming. I had a taste of his broth--it was porky and sweet but had a fairly thick layer of oil on top. His gluten free noodles were more slippery feeling and chewier then the regular noodles--they are a great sub for regular ramen noodles if you have celiac (We asked and they are made in house).

My bowl of miso ramen was fairly bland despite the "heavier style" it is noted to have on the menu. It had little miso flavor with a slight bit of heat from some peppers as a finish. I had to doctor up the broth with a little togarishi spice and soy sauce but it still tasted bland. Noodles and egg were cooked well but the egg had a very delicate soy flavor. I wouldn't have minded if it had been flavored more strongly. The chasu was good but I have had more tender versions. The pork belly are not the cubes of soy braised meat you are used to from other place, it is actually thinly sliced and without any skin. There was little difference in taste between the pork belly and the chasu as they had the same flavor--just one has more fat. 

The service from the wait staff was actually really good, but the ramen is a miss.
author: Crystal L.

description: came here on a rainy day, it was packed but not a bad line to order, and didn't take that long for my to-go order to be ready. I got the tokyo style ramen, and i found it pretty satisfying. I don't eat ramen often, and I've never been to Japan, so I really wouldn't know bad or good ramen if it hit me in the head, but I did enjoy this and would go back especially on another rainy day. i found the staff to be friendly and helpful as well.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Had the Tokyo Style Ramen and was wonderful, big and tasty! There was a huge queue during lunch hour but even so we managed to get seated in 15 minutes. Will return to try other dishes as soon as possible.
author: Victor F.

description: I had no idea that this great little ramen place had opened so close to my building, and am happy to have found it. While it's a bit too pricey to be an everyday lunch place (I paid $15 for a tokyo-style bowl of ramen, including tax and tip), I thought the ramen was really fresh and flavorful. This will be a great chilly-day treat on the weekdays.
author: Rachel A.

description: A little on the pricey side for most items but you get quite a bit of tasty ramen. I would recommend that you check this place out at least once. Careful about going during lunch or dinner rush as it gets quite crowded. The decor and ambiance is nice as well.
author: J S.

description: The food was good. I wish they have more ramen choices since it's named the ramen bar ... Currently there's just one pork ramen, one chicken ramen, and one vegetarian.
author: Xinwei L.

description: I had Tokyo style, and it was fine, but the roasted pork fillet was too much of western taste. That was not Tokyo style. That was Tokyo-like style.
author: Takuma Y.

description: I had high hopes and expectations (probably a bad sign if I'm starting a review with that phrase), as the menu looked good. I got the Hokkaido ramen and it didn't really impress me--seemed overpriced compared to much better ramen I've had elsewhere in the city. The broth was good, but was otherwise mediocre. Also had a Kirin and a shot of sake.
author: Maximillian M.

description: I actually really love their ramen, especially the chashu ramen. The place is cool and hip, the ramen bowl is huge, and its tasty overall! I just hate how its so expensive.. 12-14 dollars for ramen?!
author: Briana N.

description: I didn't have very high hopes so I wasn't that disappointed.  But you guys?  Fancy ramen is not a thing.  The emperor has no clothes.  This tasted no better than shopping mall food.  Sai Wai in the Sunset would laugh in the face of this ramen while offering you a bowl of something utterly soul quenching for $3-$5 less.  Why eat here?  The line at Ramen Underground is too long for you?
author: Olivia W.

description: I was really excited about the opening of this place! It is a nice looking restaurant, and the service is good. I tried the pork belly ramen and my coworker had the roast chicken ramen. My pork belly ramen broth, though not terrible, lacked depth and had mainly just a delicate soy-sauce flavor. The roast chicken broth was more flavorful but still pretty light. The meat in both of our bowls was a bit dry. The egg was on the smaller side though done well. The noodles were okay. Overall, overpriced for what you get. I may come back to try the donburi bowls though!
author: Grace M.

description: If you are craving ramen - don't go here, you will be disappointed.  The broth is literally soy sauce and water. My bowl of ramen was $16 and I left the restaurant so let down.  I can't understand why this place is so hyped (well actually I can because of the MM name) but this guy has no business doing a ramen bar with salty water as broth.
author: Jenn T.

description: Got the Tokyo one (#1). Don't think it stacks up. Broth just tasted like soy sauce. Noodles okay; 1 piece of pork was really tough; the char Sui was good; egg was perfectly cooked. I won't be back.
author: Alton Y.

description: Pork belly ramen was tasty and I liked the reasonable portion size. The milk bread was also delicious. Some kinks to work out, but this isn't a bad alternative to the $13 salad options in this area.
author: Ari D.

description: Expensive, flavorless ramen; primarily in the broth which is what makes or breaks a good bowl of ramen. Sticking to Japan town moving forward for flavor.
author: Cat P.

description:
After hearing so much hype about this place,we visited on a cold afternoon, looking forward to some tasty ramen.  Noodle soup is one of my main food groups (any asian kind, doesn't matter, thai, vietnamese, japanese.  Im not even that picky!)

I almost never give one star reviews, but this was the first bowl of ramen that I did not eat.  ever.  in my life.  The broth was so overwhelmingly salty, it was inedible.  i tried to just eat the noodles, but they were soggy and gross.  after a few bites, i gave up.  

This is super casual, like you order at a counter, and they drop it off to where you sit.  I am not the kind of person to send food back, so its irrelevant, but even if i wanted to, theres no service to tell it to, and what are you going to do, carry it up to the register person taking orders?

This place is garbage.  Don't waste your time or money.  There are so many other ramen places in SF that are actually good.
author: CC C.

description:
I love soup - all kinds but especially noodle soups. So when I realized the Ramen Bar had opened, I had my husband BART into the city so we could have lunch. We had a late lunch (2pm) and the outside tables were all full so we stood near them until one opened up. It's been beautiful weather lately; simply could not sit inside.

I had the Tokyo Style Kurobuta Pork ramen ($12) and a glass of on-tap cold sake and my husband had the Shrimp and Crab dumpling ramen ($16) and a glass of on-tap Kirin beer. The service was prompt and he explained the condiments on the table. 

My overall impression is that I think the Pho restaurant in Embarcadero 3 provides better value and I love adding fresh bean sprouts, cilantro and a squeeze of lime to the soup. The toppings on the ramen here were scant and the broth was really oily. Not sure why; I did not taste sesame so it wasn't added as a flavor. I thought it might have b/c the 2 pork slices in my soup had some fat in them but my husband's broth was oily too (his had 2 shrimps and 2 crab dumplings which looked suspiciously like fake crab was used). 

The waitperson did inquire how everything was and I mentioned that, to which he responded that the broth did look more oily than usual and thanks for the feedback. But mostly, it seems like a noodle lunch, even with a whole egg in each dish. May try again to see if the salads or Donburi are better; it may not turn out to be my favorite soup place but perhaps there are redeeming dishes. Not an inexpensive lunch by any means, of course (total $35 for two). Lee's Deli remains the winner there where a complete meat & cheese sandwich on wheat with all the fixings + chips (all freshly assembled) is about $5.
author: DeAnn F.

description: This place is really cool for lunch.  I don't normally like ramen but this place is pretty fun and tasty. There is often a line pretty quickly.
author: Josh B.

description: This is another of many examples of restaurants that are all about marketing and barely about food. It was a solid 3-star experience. Boring.
author: Eater S.

description: Ramen broth is bland and tasteless.  Slick setting and atmosphere but the broth is not as good as other places in SF.  Definitely not worth the $13 price point.
author: Luis V.

description:
Wow the Hokkaido was not good and was $14.  I've never had bland pork belly before that was a first. 

They have Chinese soup spoons...? It kept slipping into my bland broth, it just seemed so off. 

The cooks were working super hard to make things pretty.
author: Tom Y.

description: I ordered Tokyo pork ramen for the first time.  Wow, I've never had such salty broth in my life!  I didn't add anything, so I think it may have been this salty on purpose?  I'm Asian and coming from an Asian family, I've always finished by drinking the broth after a ramen meal (no, "Top Ramen" doesn't count).  But this broth was so salty, I could barely eat the noodles.  If I ever went back here (it's close to work), I'd definitely order something else.
author: C G.

description:
Good but far too expensive.
Very good broth. Good ingredients.
Had the Tokyo ramen.
Reminded e of the ramen I've had in Japan in a remote train station.
But again it was darn near $20 for a bowl of noodle soup!!!
author: Mike C.

description: I had such high hopes! Photos looked amazing, love Michael Mina,  but the pork donburi was disappointing and pricey as well.  There were strange greens atop the bland pork.  The packaging is creative and the menu reads fantastic, just mediocre.
author: Ros M.

description: The best thing here were the duck wings -- definitely try those if they have them! I prefer my noodles slightly more al dente but the broth was good. There was no wait around dinner time on a weekday so we were in and out pretty quickly. I prefer Katanaya but this is a decent alternative if you are in a hurry.
author: Jia H.

description: Usually this place is crowded around lunch time so I never have a chance to try it. This time I didn't get to have lunch until 2pm so I'm thinking to give this place a try. This place is opened by famous chef Michael Mina. I ordered a Chasu Miso-Butter Hokkaiso Ramen. The Ramen cooked very good and the pork is very tender. I enjoyed the eggs as well. I was thinking to give this place a 4 stars but the broth cut down 1. The broth is tasty but on the salty and sweet side for me. They said the broth supposed to have some heat but u don't really taste the spice but just salty and sweet.  I need to drink a bottom of water afterwards. The service was good. People were friendly. I might go back once in awhile to see if there are any improvements since the location is very convenient to me.  However it is on the pricey side for ramen.
