I can get a better bowl of ramen somewhere else and less expensive. But we need to consider the location is in the financial district so it needs to be more pricey to pay for the rent.
author: Becky K.

description: I love the food here! It's fresh, warm, and incredibly delicious! It seems busy but seats always open up. It's expensive bus so worth it!
author: Heather M.

description: There are plenty of other places in the Bay Area for good quality ramen.  The wait is not worth it for what you're paying.  I ordered the butter miso and the guy told me it's heavy in flavor but meh.  Not worth it but if you really want to try it they open at 8am for breakfast.  it'll be a better time to try it since there are no lines.
author: huong n.

description:
For the price, go elsewhere. For foodies, go elsewhere. For business lunches, go elsewhere. I really can't recommend this restaurant under any circumstances.

For the price, it gives you very little. A small amount of ramen, a couple of eggs and some miscellaneous filler pieces.

For foodies, the taste isn't all that great. I've added chicken to my ramen, and it was overcooked, dry and a bit cold. I assume they cooked it well beforehand, had it sitting on a tray somewhere in the kitchen, and added the chicken pieces to a hot soup thinking I wouldn't notice that the centers were quite cold when I ate it. For the price they charge, and the supposed "premium" feel of the restaurant, I expect them to cook each and every ingredient at the time I order it, even if it takes a tiny bit longer.

For a business luncheon, it's too chaotic and the servers a bit too loose and informal.

This restaurant needs to choose. If it wants a foodie restaurant, it needs to up the quality a lot. If it wants to be a popular lunch spot, it needs to lower its prices a lot. And if it wants to cater to business customers, it needs to quiet down the restaurant a bit, and train its servers to speak more formally and pay attention.
author: J H.

description: Not sure why there are so many overly-harsh reviews on here.  I was just there for lunch today and thought the ramen was really good (especially the eggs).  Yeah, it was more expensive than the hole-in-the-wall places you can go to, but I don't mind paying as long as the food stands up which I thought it did.  There are long lines, but just be smart about it and get there early so you don't have to add your unsatisfactory wait time experience into your review.
author: Jesus H.

description: Solid veggie noodles! Flavorful with a bit of a kick, but not too much for my weak mouth...also good lychee oolong tea!
author: Maña C.

description: Food is ok, albeit overpriced.  Only way to order is via the website, FB, etc.  What a joke, especially at those prices!  How about you pickup the phone so I can order a $14 bowl of glorified Top Ramen...
author: Rick F.

description:
A newly opened restaurant for ramen lovers in FiDi: the partnership between famous chef Micheal Mina and Hana Sushi owner and chef Ken Tominaga. Ramen broth is thick and flavory, noodles are chewy, authentic Tokyo style! It also offers many cute desserts! It is a bit of pricy: $14 for my choice!

My three favorite ramen places in downtown: Katana-ya on Geary, Underground Ramen on Kearny, and this one. Katana-ya is the best! Underground has the best pork belly, a must have topping, but broth is too salty, and service is almost rude!   This one offers a modern touch. Sitting outside, you can do people watching and enjoy a beautiful view of flower pots in front of 101 California building!
author: Emmy P.

description: Really nothing special here. Maybe I am a Ramen nazi but to me the broth is king and the broth here is ehh ok and the noodle was a bit chewy. If you work in the area I would say its ok but its not a place you want to drive down to and pay for parking. Better choices out there.
author: Dennis K.

description: Excellent ramen in FiDi! The outside patio is serene and the food is phenomenal! Don't forget the soy-caramel custard to end on a sweet note!
author: Todd G.

description: Probably 3.5 stars.....fairly good option for ramen at lunchtime in the financial district. It's nice but wouldn't rate the flavour and quality very highly at all...a little overpriced also.
author: Kate G.

description: Long line. Slow to get my standard Hokkaido ramen. Noodles over cooked. Not a lot of taste. Definitely had better ramen even in the city.
author: Quoc T.

description: They need more tables. At least during lunch hour. Long wait, ok ramen, and no place to seat, not worth it.
author: Joe L.

description: I've came here to have lunch with high expectations. I was looking forward the oh-so-popular Ramen Bar that everyone was raging about. I was SO DISAPPOINTED. My lunch was almost over when I finally got my food, "The Ramen" was ok and not to mention how expensive it is for what you get . For now I won't be going back there, but who knows, I might try it again some other time...
author: Kq Y.

description: Broth was rich and savory, noodles slightly al dente. Excellent friendly service and no wait.
author: Greg B.

description: I wanted to love Ramen Bar but disappointed. It's not worth the price - I've had better ramen in Vancouver and Honolulu for half the price (granted that was a about five years ago). I ordered the Tokyo style to go and although the broth had good flavor and hints of fish initailly, the after taste was nothing but sodium. The noodles stuck together and the egg was ok.
author: Ricardo L.

description:
I ordered CHASU MISO-BUTTER HOKKAIDO ramen noodle soup today and added a half glass of water, and the soup noodle was still too salty.  The ramen, pork slice, egg and soup tasted too salty separately or together.  Also I only received one slice of pork.  For $14, it was not worth the money.  

My GF ordered GINGER-BRAISED CHICKEN ramen noodle soup, and she said it tasted real bad.  What a waste of money and time!  Never will we go back there again.

L&C
author: Lily Y.

description:
I had high hopes for this place, but my experience fell short of expectations. I've had ramen in Japan, NY, and around the Bay Area, and this place was a clear miss. 

My bf ordered the regular tokyo-style pork ramen and I ordered their beef tataki ramen salad. 

First off, the ramen broth had a slightly sweet flavor and lacked depth and balance. Perhaps the sweetness was added to suit American taste buds, because we Americans like everything sweet, salty, or buttery!  Also the portions were skimpy, and I was very disappointed with the limited add-ons and incongruous ramen condiments. 

My "salad" was bland and it wasn't until after I had already eaten that I was told they may have forgotten to add the dressing to the actual salad! I ended up eating some the noodles tsukemen style by dipping it in my bf's leftover ramen broth. 

On a positive note, the service and the eggs were great. The eggs were soft boiled to perfection, which I appreciate. 

I realize that this place is new and is still probably working out a bunch of kinks. That said, I am willing to give it another try, but I will not be returning with nearly the same amount of enthusiasm as my first visit.
author: Cathy C.

description: Lousy service. Waiter pretended he didn't see you. Ramen way overrated and very salty. Service is the worst ever.
author: Dave C.

description: I wish I could give this trendy ramen spot a higher score, but westernized Asian food often lack on the fundamentals. This place did not understand that ramen should be hot, not lukewarm, but piping hot. The tepid temperature made the fatty chashu kind of disgusting. No one wants to slurp up cold broth with chunks of fat floating around!! Just heat up the damn soup.
author: Sharon L.

description:
Decent ramen. Close to work which is nice. At the end of the day though, it's just ramen. Ingredients seemed fresh. 

Ramen
Ramen 
Wanna get some ramen 
Let's go to the ramen bar
author: Jay Y.

description: I rarely write reviews, but am compelled to do so this time as Ramen Bar completely and utterly underwhelmed me. First off, the service was attentive and surroundings neat, clean, and orderly. I wanted to try it out due to the Michael Mina connection which in my mind = quality, flavorful, refined food. While the noodles in the Hokkaido ramen were al dente, the broth lacked depth and the chasu pork lacked punch and moisture. The pork buns were deconstructed al la' David Chang, but didn't standout. I'm half Japanese, have spent quite a bit of time in Japan, and have been to my fair share of noodle shops both authentic and experimental. Ramen Bar didn't deliver on either account and I'm not gravitating towards a repeat journey unless I hear they've improved on what should be their signature dish. I can get better a better, more flavorful bowl of noodles in Narita airport.
author: Lawrence S.

description:
Clean, nice restaurant. I tried Hokkaido ramen which has corn, seaweed, and pork. It was good with tasty broth, and right volume.

However, Ramen is quick street food after all. I've never seen $15 ramen ($14+tax) in Tokyo. And it was a bit too salty.
author: Max M.

description:
I'm not pretending to know how to make perfect ramen like the rest of these reviews but I loved my first visit to The Ramen Bar.  The food was outstanding.  My party ordered an array of menu options which can lead to complications but everything came out to order.  Smelled, Looked, and TASTED great.  

I will definitely go back and recommend this Ramen deliciousness to everyone.

And a special thank you to the Sous Chef that day.  You could tell he was the man in charge doing all the work.  Thanks again for a great meal.
author: Max F.

description:
Long line, pricey, small portion.
The taste is average, a little salty. Service is great and staffs are friendly but I was disappointed with their portion and price.
author: Jenna S.

description: My colleagues and I went for lunch to this place. I didn't expect too much because of the 3-ish star review. I  was pleasantly surprised because not only was the line fast moving, the wait for the food wasn't long  at all. I had the mushroom and soy ramen and it was absolutely delicious. The broth was flavorful and not too salty which a lot of vegetarian ramens tend to be. There was plenty of mushroom and corn, which I loved. I think this is definitely one of the best ramens  I have had in San Francisco.
author: Maddy K.

description: It's ok ramen.  I have had better but it will do if you work in the area and craving ramen.
author: Cj P.

description: Fantastic Ramen. I had the Shrimp and Crab dumpling ramen, and it was packed with flavor. Highly recommend this place.
author: Moon J.

description: Jesus, the broth here is the worst I have ever had at a ramen restaurant.  Period.  Based on the taste/texture, it seems that they diluted the crap out of a broth and then dumped in MSG to try to mask it.  I have been to most of the ramen places in the city, and I can confidently say that The Ramen Bar is the worst, bar none.
author: John M.

description: The cash register didn't know the difference btwn tonkotsu & tonkatsu & I got wrong kind. Anyway this is not japanese standard & way way too expensive.
author: Reika F.

description: Fresh ingredients account for higher prices.  Very tasty take on ramen noodles (not to be confused with the ramen noodles you can buy in the grocery stores).  Casual setting and lines get long so go early.
author: Platform Universe S.

description: I've been here a few times now and loved it each time. So far I've tried the mushroom and soy, Chasu Miso-Butter Hokkaido and the Tokyo Style Kurobuta Pork. The Tokyo style was especially fantastic, and no surprise that's Chef Tominaga's preferred style. The broth is light yet still completely packed with flavor. What other reviewers call "bland" I call perfectly balanced. The broth is flavorful but does not oversaturate the other flavors in the bowl. The noodles had a good, firm texture and the soft-boiled egg tasted like it was marinated in some sort of magic sauce. So good! Very highly recommended. Oh, and get a pitcher of Kirin to (hopefully) share, nothing like a crisp lager to complement this broth.
author: Darren K.

description: This is by far the worst ramen I have ever had.  It just goes to show that a fancy venue and the name of a well know chef does not equal ramen success.  I got the miso broth which tasted terrible.  The noodles felt like they dumped spaghetti noodles from a box in the bowl and there were no green onions.  I also felt that for $15 I should have gotten a lot more and be able to choose what goes in my ramen.  Ramen Bar you you should take notes from Ramen Underground.  Their place is nothing fancy but they have really perfected the most amazing ramen and they didn't need the name of a big chef to do so.
author: Athena P.

description: I had the pork belly shoyu ramen. The presentation was great, but the broth was very plain and nondescript and the meat portions were pitiful (one bit of pork belly in the pork belly ramen?!?). The cured eggs were very well done, as were the noodles which were well textured and flavorful. Hopefully they expand the ramen menu in the future to include a tonkotsu because their shoyu tasted more like a weak shio. Overall I can't help but feel that they focused more on the appearance of the ramen than the flavor. Also for the price you'd expect a larger portion overall, but given their location and higher end decor it fits the bill. I was hoping for this spot to take over the ramen scene downtown but it's not going to knock the socks off of anyone who has had ramen from any of the top Bay Area spots.
author: Sebastian A.

description: Very disappointing.  Ramen was unimaginative and was not served hot enough.  Won't be back
author: A J.

description: Shocked at how bad this is.  I am Japanese and have had hundreds of ramen noodles (mainly in Japan).  This could be the worst.  For starters, they don't serve potstickers.  WTF.  Ramen without potstickers?!   I tried the tokyo ramen.  The broth had no depth in flavor and was really salty.  It was like an oily soy sauce.  The pork was hard instead of melting in the mouth.  The noodles were plain.  I lived in Tokyo and hope people don't think this is what Tokyo shoyu ramen is like.
author: M H.

description: I am a fan of Michael Mina restaurants since I work in the financial district.  This is my first time come to his Ramen shop.  It wasn't crowed at around 2:30pm.  Order Taker was nice to ask us this was our first time visit or not.  Knowing is our first time, she explains the menus choices thoroughly and she recommends the Hokkido ramen.  I have ordered that and everything is live up to expectations.  Broth is good and Noodle is cooked just right.  One thing I would suggest is if their broth temperature can be hotter cause it was not hot enough when it was served.  Otherwise perfect place to have lunch or dinner at anytime.
author: Jimmy L.

description: unbeknownst to me this place is more conducive to the lunch crowd than the dinner crowd. it's set up so that you order and pay at the counter then sit down to eat. at dinner it's regular service but seeing the counter setup throws you off quite a bit. the ramen is not bad. coming from the Michael Mina group, i wish that i could say it was some sort of exceptional ramen but i can't. the noodles are thinner than i prefer but otherwise it's a decent bowl that would suffice during a period of ramen craving. that being said, i wouldn't purposely go back as there are better ramens found around the city and it's surrounding areas.
author: Regina C.

description: I think this is the best ramen place in the FiDi area! My coworker and I frequent this place a lot when we crave for ramen. There is always a long line but the line moves fast. During lunch rush hour you kinda have to fight for a table. The tables inside are very close to each other. It's so close that one time the people on the next table were doing lunch interview and I could hear everything. People working in the front taking orders are very friendly. One time I couldn't find that small reward card she offered me a new one instantly and told me that I can combine both to redeem the rewards. YaY! Even though it's such little thing, I do appreciate such attention to details when it comes to service.
author: Bob H.

description: The best ramen in the city for my money with the best ingredients and the most friendly staff. A casual but top notch meal.
author: Daniel E.

description: The moment I walk in, I ask for a table and I waited about 30 mins for one.  When a table finally clears up, they said they'll seat me in a few minutes.  Then suddenly, they told me some celebrity chef I've never heard of is coming in and is taking our table, so we had to wait another 20 minutes for a table.  The hostess was nice but I don't appreciate having to be told that I will get a table, then suddenly won't get a table.  The ramen I got was ok, but not that great.  I feel the hype of this place will last for a while, then it will go downhill, like all ramen shops in the city.  New places are only good for the first few months, then the quality starts to wane.  All in all, I would probably avoid this place and go for somewhere else that actually opens on weekends and caters to normal people.
author: Jim N.

description: Not sure exactly what the hype is all about other than the place is sitting dead smack the SF FiDi.  I had the most expensive ramen (shrimp & crab, $16) thinking it'd be a winner but ended up being very mediocre.  I could've walk to CT and gotten a lot more for the money.  Nothing to write home about and there will not be another trip.
author: Marc F.

description: I don't know what all the fuss is about this place.  I just came from japan 2 weeks ago and this is horrible.  I think this was the look of Ramen but taste texture not even close.  Everything is wrong, I can list the issues one by one.  But it would be a waste of time I can do better.  Maybe just open one of my own.  The price way too high for the amount portion you are getting for the meat.  The meat should be flavorful not the boiled meat that was in the bowl.
author: Jon Y.

description: If you're a ramen officionado, this ramen is like Michael Crabtree...mediocre, at best.  If you're just looking for a quick fix on your lunch break, this place is great due to the limited options in the area.
author: Rick N.

description: Was so looking forward to our meal here last night. I had been craving good Ramen in the new year. The service was very good (only reason for the 2 stars,) attentive, extremely nice, helpful, etc. but overall the food was so disappointing. Way too salty- couldn't even taste the other flavors in the Ginger Chicken Ramen. Was overwhelmingly salty. I will definitely not be back
author: Ashley S.

description: Decent ramen place at inflated prices, but nothing special. I had a miso butter ramen and beef curry dish. I enjoyed the curry dish more, but neither were spectacular and both cost more than they would have if this were not a Mina restaurant.
author: Josh Q.

description: Had high expectations but the Tokyo Ramen didn't blow my mind.
author: Ann H.

description: I came here with friends for dinner.  I ordered Tokyo style ramen. This had no tonkotsu broth. The soup was salty and pork was dry. The crispy duck wings were too dry.
author: E W.

description: Unique in the FiDi, but way overpriced; slow and indifferent service; disorganized process for ordering. Room for improvements, I hope they make them!
author: TXSebas T.

description: The noodles were inexcusably, ridiculously soggy. Otherwise inoffensive, but altogether totally forgettable and lacking in character.
author: Chris S.

description: Great location, but don't expect a Michael Mina meal.
author: Ken W.

description: Long lines - reasonably fast service once order was taken - a bit noisy - ramen was OK, not but not super special.  There are many better choices for ramen.  Mushroom salad was surprisingly greasy.   The place was enormous for a ramen place; not at all the ambiance I usually associate with ramen places in Japan or Northern California.
author: Christopher T.
